description:
I walked pass this restaurant a couple time and it seemed to always full. Since my friends from out of town craved for "shaking cow" hahahaha. But Anh Hong was closed. they picked this one so it'd be closer to my place. I was excited from reading the positive reviews from yelp.

Apparently, this place is described as a fancy "Pholicious" restaurant. Ironically, we ordered anything but Pho. We all craved for the same dish so the four of us ordered exactly the same "Claypot Catfish". Well, actually, one guy ordered "Claypot Shrimp". Usually, it'd take awhile for clay pot dish to get ready however, Mau service was quick. The clay pot was still boiling. Yum. The fish was soft, caramel coated, smelled like cotton candy. A bit salty I must say. If you ask me whether this place is an authentic Vietnamese restaurant, it's a no. A decent restaurant with a pleasant ambiance. Great customer services. Westernize vibe. Only mediocre tasting. I understand this place is known for Pho. Perhaps, other dishes aren't their expertise. 

I know this restaurant is marked with $$. Still, the portion is quite small for the dear price.
author: Bao V.

description:
This place is a new take on traditional Vietnamese dishes. I came in looking for something traditional and I'll be honest, I was a little disappointed at first. At first I couldn't decided to between pho and a rice plate, but I decided to go with a rice plate because Vietnamese rice plates a usually come with a small bowl of soup.

I ordered the Shaken Beef. This was DELICIOUS. Unfortunately the dish didn't come with soup, so I asked for a small bowl. The soup wasn't really that great. 

Overall I felt like it was a bit pricey for Vietnamese food. The shaken beef was $17 and they charged me $4.50 for the small bowl of soup.
author: Gail M.

description:
In a pinch... Bar seating is always a good idea.

Got the Hu Tieu Kho because it sounded interesting, and it was. The server asked if I have ever had it and I said nope. He instructed me to sip the broth in between bites... interesting, I thought, bc like a vermicelli bowl, I might've dumped it out into the noodles. Bam. He was right. 

The broth cleansed my palate each  salty, sweet, and chewy bite of he noodles with pork and peanuts. I asked for more broth as well and it was great. 

So if you want like a dry phô meal, this is a go to and you won't be disappointed. One star off because it is on the smaller portions side than regular phô.
author: John Michael R.

description:
When hipster meets Vietnamese food, you get Mau! This means fancy cocktails and a *relatively* expensive food menu. I tried a couple of the dishes here and some are great, while some where pretty average. 

Depending on when you come to Mau, it can be pretty quiet (when nobody is inside) or it can be REALLY loud. When the restaurant is full of the Mission hipsters at dinner time, it can be pretty hard to have a conversation since the restaurant seems to insulate sound very well. There's a fair amount of seating, but depending on when you come - you may have to wait up to an hour (e.g. prime dinner time on the weekends).

Of the dishes that I had, my favorite include the cha ca la vong, and the Hue rolls. The cha ca la vong is a Northern Vietnamese dish that features turmeric/dill catfish - it is served over vermicelli noodles and served with lettuce, picked veggies which you mix with the fermented fish sauce condiment.  If you like, you can also ask for regular fish sauce (nuoc mam) which I prefer over the traditional fermented fish sauce. This dish is traditionally served with peanuts (as it is a Mau), so if you have a peanut allergy, I'd ask for the peanuts to not be served with it. This is probably my TOP dish here and it's reasonable at $14 since the portions are BIG.  In addition, the Hue rolls (beef with a lot of herbs wrapped in rice skin, with nuoc mam dipping sauce) and are a great appetizer and fairly filling and definitely tasty. Recommend that too.

I also had the pho here, which I don't really recommend since it was a bit bland for my taste. However, of the noodles... and to note, my friends really like the Bun Bo Hue here - which I tried their broth and it was quite tasty and had the right amount of kick and spice.

Overall, the prices at Mau are more expensive for what you may be used for Vietnamese food. However, Vietnamese food in SF tends to be more expensive due to higher rent/cost of living. So I'm used to paying 10-11$ for a bowl of pho - so $14 for the cha ca la vong with pretty big portions is not too much more. Plus you're also paying for the ambiance and the trendiness of being in the Mission District.

I've been coming here for a few years now, and would recommend Mau primarily for the cha ca la vong and Hue rolls dishes. To avoid a wait, I would recommend coming here during off-peak lunch/dinner times - that  way it'll be less noisy and you can hear your friends/dates/S.O. while you guys eat.  I'll definitely be back for my turmeric catfish here. :)
author: Matthew L.

description: Delicious and fresh food! Everything that we ordered on the menu was really good except the tofu pho with vegetarian broth. The menu is great for vegetarian and gluten free options, portions are big and still not with a big price tag! Only deducting a star as the service was super slow and chaotic! The server brought the menus 15 mins after we were seated and drinks came only only after we finished the appetizers. We got our tables right away when we walked in around 7pm on a Saturday night, everyone who came after us had to wait, which was again not systematic. Must try if you have patience!
author: Nidhi M.

description:
Pretty standard Viet place, except more clean + modern look + menu. Vermicelli bowls + pho are always good choices. Spring rolls are delish.

If you're vegetarian, be wary that there may be meat in your meal, despite the item being marked veggie. Our friend who got the Pho Tofu (which is marked as veggie on the menu), received a bowl of veggies + tofu + beef. We got it sent it back for a new one after we told the server, but it was still pretty awkward. 

Overall a decent option in the area if you're looking for comforting + clean food, but if you're looking for legit Vietnamese, you'll need to head over to Pho 2000 or Miss Saigon.
author: Elisa L.

description: Great food, friendly service! Probably my favorite tofu pho anywhere. And they somehow manage to keep all the moving parts of this incredibly busy restaurant moving in synch, turning out consistently great food, quickly, and with a smile
author: Ben R.

description:
Pretty good Vietnamese restaurant in the Mission. Seeing as this looks more hipster and fancy, my expectations were low but was delightfully surprised by how good the food was.

The ambiance is nice and modern and the place seemed pretty busy coming for dinner on a weeknight. The servers were noticeably pretty attentive for us. 

The menu consists of interesting starters such as Hue Rolls, Lotus Shoot Salad, Banh Xeo. There's noodles, vermicelli bowls and rice plates. They serve banh mi only for lunch. Prices are on the higher side for Vietnamese cuisine. Expect to spend atleast $12+ for an entree. You can add tendon/tripe/beef balls for $2 and veggies for $2.5 to the noodles.

Pho Ga ($10.5) - Poached chicken, rice noodles, ginger-chicken broth. I really liked the integration of ginger in the broth. It tasted great for the most part and I added veggies in which was a good choice.

I'd love to come back. The food here was quite memorable!
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Food was very delicious and loved the cocktail that I ordered. I usually go to Pho as a comfort food without the glam, but Mau definitely kicks up the "date night" factors.

The ambiance is very hipster/organic with a delicious vietnamese food and a night out vibe. The food is also very tasty. We got the meatballs as an appetizer with pho to follow.  

The only critique is that the service was very slow. I think we waited around 45-1 hr before our pho came out. It was pretty crowded, but we were a bit hangry.

Ambiance: 5/5
Food: 4.5/5
Service: 4/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Pho was delicious. The chicken was a little too tough but the rest of the flavor made up for this. Casual spot to catch up with your friends.
author: Maleah O.

description:
Firstly I would like to note that I would be giving this place a 4 review if the service hadn't been so bad.

My boyfriend and I stopped here for an impromptu dinner on our way home Friday m work last week. The restaurant was packed but we were seated immediately by the hostess. Although I was pleased we did not have to wait, the table where we were seated was probably the least desirable spot in the whole restaurant, tucked way in the back corner by the registers and where the high chairs are stacked. 

We ordered the Hue roll to start, my boyfriend ordered the 5 Spice chicken entree, and I had the [DECONSTRUCTED] Vermicelli bowl with pork. 

The hue roll is basically just a spring roll that has been steamed - it was delicious (although admittedly not very different from a regular spring roll...). My boyfriend really enjoyed his chicken dish as did I. 

The Vermicelli is a dish that I order at many Vietnamese restaurants, as it is a staple, and one of my favorites at that. This dish however, comes with the same standard ingredients but the dish is deconstructed. Typically you'll have a large bowl with a bed of cold noodles, lettuce, sprouts, cilantro, mint, and pickled carrots and diakon served with fresh grilled pork or chicken on top and a side of fish sauce to pour over your bowl. This dish had a small bowl with the pork and noodles, and all the veggies on a plate, and most of the veggies were left either whole or on very large pieces - very difficult to eat. I'm not sure how this is designed to be eaten, but it was so difficult that I ended up asking for a pho bowl to put all my food in. Once the REconstruction was complete, the food was actually very good. 

The big rub here was the terrible service. I do not remember the name of our server, but my guess is that he forgot about our table as we were hidden in the corner. He came to our table 3 times. The first was to take our order, the second was when my boyfriend flagged him down so I could get the pho bowl I needed, and the third was when by boyfriend again flagging him down to get our bill. He was not rude or anything, just non-existent. No refills of our drinks, no check-ins to see how the food was tasting, no request if we would like to order dessert. Maybe he was just busy and had lots of other tables that were not hidden...I'm not sure. 

I spoke with the manager before leaving and said he hoped we would return and assured me that our next experience would be better. I'll have a hard time talking my boyfriend into eating here again.  We shall see.
author: Taylor D.

description:
Mau is the sister restaurant of Tin. I like them both but seem to like Mau better. 

I generally order vegan pho and spring rolls (without mushrooms) and these dishes are generally pretty good. My only gripe is that I wish they gave you the option to choose different noodles, because I am not a fan of the thin noodles Vietnamese places use in San Francisco. 

Other than that, Mau has become of of my favorite takeout places. I will glady continue consuming their vegetarian spring rolls!
author: Christina M.

description:
The food here is very mediocre and overpriced. I came here for a late weekend lunch about an hour before they closed - luckily only a short wait. There were many families with young children dining here, and the ambiance is a little more modern than the usual Vietnamese restaurant. 

I ordered the pho bo, which is a rice noodle soup with brisket. The beef broth was good. Meat was quite generous but noodles were lacking in portion. Also, the noodles were either over cooked or sitting for a while, because they would break whenever I grabbed them with my chopsticks. Overall, not worth the $11 cost. In my opinion, you can find much better and less expensive Vietnamese food in East Bay!
author: Christine L.

description:
Wow what a whirlwind of emotions.. after finding out it was temporary closed then seeing a yelper's review on them being permanently closed, I saw an updated article that they will be back. What a relief! 

Although this place looks fusion and more modern, their food is pretty legit. I never had the food in Vietnam, my boyfriend who grew up in Vietnam says the food tastes really similar. They have dishes he says doesn't normally see at other Vietnamese restaurants. We tried their Bun Cha Hanoi twice, turmeric fish and caramelized cat fish. I love their Bun Cha Hanoi, it comes with fresh veggies/herbs, vermicelli noodles, and the meat on the side with their sauce. I like the fact that their pork is tender and they come with meatballs too. My bf is always impressed that the waiters can say/pronounce the dishes in Vietnamese. The turmeric fish isn't my thing only because I think I don't like turmeric but my bf says it tasted really authentic. 

For now, I'm glad they will be back, but not sure if their price increases on their dishes will scare me away due to the rent increase.
author: Stephanie T.

description: So awkwardly sweet.  The hue rolls were but omg we got pork that literally tasted like it was brewed in sweet tea.  Too much for me.
author: Rebecca J.

description: Slow mediocre food. Got the fish vermicelli. Wish it had more broth. Wife's tofu pho was also bland.
author: John A.

description: Nice atmosphere, decor, and pretty good food. I enjoyed the papaya salad (comes with shrimp AND calamari) and the bun bo hue (beef shank, rare niman ranch eye-of-round, pork sausage, pork belly, spicy lemongrass chicken broth) was quite good. They have some interesting drinks and the service was friendly as well. I'll definitely be down to come here again to try some more of their dishes.
author: Christina W.

description: Had takeout from here! Loved the food and plating. I think we would definitely consider going to the location or doing takeout. Banh Xeo (like a seafood omelet crepe) was amazing with perfect portion of seafood to crispy omelet. The hue rolls were also very good. We had a fried rice dish but I forget what it was called. I think the portions were good and the quality was really what made it stand out. I had expected the seasoning of the food not to be as on point and the banh Xeo to be soggy. Thanks to our friends who introduced us to this spot!!
author: Lily P.

description: A hipster take on Vietnamese food. I liked it, though. The beef pho was delicious although a bit pricey. The restaurant's atmosphere is pretty chill and this place seems like a great place to hang out with friends.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Delicious lemongrass chicken rice plate! Dense with lemongrass flavor, which I often crave. It has fish sauce I think which is also tasty. The sauce overall is a bit sweet so the rice is a good match to balance it out. I ordered the cha gio on the side which is like a fried egg roll. Comes at extra charge.

The more unique dish is the lotus root salad. Thanks to the Yelper who added a pic of this and said it's a must have. I agree! Has pig ears--so delicious. Crispy chewy and porky. Yummy.
author: Alias A.

description:
Let's start off with the fact it's a common saying that "nothing can beat my mom's, aunt's, grandma's (or father's, grandfather's, uncle's) home cooking. And it's probably because every family will put a spin or twist on their culture's cuisine. I came to this restaurant with an open mind and with an unbiased mindset. 

I went here with my friend at 12pm on Tuesday, per the recommendation from my brother. Immediately when the doors opened at 12pm there were at least 6 tables sat. We were surprised because I have never seen that happen before at a restaurant - so my expectations were quite high and I was super excited! 

Cleanliness (4/5): Everything seemed clean. No dried water marks on the serveware or glass cups. No visible stains on the table clothes or chairs. All around, it just looked clean. 

Customer Connection (4/5): We got seated right away. Welcoming greeting. The server probably had around 5 tables (and it kept increasing as we sat there) so I totally understand he was quite busy. Speed of service was okay; but, I wasn't expecting quick service. The thing that stood out the most for me in terms of connection was the server's genuine option between two salads I was debating on ordering. More often than ever, I always hear "well it depends on your taste". I 100% agree but I wouldn't be asking for YOUR opinion if I didn't want to hear it. So, THANK YOU server to being honest. He also checked up on us throughout the meal. Overall, pleasant! 

Service/Product Quality (3/5): We ordered the papaya salad, banh xeo (basically a vietnamese savory crepe), and the cat fish claypot with brown rice. Out of the three, the papaya salad was DELICIOUS. I generally don't like papaya ... or I though I didnt...but this salad was a great fresh start to the meal. Again, thank you server who recommended it. The banh xeo was similar to the ones my mom makes but also different. The overall taste of the banh xeo was okay. The problem I had was that the crepe itself was thick so the under layer was soggy and undercooked while the outer layer was crispy. I assume the crepe was too thick. That wasn't good. The Cat fish claypot was ok, but too salty for me - that could be my own personal preference as I have cut down on my sodium intake. 

I might come back to try other dishes like noodles with grilled steak/beef or even the pho.
author: Martin N.

description:
Was feeling slightly under the weather and needed some chicken pho for my aching soul. Came here around 1:30pm for lunch on a Tuesday and was surprised to find the place still 3/4 full.

The soup was fantastic, incredibly flavorful and not too salty. The chicken however, ranged from being tender to extremely overcooked. Bit disappointing.

This place is a bit pricier than the typical Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Tim X.

description:
The pho here is so very good. Noodles come a bit al dente so that they are not overlooked by the end of your bowl. Beef is very high quality. I always get the pho bo. Ambience is great and service is also held at a high bar. The food is good enough that I have also come here alone and sat at the bar on nights when I just craved a good bowl of pho after a long workday

My go tos: Pho Bo, Cha ca la vong, Banh Xeo
author: Diane W.

description:
May has changed! Prices have increased and the pho (all noodle soups, for that matter) portions have shrunken! Way smaller bowl, fewer ingredient, a lot less broth but it's more money. 

Service is the same - SLLOOOOWWW AF.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Is three stars generous? I don't know it might be. Everything was mediocre/fine but I know it could have been better for sure. I came here for lunch with my friends and was seated right away. First thing I thought to myself when we walked in was, "Where are the Viet people?" I think I might have seen one person working in the kitchen but the rest of the employees were white, which is fine but is something I'm not used to seeing when I think about going to a Viet place to eat. The space is nice and pretty. We took our time figuring out what we wanted then ordered. It felt like the food came in about 20-30 minutes which was fine since we were talking. I ended up ordering the claypot catfish.

We were all pretty hungry since we didn't eat much for the whole day so when the food came out we were ready to chow down. I, on the other hand, was let down when I saw the size of the clay pot. It's like one of the small stone bowls used to eat kimchi tofu soup. It matched the size of the rice bowl, which I have to say it was nice that it comes with rice. But for the price I am paying, I expected portion size to be a lot bigger, so seeing a small pot come out made me sad but I still had hope in the flavor. My friend's food came out and it looked perfectly portioned for an ok price but I believe my item was one of the more expensive items so I would expect a bit more.

The texture of the fish was soft and easy to chew. No bones. It was seasoned very well but it was a bit on the salty side for me. I recommend​ eating the fish with the rice, but if you want to eat the separate I also recommend drizzling the fish sauce at the bottom of the clay pot onto the rice to give the rice some flavor too. The meal for me consisted of putting the fish onto the rice because of the saltiness that kept building up. In the end it left me content and not full, though I was eager to eat a whole hardy meal for lunch.

Overall, food is fine to eat but portion size might be questionable. I also did notice a lot of waiting around for people to tend to us but most of the time it was us flagging down a waiter. I could go back to try all of the other Viet food as well to see my take on it but I can get the exact same things from my home or any place in San Jose since there is a large Vietnamese population there.
author: Timothy D.

description: Great place for Vietnamese food in the mission. Great and efficient service as well. Tried the Papaya salad and the classic beef pho- both Delicious. Have only had pho at traditional Vietnamese restaurants, so it was a nice to try a more Americanized version of the classic dish. Loved it. Would def go back!
author: Linda H.

description: I was here a couple Thursday's ago with my girlfriend I decided to take her out for a nice  Vietnamese restaurant everything was going well until the host sat us down named Mario short brown guy had a very rude attitude towards us it was like he was having a horrible day. We sit down looking at the menu when we decide to ask if we can switch tables as the restaurant was pretty much empty with like a couple people in and so called Mario with a rude attitude say's (NO) what kinda of customer service is this he needs to be retrain or fired this is unacceptable. i would love to speak to the owner of this place. If you see a short brown guy as the host your better off going to a different place
author: Chris H.

description: So today was the first time in years I've eaten here and I remembered it being good. So I brought my co worker and first there was no host to greet or take our name for a table we stood inside the doors for about 7 minutes until we spoke up. Also we had ordered the bok Choy with our meals and which we never received and however were almost still charged for it. The food was good that I was please with but the service is not that great, it did not feel like they had servers but a few food runners going around. It's missing that customer service experience.
author: Phillip D.

description: Still super popular neighborhood modern pho with a twist. Want better, healthier pho options? A modern twist on the comfort food / soup? Well this place is the way to go. Situated comfortably in the vibrant mission district, on the popular valencia street, this is an interest success. There's an all meat pho - 5 kinds of meat, but did you know you can add extra veggie? We did that. Carrots, broccoli... that's a good thing to try
author: Dilys S.

description:
Excellent service! We came in 20 min before closing, sat us and let us stay 40 min after closing without ever pressuring us to leave. Very chill vibe.
Veggie pho didn't have much broth, asked for more, which they did charge us for :\ 
Garlic boc Choi was so yummy.
Papaya salad was delicious, recommend stirring it up before enjoying!
Only one choice of Nigori, which was $34 for a bottle, a bit steep but was really good.
Will def be back.
author: Jena L.

description: A very nice hip place to grab a bowl of vermicelli noodles on a hot Thursday afternoon. Loved that it comes with tons of veggies underneath the noodles and the flavor was all there. It would of been perfect if the pork wasn't dry. I also ordered coconut juice and it was really refreshing. I wanted another but I had to remind myself that I can have all I want this summer in Hawaii. Regret that I didn't the second I walked back out in the hot sun.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to eat on Valencia.

Some recs:
* Hue rolls
* Claypot Catfisn
* Any pho

I also love the staff. Special props to Nadeem (sic?) behind the bar, and Caleb on the floor. 

The only reason I docked a star is that the actual environment is a bit too noisy. But you can't go wrong with the food and service!
author: Alice W.

description:
Rich flavorful broth, affordable price point, and a tasteful dining spot in the heart of the mission. 

Had a nice sampling of many dishes, and everything, even the vegetarian broth was lovely.  Spring rolls and Pho would bring me back. 

I'm always pleasantly surprised by places like this that seem overly chic, but in actuality offer fairly priced dishes in a non cliquey setting.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I'm born and raised in San Jose, which means I grew up eating the best kinds of Vietnamese Food and have high expectations when it comes to a bowl of Pho. My friend was hesitant to take me here knowing my standards but he took a leap of faith anyways. I was glad he took me here because the food ended up being spectacular!

I ordered a bowl of Chicken Pho and was mesmerized by how flavorful the broth was. The chicken was also fresh and tasted delicious dipped in siracha and hoisin sauce. The staff was also really friendly when I requested for extra jalapeños to add to my soup. I love when my pho has a spicy kick!

Overall this place is pretty pricey for Vietnamese food, but it definitely gets the job done when you're feeling sick or need to recover from a hangover. It's nice knowing that there is a Vietnamese restaurant in the middle of the Mission. I'll definitely be visiting this place more often, especially after a night of heavy drinking!
author: MyTien P.

description:
Since the bf prefers soupy foods for hangovers, we've been to Mau more than once. The menu is pretty extensive, so I appreciate I'm not stuck getting pho each time he craves it. The food is pretty decent. The pho ga is solid. The spring rolls were a bit bland - get the Hue rolls instead. The five spice quail was dry. The rice plates are okay.

Service is fast, though not the friendliest. We've never had a problem getting a table during lunch time, but I have had very short waits for dinner. It's usually clean-ish, but I have seen numerous flies buzzing around during the summer heatwaves.
author: Eva W.

description:
Food: I can only review the pho bo. I've eaten a lot
If pho and didn't expect to like the one. But I did. Wish they put more noodles if they are gonna charge 13 bucks. But overall it's tasty. 

Place: regular casual spot. Nothing special, but nothing bad at all.
author: P L.

description: Had high hopes especially when I saw the banana blossom salad on the menu which elicited much excitement. Tbh, it was ok. Well marinated and crunchy but skimpy on protein. The soup for the dry noodle was bland on top but ladened with salt on the bottom. Chicken clay pot was small in portion and needed some sort of veggie to pair with it. Fried egg rolls were good - I appreciated the thin, crisp wrapper that provided a light, airy crunch. The price of cocktails needs to be reduced if all you're getting is 70% ice in a small, small vessel.
author: Julie L.

description:
Mau is a great Vietnamese spot in the mission with cool and hip ambiance. 

I think the dishes are pretty authentic. They have all the typical Vietnamese dishes such as spring rolls, pho, bun, rice plates with BBQ meats. All are delicious and great quality! 

For the pho, you can add tripe and tendon, which is awesome. This place is vegetarian and vegan friendly too. You can get pho with vegetables broth. 

This place also serves refreshing cocktails and great selection of wine and sake.
author: Sam M.

description: I paid $10.5 for a pho and $4 for a can of Diet Coke (before tax). I don't mind the total bill but the distribution feels like a scam. Food is good and reasonably priced, but pricing the drinks at such a disproportionate level to the food and at the highest price I've ever seen for a can of Diet Coke at an otherwise affordable restaurant felt like extortion, since they know no one really checks the price on Coke products. It wasn't even free refills... :(
author: Ellie G.

description:
This is a comment from a Vietnamese born kid: 
- This place is definitely an American Style Vietnamese food 
- Comparing to other fancy trendy Vietnamese restaurant, MAU does do a good job in trying to keep the authenticity of Vietnamese food. I def have to give the food quality some credits. Unlike others, MAU didn't twist the taste or the origin of Vietnamese food - good job. 

- I don't know about others but GOD, go easy on the salt & fish sauce please - it's SO salty for my taste buds :( 

- Pho is OK. Not really my style since I'm from Northern Vietnam. 
- Bun rieu (Crab noodle soup): Don't say it as a crab noodle soup when you are using ground pork to imitate the "crab" in this dish. I like the fish because it's flavorful & has more filling to it but It's not "Bun Rieu" if there's no "Rieu" to it (Crab meat) 

- Grilled Pork Noodle is another recommended dish. (Big meat patties though) 

- Tofu Clay Pot is another good one 

In conclusion, it's a good place to try Vietnamese food and at least you are getting something close to the authentic Viet food. 4*/5
author: Thao P.

description: Best Vietnamese food in the Mission/Castro/Noe valley area. Salads are all fantastic, fresh with vibrant flavors. Lemongrass anything is delicious. Highly recommend this place.
author: Mike T.

description:
SERVICE - Was super slow, the table next to my table of two (a family of 4) all got their food before us. It took more than 15 minutes for me to flag someone down so I could order, but when the servers noticed they were very attentive and enthusiastic. 

FOOD - food also took a long time to arrive, which I'm not used to when it comes to pho. 
     *Pho Bo - I got the Pho Bo which had high quality meat and yummy beef broth. The flavors don't taste as authentic as other Vietnamese pho but tastes healthier! 

     *Tofu Pho - My friend got the Tofu pho and she said it was average, nothing spectacular. 

     *Young Coconut - Super refreshing on a hot summer day!
author: Jocelyne L.

description:
You know the saying - if you love something, let it go. And if it comes back, then you know it's meant to be. 

This saying rings true for me when it comes to Mau. When they first opened, I didn't want to like it. This was when I was younger. More naive. I said things like "The only good pho places are hole-in-the-walls."  "Is this place asian fusion. Ew." 

But then I tried it. And I did like it. 

I went there a couple of times, not a lot.

But then in November 2017, they closed. I walked by it and my heart sank. Oh no... Mau closed. This is upsetting because I did like it, but I didn't go very often. Worst of all they are closing because their landlord is trying to jack up their rent. 

I look across the street to West of Pecos. Which is not good. They get good reviews on yelp and are always busy. Even though they are... NOT GOOD.  And I look at Mau - tasty food, decently priced (for valencia street), great ambiance... and I wonder - WTF?? 

It's a decently priced asian place with good food right on Valencia street. And now it's gone. Probably to be replaced by some not good, expensive fusion place of some type. 

Yes, still harking on fusion food. Old habits die hard.

But then, I walk by and I see a sign. They're coming back! They've worked it out with their landlord who tried to kill them.

Since then, I've been back to Mau a few times. And I have to say - they really are very good. I love their ultra hearty noodle soups. And I love they have a large variety of them. 

For anyone who complains that you can get Pho for a lot less than that somewhere else, it is true. But you have to consider that they are paying for rent on Valencia street. You are eating at a clean place with nice decor and ambiance. And their ingredients are super fresh. So yeah, you're going to pay a premium compared to the hole-in-the-walls. Deal with it. 

All-in-all. I'm glad Mau is back. And I definitely plan on visiting much more often.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
Hands down my FAVORITE Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco and ALL of the Bay Area.  Mau gets the seal of approval from this Viet foodie!

I have to say, I have been depressingly disappointed with the quality of Vietnamese food in the South Bay (especially San Jose) and it took a hipster-ish Vietnamese restaurant in the Mission to restore my faith in the cuisine of my motherland in NorCal. 

What I love about Mau is the freshness of its ingredients and how it doesn't tone down or back down from the strong South East Asian flavors of fish sauce or fermented shrimp paste. 

LOVE the modern, fun, and pop punk-ish atmosphere.  It's rare to find a Viet place with a decent wine last and killer cocktail menu.

Mau has a mix of Southern & Northern Vietnamese dishes, some of which I've never even tried before like the Northern Bun Cha Hanoi which has now become one of my favorite dishes.  Here, the noodles are served separately from the meatballs and fish sauce.  It was a revelation in flavor to eat.  

Other dishes to order:

Ch giò - Vietnamese fried imperial rolls.  These should NOT be confused with the spring rolls in which the rice paper is not fried.  You get three to an order.  The imperial rolls are cut up into smaller pieces.  The traditional way to eat these is to wrap them up in the lettuce provided and pile on the fresh herbs and noodles - almost like you're making a lettuce wrap.  Not a lot of places serve it this way. Love it!

Frog Legs - found them to be a bit on the dry side, but still not bad.  They are deep fried. The jalapeño dip served with it really helped brighten it up. 

Hu Tieu - BEST I have ever tasted!  The garlic-infused chicken broth was AMAZING and tasted so clean and fresh.  Perfect for a cold winter day. 

Bun Bo Hue - probably the only miss that I've tried so far.  Something about it just tasted off.  

The Pork Chop rice plate - probably the juiciest pork chop I've ever had at a Vietnamese piece.  Must get!

I wanted to try the Hue Rolls and Cream Puffs, but they ran out.  Will definitely be back to try it and all the other dishes.
author: Hieu H.

description:
Came on a Tuesday night and the restaurant was pretty much full. I ordered the hu tieu kho which comes with xa-xiu pork, minced pork, chicken, gulf prawn and it's a noodles without broth dish. Ironically, it does come with broth, but it's on the side and is more of a palette cleanser. The soy-tomato sauce with the dried rice noodle was sorta sweet and delicious. I really liked that this dish had a variety of meats to try, but pork was my favorite meat so I'll just go with that next time.

I also ordered a crispy-fried cha gio roll on the side and it was pretty good. Loved that they have water jugs for each table.
author: Edward W.

description:
3.5 stars rounding up to 4.  

Good food and portions.  A little bit on the pricier side for what I'm used to for Vietnamese food, but that's to be expected in San Francisco.  This place has also got a trendier atmosphere to it.  I got the lemongrass pork noodle (bun thit nuong).  It was tasty and filling.  Definitely had enough leftovers to take home and eat later.  I just wish that I got more fish sauce.  It would've also been nice if the menu had a noodle without broth that also included egg rolls in it.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Stumbling upon this Vietnamese restaurants one day has been one of those rare finds! Since my first run in, I've been to this place a few more; huge win for me in the Mission area. 

When you walk in, you're pleasantly surprise as it's not your typical Vietnamese "mom and pop" joint. Nice ornate chandeliers, lots of wood work, exposed kitchens; the makings of a fun hip place! The staff was super nice and helpful; wait wasn't too long in all accounts. The tables were strategically places so you didn't necessarily feel like you were sitting on top of your neighbors. 

When you visit, be sure to get the Mau drink for $9: ginger infused soju, ginger beer and lemon. It's a very summery-type cocktail, not strong, easy to the tongue. I love the ginger tone you get with this drink. For our appetizer, I ordered the spring rolls for $8. This is THE BEST spring rolls I've had. Ever. Let's start with the fact that the spring rolls are at least double the size than other restaurants. So big, they cut them in 3 pieces. With two whole rolls, you get 6 mini rolls, easily able to be shared amongst a small party. In it was poached shrimp and pork, vermicelli noodles, mint and served with a peanut sauce. I LOVE the ratio of filler and protein. Such a filling app. HIGHLY RECOMMEND that!

For the few times I've visited, I've gotten two types of dinners worth discussing. First, the Pho Bo for $10.50. I feel like you can't go to a Vietnamese joint and not get pho. In my pho, they had rare eye of round, brisket, rice noodles and other veggies in a broth. I LOVED the broth; so rich and full of body. Sometimes I get pho somewhere and the ratio of bean sprouts and noodles are off. Not here. Lots of noodles to fill you up; in fact the bowl was big as it is and filled to the top with things. LOVED IT. Another dish I would highly recommend is Is the Pork Shoulder Rice Plate for $11.50. Grilled thin pork, lemongress, shallots, garlic and served with picked veggies, rice and fish sauce. I'm just in love with this dish. They give you so much food! I had another meal with my leftovers. Pork was perfectly grilled and the fish sauce really enhance the flavor. 

Overall, such a major win for Mission. This place is on point, the staff, the food the ambience. I REALLY like the fact that for an upscale nice joint, you aren't going to pay an arm and a leg for. If you're on Valencia, walk your happy butt to this joint and check it out. You will NOT be disappointed!
author: Rockne H.

description:
Service was so bad I had to get up and leave. In my whole life I never had to do that. The servers and runners looked like they hated their jobs. Honestly the most professional and friendly staff there was the busser. It's sad to see the wage disparity between really good hard working people vs the millennial, whiter servers. We were seated quickly but not greeted or even offered water for a long time. 

When I finally received my order, the runner pushed things aside on the table with the plate in his hands (who does that?!) with no expression or a word. The server got my order wrong and when I pointed it out he blamed it on the runner (so much for looking out for the team) and made no apology or explanation on if I'll get my correct item. So the wrong item just sat in front of me while I watched my friend eat. I was so pissed at the whole restaurant's lack of communication with themselves and to their guests. Fuck you for ruining my night. Hire people who know customer service. A place can be packed and busy and know how to handle its guests with communication and hospitality instead of avoidance, blame and incompetency.
author: Rachel T.

description:
I'm pretty picky with Vietnamese food, especially if the restaurant looks super clean, hipster and has a health rating score of 80 and up.

Yup, I do prefer the hole in the wall and grungy pho restaurants that make people turn around. Judge away. 

Mau was definitely a surprise for me. I went on a Tuesday night and our party of 2 was seated within a few minutes. From start to finish, our table was greeted with satisfactory customer service. Our glasses were never empty.

For appetizers, we ordered the Five Spice Quails and the Hue Rice Rolls. Just order them. Don't ask why. Don't ask about any other appetizers. Just do it. You'll thank me. The quails were well-seasoned and had an explosion of flavor. It's a delicacy, so it didn't have much meat, unfortunately. The rice rolls weren't far behind either and was tasteful with every single damn bite when dipped in the accompanied sauce. These appetizers were about $10-$12 bucks each.

For my main entree, I ordered the Hu Tieu. Each sip was greeted with so much and it was so smooth! I definitely loved my choice! But seriously, I had to pay for meatballs ($2.50?!) and it only came with one large jumbo shrimp. 

Overall, this place was on point and I'd definitely recommend this place. Yeh, it's a bit expensive for a Vietnamese place, but you shouldn't be surprised. It's located in the heart of the Mission and the decor was actually nice too, ha! 

Go go go.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Dear Mau.. you are EASILY one of the best spots in the city. A true gem. One of our all time faves. 
BUT.., please please please PLEASE bring BACK the Xíu Mi!!! It is the TRUTH!! 
An amazing dish. We're not sure how you could have cut it out from the menu, but we are SADLY missing it!!! 
Please bring it back. 
By the way.. it's STILL on the menu! 

Cheers guys! And gals
author: Sean S.

description:
Americanized vietnamese restaurant on valencia which I will most likely not return. I do prefer a more authentic mom n pop pho place which this place is not since none of the workers are asian and the prices are way too overpriced. I ordered their bun bo hue and while it does have good beef flavor, it was way too salty. Their bun bo hue is missing some of the traditional toppings, which includes pork shank slices and pork blood. They charge extra for getting tendon. They also skipped out on the cabbage shreds which are often served with bun bo hue and served only bean sprouts.

But if you do prefer a cleaner and fancier pho restaurant, then this is the place for you!
author: Hoyan L.

description:
Mau is a very hipster and beautiful Vietnamese restaurant. :)

If you're looking for a more clean, americanized, and lighter style of Vietnamese food, this is the place to be.

We tried their Bun Rieu, which has a more clear broth than usual and a lighter taste as well. It's   a noodle tomato based soup, with shrimp cakes. It's a different take on this noodle soup and I can't say I love it, but I did enjoy it! 

I tried the chicken clay pot, and it was good! It's similar to how my grandma makes it and it tastes pretty yummy. It's like a soy sauce braised chicken dish that comes with your choice of brown or white rice.

Their Hue Rolls are delicious and I think you should try this. They're yummy and delicious. Although I've tried a lot of different types of spring rolls, this is one that is special to Mau. Try it out and you'll be a very happy camper.
author: Melanie T.

description: Nothing beats a grade c hole in the wall Vietnamese  spot.  Mau....not bad, not great. I only tried the pho and shrimp salad.  It was probably more fresh compared to your typical Vietnamese place though.  I'll stick with my usual spots.
author: Mon T.

description: Mau is one of my go to's in the Mission. It's a great spot to catch up with friends of all different dietary needs! I have a gluten allergy and they offer several gluten free options. I've also had some really lovely servers here. The food is 4/5 stars but I think the service warrants a 5 star review!
author: Emily H.

description:
Had a friend visiting from out of town and she wanted good Asian food for the whole week she was here. Given that it's the bay area, shouldn't be too hard right? 

Except we were in the Mission on a Saturday night feeling disgruntled that our dinner spot of choice (FOB Kitchen, a pop up Filipino spot) was unexpectedly not going to be popping up for the night. Doubtful about the Asian choices in the Mission, we quickly turned to Yelp and came across Mau which we all loved. Thank goodness for Yelp!

We got here around 7 and there was no wait for a group of 5. We got seated immediately and started perusing the menu. Half the party wasn't too hungry, but we decided to each order an entree and take any leftovers home.

I ordered the five spice chicken rice plate and was really pleasantly surprised by how tasty the chicken was! Some of the breast pieces were a little bit dry, but both the white and dark meats were very well marinated and flavorful and went great with the rice. My only complaint, if I had to pick something, was that there wasn't enough rice. The meat-to-rice ratio was pretty high, but I didn't mind since I only ate half and took my leftovers home, so I just ended up eating the remaining chicken with leftover rice I had at home.

I didn't try my friends' orders but they all seemed to really enjoy them too. Two friends both ordered bun thit nuong (pork with noodles without broth) and it looked really good. I wouldn't mind coming back here to try that!

Service was good. Our server checked on us pretty often and we got our food soon after we ordered.

Parking was a bit of a struggle, but it's the Mission on a Saturday night so to be expected. Had to circle around for quite a bit until I finally found a metered parking on Mission St itself. 

Yes the prices were higher than typical Vietnamese fare, but it's the Mission so again to be expected. Paid around $16 for my meal, but the leftover chicken lasted me for another 1.5 lunches so ultimately I think it was a good value.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Look, we know it's not authentic and 10x cleaner than real Vietnamese shops, but hey - it's still good food!

I come to MAU all the time. You can nearly always expect a wait during dinnertime, but it's nice to be surrounded by an upbeat atmosphere.

No waiter or host seems to be Vietnamese, but they are super friendly despite the complaints about the wait they must deal w/ daily.

After sampling most dishes on their menu, I stick to the classics: get the pho bo w/ tendon, and one of their appetizers (pancakes & papaya salads are great). Rolls are meh.

If you are looking for an authentic Vietnamese meal in SF, then there are other options in the city. But if youre just looking for great tasting food and a good atmosphere, this place will do the job!
author: Jeremy C.

description: My family and I visited this place as we were craving Vietnamese food. We tried the hue roll which the a summer roll but instead of shrimp it's grilled pork. I thought this roll was decent but nothing spectacular about it. I of course then order the bun bo hue. Now if you have read my other review I love spicy food. This soup surprise me with how much flavor and spice is in this dish. I feel that it was the first time in a long time that I was chugging my water after eating this dish. I would come here again just to get that dish.
author: Jackie N.

description: Really good service ! My boyfriend and I loved the food. The food has this home made taste that make you feel great :)
author: Margarita T.

description:
Seems like the landlord and MAU came to an agreement and MAU will reopen. Glad to have my neighborhood Vietnamese restaurant back! 

https://sf.eater.com/2017/10/1/16393054/mau-reopen-closed-landlord-rent-agreement-saved
author: D. P.

description: Last Thursday a group four of us decided to eat at Mau. The restaurant was busy and we couldn't get a table right away and since the bar was open we decided to eat there. We were greeted and attended by our bartender. We didn't know much about the menu and thoroughly explained to us the best dishes and suggested a delicious wine and cocktails to pair  the food, to our surprise we had a great time with great service and out food come out fast. I would definitely come here again and would not mind sitting at the bar to enjoy dinner thank you to bartender for making our night those Hemingway cocktail and fog lifter were amazing!!!
author: Serafin K.

description:
While San Francisco has countless Vietnamese restaurants, Mau remains one of my go-to ones. 
It's modern and has really good Pho options, as well as other mains and yummy starters. Not to forget, good drinks!

My favorite part though might be the fact that it doesn't have that smell that a lot of authentic Vietnamese restaurants have. If you're looking for an authentic Vietnamese culture experience I wouldn't recommend Mau. 

My favorite starter is the Hue rolls!! They also have vegan and vegetarian options. 

It gets really packed so make sure you make a reservation!
author: Virgo M.

description: Food was really good. Highly recommend the bun bo hue chay if you like spicy, savory broth. Overall service could've been better. The kitchen bright out the wrong order for my boyfriend. Although they did end up correcting it, I feel like they should have comped that item for the added wait time and inconvenience.
author: Leanne H.

description:
Terrible, terrible pho. We had both beef and chicken pho and the broth was horrible. Very funky flavors. Noodles were mushy. Anyone who loves pho stay away. 

Claypot prawns were rubbery and dry, obviously not fresh.

I can't believe there was a wait to get a seat here, the food is a joke. Service was slow, had to ask for refills and drinks. I cannot recommend this business.
author: Daniel G.

description: i got the bun bo hue. Flavor wise, it gave me a sense of Vietnamese nostalgia. A sense of it had vietnamese roots. thats a good thing. All the ingredients were fresh and well presented. The bean sprouts had crunch. lettuce looked like it was plated.  however at the end of the day, this was bun bo hue that was safe for... how should i put this... safe for non-vietnamese. there was no pork blood jello, no bones, or tripe. it was bun bo hue without the scariness hahaha
author: Jason C.

description: Late review: This place was really good for a starving traveler! I had just landed after a 12 hour flight, and really needed food. The pho was decent. My friend got a fish claypot and it smelled amazing.
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place we busy and crowded on Sunday around 6:30pm.  They will not seat you until your full party was present.  We sat at one of the high tables near the front of the restaurant. 

Their menu was simple and had a lot of variety (and vegetarian dishes too).  We ordered Spring Rolls ($8), Tofu Pho ($9.50), and two Pho Bo ($10.50).  It took a long time for them to give us water so we were pretty thirsty considering it was a hot evening.  Other tables around us had the same issue with not getting water. 

The Spring Rolls came out first and they were just okay.  The peanut sauce was a little bit loose but still tasted what it should.  The Pho Bo was okay at best and it tasted Americanized (hard to describe).  The broth had flavor but not the same ones as other places that had pho.  The meat was at least good to me. 

I think if the service was better then I would have been more satisfied.  The food was still okay to me though.
author: Daniel H.

description: My favorite go to for my Vietnamese fix in the city. From the salads, to spring/crispy/steam rolls, to soup items, and clay pot items -- all delectable.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
I really enjoyed my three visits to Mau. It can get quite crowded and busy on weekends though, so you may want to avoid the wait if you have a large party. 

My go to, which I think Mau does well,  are the grilled beef vermicelli noodles. The overall flavoring is done well. The hue rolls are also a great choice for appetizers and pretty unique. 

Excited to try out the Hu Tieu next time!
author: Lucy G.

description:
Okay, ya'll. You hardly see any Asian staff here. I won't lie. I was pretty concerned the first time I went, but yo... idk where they got their recipe from but it's bommmbdiggity. 

Their broth is so, so, so good. 

Clay pots? Can't go wrong. 

Lately, I've been opting for some dry noodles. I hardly have time to drop by Nam Vang in east side San Jose these days for their hu tieu dry nooooodoh. But Mau's is pretty good if you need your fix. I prefer my dry noodles to be drenched in sauce. They're happy to give you an extra side of sauce if you ask for it. I've been asked by two other guests (one who made her way over to me from a table not near mine) what my dish is. Presentation is one hunnid. Hahaha. 

Boyfriend really enjoys their fried quail appetizer. His friends order their bok choy. 

Pretty sure if you're craving Vietnamese, don't bother going to the other Viet restaurants nearby (I'm sorry other places- step it up!) ... just visit Mau. You won't be sorry.
author: Andra C.

description:
Four star food, but a three star rating is generous, considering the extremely slow and inattentive service that's worthy of one or two stars at most. 

An hour before its 3pm lunch time closing, the restaurant was still packed. My boyfriend and I were still seated within 10 minutes, which was a good start. But after being seated with menus, we waited around 15-20 minutes without any water before a server came by, and even then, it was only because we flagged him down. After ordering, we still didn't receive any water until we reminded the server again, another 15 minutes later. 30 minutes without so much as a glass of water...kind of ridiculous.

The Hue Rolls we ordered as an appetizer came out fairly quickly and were super flavorful and fresh. Amazing starter that I'd definitely recommend. They were great with the chili sauce, which I had to swipe off an empty table since service was already nonexistent at this point, with no one coming by to check on the table.

My boyfriend ordered the Bun Thit Nuong as his entree, but they forgot to bring the sauce that it's supposed to come with. Again, we had to ask a server for it. It tasted great...after the unnecessary additional wait for the sauce. I had the Bun Bo Hue, which was noodles and beef in a spicy lemongrass chicken broth. I didn't think it was as spicy as I was expecting and wanting it to be, but I still really enjoyed it. 

After finishing our meal and asking the person that cleared our plates for the check, we waited for the check...and still no check. Once again, we had to ask for it again. Then another unnecessarily long wait before they picked the check back up with the card. 

The shitty service would've been kind of more acceptable if the restaurant was packed during our entire meal, but they were winding down and preparing for closing towards the middle and end of our meal...during which the service was still terrible. This seems to be somewhat of the norm, since other reviewers have mentioned that the service is a hit or miss.

Overall, great food with god awful service. If you don't like sit-down restaurants with bad service, you're probably better off ordering takeout.
author: Sara L.

description:
Yes- Mau is an upscale Vietnamese restaurant- it's clean and way too hipster for it's own good. But where in San Francisco can you get a bowl of pho for less than $9, nowadays?! The pho is good but I actually really enjoyed the Wonton Noodles- you get the best of both worlds: egg noodles and wontons in a soup. The Cha Gio (crispy-fried rolls) is always a crowd pleaser and if you're not on a budget, the Pork Chop plate is muy bueno. 
Since Mau is not your typical Vietnamese restaurant, there is a 4% San Francisco employer mandate fee and a 2 credit-card limit per table.
author: Grace L.

description:
Came here for the beef pho and it was delicious! Broth was very flavorful, beef tasted fresh, nothing to complain about! Overall, food came out relatively fast, service was nothing special and tables are super tight with one another, but the food was delicious! 

My friend and I saw someone eating a dry egg noodle dish, which looked amazing - will be back to try that one out!
author: Cynthia H.

description: Mau is a pretty standard Vietnamese restaurant that is attempting to cater to a westernized, yuppie taste palette. They advertise young coconuts in line with their tropical theme and boast a tropically themed interior.  I've tried several of their vermicelli bowls, beef phos and the bun bo hue (The spicy lemongrass pho). I find their food lacking in flavor or flair and as for the bun bo... it was the wateriest and worst balanced broth I've had. I get that they're trying to curb the flavor and spice, but that doesnt mean it should be bad... Its pretty disappointing because there is a good atmosphere, great location and a lot of potential here.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Good pho with just the right portion. Not sure why this place is only getting 3.5 stars, but the price+food+ambiance combo equates to 5 stars in my book. Fast service, clean kitchen and restroom and overall just good vietnamese food in the Mission area.
author: Vin A.

description:
I ordered bun noodle without soup and hue rolls. Hue rolls are great mix of grilled beef and fresh lettuce. Crispy garlic fries are on top.
Noodle is usual Vietnamese for me which I could eat close to my house but more beef in it. The beef was smoky and tasty.
A little pricy for Vietnamese? I can service with local Vietnamese places around San Jose area.
author: Nazuki Y.

description:
Came here around 8pm on a rainy Friday night and the wait for 2 was only ~10 minutes! This place is interesting because it's a trendy Vietnamese restaurant, which you normally don't find. But with the nicer, more modern ambience also comes slightly higher prices than a hole-in-the-wall place for pretty regular Vietnamese dishes. We got the grilled beef vermicelli and the pho bo - tasty, but nothing exceptional. 

Oh, their sparkling lemonade is a little salty! After the initial unexpected kick, it was actually quite good, to balance out the sourness.
author: Tiffany P.

description: This food is amazingggg!! Seriously the meat has great taste in the vermicelli and the fried chicken, oh mah gahhh, finger lickin' good. I crave this place. Sure it's a little more expensive, but for the quality of the food-- totally worth it. Only thing is they need to work on handling their ish. We waited almost an hour for our food when it wasn't even busy. I think they just forgot about us and we had to remind them.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I went here with a friend recently.  The pho was good, but some people may not like that it had celery in it.
author: Michael E.

description: Small dinner here with our visitors while at Delores Park. Very tough parking neighborhood. Walk around to see where to eat noodles. Looking at Yelp and found this place. Soup broth was a little too much pepper for me in Pho Bo beef noodle soup. Noise level a little high. Dinner seating best if you get there before 7pm.
author: Clifford W.

description: My friend lives in the area, and we went here for a quick bite the last two times I came to visit. In love with their bun cha Ha Noi. Not sure how I missed this one growing up in OC, but this was the first place I had it, and I love the meatballs and fatty pieces of pork. The noodles were a tiny bit overcooked, so they were too mushy for my taste, but overall, it was a great dish. We also got the Hue rolls both times, and I really enjoyed the lemongrass seasoning of the beef. I've had bites of the pho, bun rieu, bun thang, and got bun moc last time. Everything was pretty good, and didn't taste bland like how you would expect a hipster Viet place to taste. It's one now one of my SF staples.
author: Anh N.

description:
I'm normally a hole in the wall, pho for under $7 bucks or I'm out kinda gal but Mau enticed me in with their fun atmosphere and this BÚN RIÊU CUA - crab tomato noodle soup that I love and can be hard to find in the city. I was pleasantly surprised by the meal and have since eaten there several times. I always find the staff friendly and courteous, even on busy nights in the Mission. 

I'd give it more stars (but see line one; first 14 words); but that's just me. Try it for yourself!

Also, shout out to Mau for being so nice the other day when I stopped in to use the ladies and somehow managed to drop an entire bottle of unopened wine on the ground which promptly smashed into a bunch of wet pieces. It looked like a murder scene! Your staff was SO NICE about immediately cleaning it up and not scolding me for the accident. I tipped the guy who did the mopping and have been meaning to write this thank you for a while now. 

I'll be back soon!
author: T L.

description: I really love pho spots around town and for so many optional broths and being located in a nice part of Mission, we were really drawn to this place. After 4 times, I finally decided to leave my 2 cents. The service, although nice staff, is really slacking. The servers relay heavily on the server assistants for busing tables and refilling waters. Out of the 4 times, we only had one time where the server actually checked up on us after the food order was placed. Taking an order and leaving the rest up to the staff leaves much to be desired in a place we wanted to enjoy and come back to. Food is slightly above average but the last two times I really wanted to try the cream puffs (ordered both at beginning of meal to come after main course) and both times were told they were out. Coincidence? Maybe... Either way, not recommending unless someone wants take out.
author: Aric R.

description:
Fun ambiance, good music. R&B and pop hits. It's too loud for a first date, but third date or coming with a group of friends would be perfect. 

I ordered the grilled lemongrass pork and vermicelli bowl. It looks like pho is very popular here as well. The pork was in slices rather than bits of meat like what you would typically see in Vietnamese fare. The lettuce and cucumbers were very fresh. I wish there were more pickled carrots, they are my favorite!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I came here for lunch this afternoon to try out the Hue Rolls and the Hu Tieu Kho. The Hue Rolls were delicious with the peanut sauce. The rolls normally comes with a side of nuoc mam, but I asked for peanut sauce instead. I was not too impressed with the Hu Tieu Kho. The portion size of this item is rather large. I was unable to finish my meal. The noodles were stuck together and hard to separate. The broth on the side was too salty for my taste-I only had two spoons full. 

As for the service, it was mediocre. The restaurant wasn't busy at the time I arrived. I wasn't sure why it took so long for the waiter to get around to take down my order.
author: Cindy T.

description:
This place is truly cognizant of the Mission neighborhood, and while the ambiance of the restaurant is on point and has a lot of potential, I couldn't help but feel underwhelmed by the food.

We stopped by mid-day during Santa Con for a quick bite to eat with ample seating available, but took about 10 minutes before we were actually seated.  I was craving for something spicy, so I decided to go with the Bun Bo Hue, which had the spicy chicken broth.  While the portions included a good dose of pork sausage and beef shank, but man...the noodles were pretty subpar compared to what you would typically expect from a Vietnamese restaurant, not to mention there were hardly any noodles in my bowl to begin with.

Also, their dishes are typically $2-3 more than the average Vietnamese price points.  If you're looking for authentic pho from your typical mom and pop shop, this probably isn't the place for you.  Love the interior design and open space though.
author: Kevin C.

description: My friends and I had a great experience last week as we came here to celebrate my birthday. We sat at the bar and had a great time. The food was delicious (I had the Papaya Salad and the classic Beef Pho). I am not a big fan of Vietnamese cuisine but the food here is different from any other place I have been to. The uniqueness, freshness and amazing taste makes Mau a fantastic place to try something new. And by the way, the service is as good as the food. The bartender Marin was friendly and very accommodating from the beginning of our dinner till the very last minute we spent at the restaurant. We had a great time, next week is my friend's birthday and we already have plans to come back.
author: Shoshana M.

description:
TLDR - nice ambiance, okay Vietnamese/Asian fusion food at higher prices than actual authentic Vietnamese. basically "fancy" Vietnamese

For a pretty late lunch (like 1:30pm) on a weekday, this place was surprisingly busy. No wait for bar seating but a table would've required some wait. The atmosphere of the place was nice and more on the trendy side of Asian restaurants. Food, on the other hand, was just okay, although I didn't try much so I'd still be willing to come back and try more of their food. Prices are definitely on the more expensive side though, especially for the portion sizes.

I stopped by for a quick, light lunch and got the LOTUS ROOT SALAD ($11.50), which was decent but not particularly memorable. Light and healthy tasting (minus the fattiness of the pig ear and the crunchy rice chips) and a pretty crunchy salad overall with the lotus root, carrots, celery and bell peppers. I was expecting the lotus root to be crunchier but they reminded me of limp celery. Definitely pricey for a pretty small salad.

If you're looking for real Vietnamese food, I don't think you'll find it here. But for a trendy Vietnamese place, Mau isn't bad, especially given there aren't as many fancy Vietnamese spots in general.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Extremely disappointed. 

This must be an anomaly because the other reviews are great.  

Our waiter could have cared less about our meal.  Tall, white blonde guy. 

We really disliked an appetizer and kindly asked to have it replaced. He stated his manager would not credit the app to our bill and he would not ask her.  We just smiled and nodded because we didn't want to get upset. We ordered an additional app and had the other one sent away. 

Our dinner was poor quality for the price and he never came back to our table to check on our meal or get our ticket. We had to find someone else to help us with the rest of our needs.  


$63 and this is the awful experience we had.
author: Alex P.

description:
Unimpressed. Disappointed. Waiter brought water jug but no water glasses.  Delivered the beer but didn't come back for a long, long, long time to take the food order.   My pho came with no soup spoon, no side dish of sprouts and accompanying add-ins.  Had to constantly find a waiter, even though there were a lot of them, to practically beg for stuff that normally would be a no-brainer.   Then we had another long wait for it to be delivered.  Kind of a pattern?

The pho broth was bland, the shredded chicken was super tough, very stringy and dry.  Of course, it was overpriced, naturally.  The minimal dipping sauce that comes with the deep fried rolls had no taste, did they leave out the fish sauce??   By the time I got the bean sprouts for the pho the broth was so cooled down that the sprouts never got soft.  

What a mess!!!  Forget about ever going back!!!  

There are Vietnamese restaurants in DALY CITY and SF Tenderloin that charge half as much and completely put this place to shame!  The decor/ambience seems more of a concern at MAU than the service and quality of food.
author: Rona M.

description: Great service tonight. Great music! Icing on the cake. Food was delicious as always. Keep up with the great job!
author: Beatriz M.

description: Nice Location, place is nice and clean. Food is excellent, the presentation was good but, a bit pricey. The customer service was good as well. This place I recommend is a great place for lunch and dinner for two people or maybe a double date. I wouldn't recommend a big party. But over all I give this place a
author: Braddah Rick M.

description: get their young coconut! delicious! we also had the bun rieu which was tasty and not too oily and fatty like other places that are more traditional. my girlfriend got the vermicelli pork rolls and those were tasty but had a bit too much cilantro for our liking so we just picked it out. service was good - they let us enjoy our time there and checked in every so often
author: Calvin C.

description: We had the Pho Bo and the Vegetarian Ph. The atmosphere was pretty nice - felt new american and so did the food. It was very average. Wasn't bad but not wow.
author: Nancy A.

description:
tl;dr: great food, good location & atmosphere; quick for lunch.

Ate here today and left very happy.  Had the Bun Thit Nuong, and couldn't have been happier.  Great portion size, excellent taste, and served plenty quick (for lunch).  Their Thai Tea was good (not exceptional), but the food more than made up for it.

Go here.  Eat tons.  Be happy.
author: Cj L.

description:
Slow, but friendly service - come early and put your name down because this hot spot gets crazy at peak times for dinner.

------------MUST ORDER ITEMS------------
* Hue rolls - Tasty app, 6 pieces, great to share.
* Lotus root salad - Refreshing, umami-full.
* 5-Spice Chicken (make sure you add the CHILI PASTE - not the same as the sriracha sauce)

------------OTHER FAVORITES------------
* Hu Tieu Ko Bho - Dry vermicelli noodles with combo seafood/meat. Super tasty.
* Bun Bo Hue - Soul-satisfying soup. 
* Clayfish Claypot - Sweet, savory, a little small but delicious.

------------FULL FOOD REVIEW------------
BUN BO HUE ($11) - 4 STARS
Thick rice noodles in a savory, peppery, clear broth and topped with lots of meat. I like to ask for pho noodles personally - they also have this at their sister restaurant, Tin. 

BUN RIEU ($11) - 5 STARS
Contrary to popular opinion, I'm a fan of the bun rieu, which is more tomatoey and has more umami.

LOTUS ROOT SALAD ($11.50) - 5 STARS
A cold, savory dish with no lettuce. WOW - order it. 

BANANA BLOSSOM SALAD ($11.50) - 3 STARS
Just wasn't a fan personally. Stick with the lotus root.  

FIVE SPICE CHICKEN ($11) - 5 STARS
Add their special chili paste and tell me this is not delicious. The lemongrass chicken is good but not as good, and you can't find this at Tin. 

PHO BO ($9.50) - 3.5 STARS
it's good but not one of my regular items. 

HU TIEU KO BHO ($11.50) - 4 STARS
I order this because it resembles the #25 dry crack noodles from Ha Nam Ninh. The sauce here isn't as good but overall it's still delicious and fresher tasting than HNN. You can order it in soup too. 

HUE ROLLS - 5 STARS
Lemongrass pork summer rolls. Delicious - must order. 

SPRING ROLLS ($8) - 4 STARS
Good - normal good.

CATFISH CLAYPOT ($11.50) - 4 STARS:
I love salt, but the caramel sauce was reduced and overly salty compared to the ratio of fish in the bowl. Like it but I still prefer the five spice chicken.
author: Jess C.

description:
Awesome Vietnamese food with a modern twist! 
I ordered the bun thit nuong and my friend the bun cha (similar style of vermicelli noodles, but the former is southern whereas the latter is northern). Both were very tasty and very fresh. 100% recommend.
author: Minh Tri P.

description: I promise the foods are delicious and the palace is comfortable for hang out w/ friends and eat. But the only problem is the server, you may need to call 2 times to get your water even they aren't busy. BTW they need to charge you sfmandate fee, lmfao.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Wasn't expecting the normal type of Vietnamese cuisine by just looking at this place but after trying it they've won me over! It's a little more expensive than regular pho restaurants but let's be real you're paying for an experience, plus it's way cleaner than a regular pho restaurant and tastes just as good. I really enjoyed the pho bo, the bun bo hue and garlic noodles (I love my noodles!). The only thing I hate about this place is that parking sucks!
author: Jenny E.

description: They are back and better than ever.  Their vegetarian options are the bomb.  My crew always orders the Bun Tofu and it's excellent- flavorful and delicious.  So happy they made a comeback.  They had an excellent Sancerre on the menu before and no longer carry it, and their service can be slow, but the ambiance is good, the staff is friendly enough, and the Bun Tofu and veg spring rolls are awesome.
author: Wendy S.

description:
We trekked a long way to come here for a Sunday dinner and while the wait for our food felt like forever, the food did not disappoint!

For a Vietnamese restaurant, I loved how extensive their menu was, with various types of broth for their phos, noodles without broth, rice plates, salads, and so many appetizers. I feel like there's definitely something for everyone, vegans and vegetarians too! 

We ordered:

Pho Ga ($10.50): Rare niman ranch eye-of-round, brisket, rice noodles, beef broth.
Bun Tofu ($10.50): Grilled lemongrass tofu, shiitake mushrooms, bean sprouts, peanuts, soy nuoc cham.

Added extra noodles to both and extra meat on the Pho Ga too, I love me some noodles! The food was seriously SOOO good and the extra portions were really generous. I loved their spice combinations and how flavorful everything was, without feeling too heavy/oily. Also the noodles were so soft and chewy!

While delicious our food took sooo long to come out I don't know if I was just too hungry but it was hard watching everyone's food come out around us haha. Also, it was SOOOO hot inside that night where's the AC at?!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Open once again, Mau is your go to spot for tasty Vietnamese on Valencia. Best way to avoid a wait is to show up right at opening (5:30pm as of this writing), otherwise even weeknight waits can start dragging out into the evening. Bun Bo Hue is a spicy fave, with beef, vermicelli, and Vietnamese sausage.
author: AustinSLin ..

description:
I think the pho here is pretty terrible.  Like it's actually one of the worse pho I've had ever.  One would think that's a hyperbole or that I'm saying it's more terrible than I thought it was to counter the high reviews but I'm honestly not.  I really thought it was one of the worse pho I've had. Like I thought it was fusion pho because it really shouldn't be counted as pho.  But fusion or traditional, I thought it was horrible.

However, the various bird appetizers were delicious!

Service was okay.  I'm between a 2 or 3 but the pho was really was not good and I've tasted various ones from my friends' bowls.
author: Phillip N.

description:
If this is the modern Vietnamese dining experience, I love it. I was surprised at how hip and lively the atmosphere is, since I'm used to the dingier Vietnamese restaurants where the waiters hardly speak English. I had my doubts about Mau, but the food and service proved me wrong.

I came here with a group of friends, and we were seated at a table with barstool chairs. Remember to bring sunglasses if the sun is setting because it could be right in your eyes! Anyways, I love the décor here, and there's even a bar area if you just want a drink or if you're waiting for someone. How cool!

As for food, I ordered the Pho Bo. I think this place is overpriced for Vietnamese food, but then again you're paying for the classier experience. The bowl of pho was just the right amount of food. I actually finished for once. Hooray! Overall I enjoyed my experience here. I'm not too crazy about coming here again because of the price, but I would certainly recommend it to others.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
3.5 stars. My friend and I came here last night after watching the debates. Service was good and attentive. I am trying to eat less meat and while they had some vegetarian options, there weren't too many (which you can't really fault them for since they're not a vegetarian restaurant nor do they purport themselves to be). Between the pho tofu and tofu lemongrass vermicelli, I chose the latter cause it was too damn hot last night for soup.  I must say that the tofu was pretty tasty but the overall dish was too salty. I wish there was a bit more of a balance. 

This is definitely not your typical Vietnamese restaurant and I'm not sure if any Vietnamese people even work here so don't expect it to be authentic. If you come in with an open mind for some sort of Western/Vietnamese fusion, I think you'll find it pretty tasty. The atmosphere of the restaurant is nice and comfortable as well, making it a good place to come for a casual date.
author: Joan S.

description:
Took them a while to notice us at the door. I guess They were a little busy

This place is quite pricy for a vietnamese restaurant. When you see workers, its mostly american. Maybe this place cater to non-asian. But they actually have decent amount of some vietnamese traditional dishes. 

Got the bun rieu. It costs $11. They don't give you much meat and noodle. My mom got the spring roll which is $8. I was pleasantly surprise that the foods were good. The foods came out at a reasonable amount of time

Very modern place for a vietnamese place with the big lights in the ceiling and has a bar

They music have use pandora or something for their background music since some of the music i heard is from the 90s and early 2000s
author: Julie N.

description: You have to start with the Hue rolls they're always fantastic. And the pho are always spot-on, everything is percent that nicely and very fresh! Caleb what our server and is absolutely fantastic and full of personality. And provided great service with wonderful recommendations.
author: Brad S.

description:
I wanted to love this place, but I just couldn't :( . 

As much as it pains me to write about a place that I've been so eager to try out for so long, it has to be done, so I will respectfully do so. 

Firstly, I've seen this place through Yelp and It was a place that I knew I needed to try, mostly because I love Vietnamese food and fusion cuisine. At first glance, the interior was very appealing, it is definitely a great place for a casual dinner date, especially with the lightly dimmed room. The servers were very attentive, which was a plus. So now for the food: 

1. "Bun Bo Hue": First off, there are only a handful of places that can master this noodle soup dish, and this place was not one of them. When we received the dish, the temperature was lukewarm, which made it very unappealing. The meat in bun bo hue is suppose to be a variety of pork, fatty beefs, and porks blood, however this place had its own version. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but it just lacked the flavor that Bun Bo Hue is suppose to give. I was pretty disappointed, sad to say. 

2. Garlic Noodles : Small portion for $7, lacked in flavor. 

3. Bun Thit Nuong w/ Cha Gio ( BBQ Lemongrass pork w/ egg rolls & Vermicelli : I must say, the egg rolls were pretty darn good and also great portion size! I don't know if its just me, but the round - cut carrots really threw me off, I think Mau should consider shredding the carrots instead. 

The one item we wanted to try was the " Hue Roll", however they ran out for the night. It seems that this is the most popular appetizer, its a shame we missed out!!

Overall, I really wanted to love this place, however I think I am going to stick to traditional Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Lydia L.

description:
This is a Vietnamese restaurant? 

First, I notice that none of the staff are Asian. Does this mean there are no Vietnamese cooks? I don't know, but the food sure as hell didn't reflect that idea.

The service is great. The server was super nice and attentive. The support staff were always on point and courteous.
