But oh god.. the food. We started with the Hue Rolls, which were pretty good even with the tofu substitute. But they fell apart so easily, we had a salad and rice paper wrapper at the end. Then I had the Bun Bo Hue:
Beef shank, rare niman ranch eye-of-round, pork sausage, spicy lemongrass chicken broth
This sounds great on paper, but WTF. EVERY piece of meat was overcooked. I was chewing on rubber the entire time. The broth was OK, but I just couldn't get over how low quality the meat was.
$11.50 for this is not bad, but the food was just not on point.
author: Alex K.

description: Come here for clean pho broths that are good and safe. My favorite is the bun rieu (crab and tomato). I just wish they would add more herbs (both in terms of quantity and variety)-- their soups could use just a bit more of the herbaceous oomph that you would get at a more authentic spot.
author: Jean L.

description: Food was delicious and service was pretty darn great. I really appreciate that the bar has a wheelchair accessible section. We will be back!
author: Amy Grace C.

description:
Trendy Vietnamese place in the Mission. They are really popular even on weekdays. Note that they will not seat you unless your entire party is present but there is a nice bar to wait at. Service was friendly but pretty inattentive since they were so busy. It took us trying to flag down the waiter several times to order our food.

I got the pho bo ($10). The broth was rich and flavorful and the rice noodles were the perfect texture. I thought the slices of beef were just okay. I prefer the ones served at the hole in the wall Vietnamese places. Not the best pho I've ever had but definitely satisfied my craving for it!
author: Linda X.

description: My wife is from Saigon and wants it authentic. I'm a vegetarian and enjoy the movement towards a more modern, fresh take on Vietnamese food. Mau does both and is our come-together place that she approves us as the best authentic food in SF and I love for the freshness and that it's not in a dirty hole in the wall.
author: Daniel E.

description:
Mau is a solid 3 stars for convenience (on Valencia street), and Vietnamese food (which there isn't much of around there).

It's tasty, in a somewhat Americanized hipster manner, and does the trick if you're in the mood for pho or other Vietnamese plates.

It is decent and it doesn't seem to be striving to be any more than that. I'd come back if in the sudden mood for Vietnamese nearby.
author: Victoria C.

description:
BEST pho I've ever had, anywhere! The bo kho, hue rolls, turmeric catfish, and tofu pho are out of this world. 

Happiest, smiliest, friendliest wait staff you'll ever encounter, even when the place is insanely busy. I've been coming here for four years and I don't know why I've never written a review. Probably because I've never had bad service.

You're bound to have a great meal whatever you order, and paired with one of their inventive cocktails (*cough* Hemingway *cough*) or a whole young coconut, you'll leave craving Mau for weeks afterward. GO!!!!
author: Ysabel L.

description: I've been here a handful of times over the years and really like it for the vibe and food. But they changed the menu when they reopened and took off my favorite item which was an app of beef meatballs in a spicy broth served with soft baguette. Please, please Mau bring this back!
author: Caitlin G.

description:
FOOD: yes. Everything is fresh, popping with flavor. 
Spring roll wrap was tender without being too sticky or chewy. Flavors were well balanced (mint, cucumber, and all else). Dipping sauce was exceptionally delicious, perfectly balancing savory and sweet.

Beef bun xue bowl we ordered was the favorite. I don't know where they source their noodles and fish sauce, but I could live on those two alone!

SERVICE: Courteous and welcoming.

AMBIANCE: Definitely a hip place to be seen slurping noodles in the window. Popular for drinks/small plates at night as it is for date night dinner. I've been comfortable here in spandex and business wear!
author: Helen W.

description:
We got to town late because I miss took an on-ram and had to pay an extra bridge fee.  Well, I went through two of the three main bridges to San Francisco at night at least.  Wife was complaining about the long drive.

By the time that we are in the room, it was about 9:15 pm.  The wife told me that she would like a hot bowl of noodle soup delivered since it was a cold night and she was too tired to go out.

Of course being the Yelper that I am, I logged on to Yelp and found out where is a good place to order foods from--lots of choices in the city of San Francisco.  One place told me that the cooks went home already although the place was still open.

Ok, next closest place with good foods at reasonable prices...Mau....

Called them and ordered a pho and a five spices chicken rice dish.  I thought they delivered, but it is not that far, and I simply want to save the delivery fee and tips.

When I left the hotel, it was not rainy.  About two to three blocks away, it started to rain--not heavy droplets, but at times, it was a dense mist.  The walk was about 25 minutes one way.  I got there at about 9:50 pm, and the foods were ready.  The prices were very reasonable by San Francisco standards, but the City charged a two percents surcharge, so the F&B workers could have health insurance. Whatever....

I was wet when I got back to the hotel.  The wife wants to me to join her in dining, but I needed to get a hot shower and get out of my wet clothes.  I told her to eat first since the soup was still warm.  She said the pho was good.  

I started to eat my chicken.  It was burned, and hard.  It was flavorful, but I do not like hard meat.  It got a two star, but because what my wife said about her pho.  The combined score for our meals is a three star.  Will not be back in SF for a while, so it is what it is.
author: Ray L.

description: Worst service ever. We tried to order takeout and weren't able to. First - no one picked up the phone. Then we tried to order via Eat24. The restaurant was offline. Finally we just went to the restaurant to order in person. We waited for nearly 5 minutes before one of the servers sat the couple standing in front of us and then he told us to go to the counter to order takeout. As we waited at the counter, several other customers were waiting to either place their order or receive their order. However, no one acknowledged any of us. For over 5 minutes. The entire staff was in or near the kitchen moving takeout boxes and tickets around - apparently too busy to help any of us. I would have been fine if someone apologized and asked us to wait and thanked us for being patient. But nothing. Not even acknowledgement of our presence. We tried to get their attention but they just kept on doing their rude ignoring thing. We finally gave up and went elsewhere with our money and our appetite. I don't think they even noticed. Probably didn't even care. Terrible experience.
author: Pei L.

description:
One of my favorite Vietnamese spots in SF. This is coming from a Vietnamese-born and San Jose-raised eater. Also, says a lot considering there aren't many great Vietnamese spots in the city. 

Even though it's supposed to be fusion, the dishes are authentically Vietnamese and include ingredients that you wouldn't find in Americanized Vietnamese food. I've enjoyed most of the items on the menu. Haven't the desserts. Table service can be a bit slow.

Delivery review: the salad portions were much smaller with delivery, but the food was still delicious.
author: Ai N.

description: I simply love Mau. So happy they reopened. The Hue rolls and cat fish vermicelli noodles are my go-out. Their garlic noodles and Vietnam's crepes are excellent. If you don't feel like waiting, just order to go.
author: Isabelle G.

description:
The Mission doesn't have too many Vietnamese options and we opted for the more modern, more Americanized (and more pricey) one. It goes along with a theme on Valencia, with Tacolicious and Hawker Fare within a block.

OVERALL: No one was super impressed with their pho. The flavor was fine but not very authentic. My noodles were bland while the meat was better.

THE WAIT: None for three of us on a Sunday night around 7pm.

THE SERVICE: Fine, no complaints.

THE COST: $16.00 total for my noodles with Imperial Rolls on top.

MUST-HAVES: Imperial Rolls! Great added on top of my noodles.

THE FOOD: Reviewed below, and see my photos for additional details.

* Bun Thit Nuong (lemongrass pork, vermicelli noodles without broth. $11) - 3.5 stars
The Imperial Rolls were the best part: very crunchy & packed with flavor. The meat had good flavor but the pieces were quite dry; there was plenty of it though. The noodles were very bland; I eventually poured in all the sauce it came with, but that didn't help very much.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Yum! Mau is one of our favorite casual spots in SF. Love their soups and bun bowls. Can't wait for our next visit!
author: Kira P.

description:
Mau? Meh.

The food was good but average. 

They could've earned 4 stars but the service was just horrible.

It took them about 15 min to tell us that the they'd run out of the sake we'd ordered. In the meanwhile, we'd finished our lackluster appetizer (the spring rolls). 

Everything came out sloooooowwwwly. Very. Slowly. And they weren't even busy.

It was so bad that we left exact change...no tip. Maybe the second time I'd ever done it in my life. It'd have added insult to injury. No way we'd thank them for the bad service!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed Mau yet, since I'm here every other week. Dinner time always seems to be crowded, no matter what day of the week, but service is friendly and food is always consistently good!

Mau is an upscale Vietnamese-fusion restaurant, so don't come here with expectations of authentic hole-in-the-wall Viet food that tastes like your mom's homecooked pho or bun bo hue. That said, I'm Vietnamese and I still think most of the dishes that I've had here is really good, and the ingredients are always very fresh.

FOOD
* My go-to non-soup dish is always the 5-spice chicken. Super flavorful and moist.
* Hue rolls - one of my new favorites! Very fresh and the lemongrass pork and shiso are sooo tasty together.
* Pho - always a solid choice here
* Bun Bo Hue - also great, but I enjoy Tin's better. Although it's missing more traditional ingredients, I still find it very satisfying.
* Bo Kho - also another favorite, if I'm in the mood for something hearty and hot.
* Lemongrass pork bun - Refreshing and flavorful.

The Mau sauce (the lemongrass chili sauce) makes everything taste sooo much better, so make sure to request it!
author: Vivian H.

description: Mau is a treasure of a restaurant. They are home to the BEST VEGGIE TOFU PHO I've ever tasted in my life. Their broth is delicious, the veggies are delectable, and the tofu is amazingly executed. Go support this restaurant, you are going to wish you would have tried this slice of heaven sooner. You're socks will be blown off!
author: Simply C.

description:
Decent casual vietnamese food that is open late night and satifies eating without breaking the bank post drinking in the Mission.  The alcohol menu is pretty limited, but not bad overall.

Food: Got all your favorites and a few twists on some classics.  Overall, decent ingredients, large portion sizes and well priced.

Service: Minimal but quick.  The second you walk in they are already trying to configure where you will sit.  They take order, deliver food and you don't see them again until you request them, in which case they are hurry over quickly.

Price: For the area, food quality and quantity, right where I would expect it to be.

Decor: Minimalistic, bright, lots of tables but doesn't feel OVERLY crowded.  I imagine it could, but that wasn't my reaction.

Special Notables: Can't say there is anything.
author: Reena B.

description:
Great authentic Vietnamese flavors in a modern clean setting.

We have been here 4 times in the last year or so. Their bun rieu is excellent. Price is reasonable. The Hue Roll is pretty interesting as well and don't see that in the menu in other Vietnamese restaurant. 

Service is efficient and with a smile. We would return whenever we crave delicious bun rieu!
author: Tracy L.

description:
Aight, here's the run down.

When I visit a new city, I try to eat Vietnamese food atleast once during the trip. Mau is located in a semi-busy area filled with businesses, art, and other restaurants. I dig the vibe of this area a lot. I felt bad for my friends, because they had to wait until we arrived, since they wouldn't seat them until the entire party was present. Understandable, but for a paying customer, it can get pretty frustrating. 

So with the food, I ordered the Bun Bo Hue, aka the BBH aka, when-you-telling-your-friends-you-getting-the-BBH-and-they-think-you're-ordering-a-BigBootyHoe. It was aiiiggghhttttt. Portion fit the prices of SF, which I alteast was hoping going to a place like this. It wasn't as flavorful and hearty as I was hoping, but still not too bad nonetheless. My friends got the Bun Thit Nuong and the chicken clay pot, and they seemed to be pleased with it. 

TL;DR: This would probably be a good place to bring friends who's never had Vietnamese food before.
author: Quang H.

description:
Walked in, with a warm welcome, starters were amazingly delicious. Our waiter started off very professional and seemed as if he knew what he was doing. Admittedly, we did ask a lot of questions about the menu, but mainly because we like to know what we are ordering because we both are pretty particular. He began to become uncomfortable with the inquiries, so we ordered our entrees. Beef pho and Tamarind Prawns; his knowledge about the dish seemed to be lacking since he failed to mention that the prawns, although shell-on, were unable to be peeled since the shells ripped the shrimp meat to pieces from being stuck together. It was unpleasant, messy and just not something I was ready for so I asked the waiter about it and he just stood there saying how he warned me the shells were still on the shrimp.. that wasn't my concern.. the shell should come off the shrimp SO I CAN EAT IT

My partners pho was good, a bit of a rich broth for pho if you ask me, but delicious nonetheless. The sparkling lemonade was just mineral water with sugar and chunks of meyer lemon in it it seems. The point is, the food was pretty great, the flavor of the tamarind and shrimp was phenomenal, I just don't enjoy eating shrimp shells and I was under the impression I'd be able to peel the shrimp easily. The waiters response was dry and ignorant. When the manager arrived, she was sweet and she was kind enough to remove the item from my bill, so we paid and left. I would return, I just don't know how I'd react if I saw that waiter at my table again, nor would I ever recommend this particular shrimp dish to anyone.

Papaya Salad - Amazing, fresh, not spicy like a typical order would be. The shrimp was sliced thin so it wasn't overwhelming. Comes with large puffed shrimp chips.

Mussels - creamy and good. arrived a bit tepid, but the large, crusty bread piece that soaked up the salty broth made up for it.

Beef Pho - dense, meaty broth. the veggies added were sliced thin how I like them which is perfect for a hot thin broth. The tendon was perfectly tender and the tripe was so thin it melted in your mouth.

Shrimp Tamarind - don't get it. the tamarind sauce is spicy, salty and sweet just like a classic tamarind sauce, but the sauce makes the shells stick to the shrimp in an unpleasant way. you cannot peel any of them without having you hands covered in sticky sauce and missing out on chunks of shrimp because it cant come off the shell.

Fresh limeade - REFRESHING and so good, would love to have gallons of this

Sparkling Lemonade - When i took my first sip, i drink up a bunch of sugar syrup and lemon chunks and then the rest tasted like mineral water.

Overall -- hope to try the restaurant again, but not for lunch.
author: Nate A.

description:
Pretty good and authentic tasting Vietnamese food! We got the pho and bird's nest. The aesthetics and service are definitely more "westernized" but I definitely would consider the food be at the level of traditional Vietnamese fare. 

The only bones I have to pick with this place are the cleanliness and the environment. The bar tables felt sticky and really grimey. The air was thick with grease and fish sauce fumes. Of course this is not an uncommon problem when it comes to many Asian eateries but I pick on them every time. Environment is always included in my threshold for giving a place 4 stars.
author: Alice W.

description:
I ordered Caramelized Catfish In Claypot (Cá Kho T) on a whim and now I'm addicted to it -
 kinda like that one time I ordered the Miso-Marinated Black Cod at Nobu.  Still can't get enough of it!
author: Matt D.

description: It was  the first time me and my boyfriend had Vietnamese food and we both were excited and totally satisfied with the flavors ,the size of the dishes ,the price and the service.We definitely recommend it.I had the Pho Bo and couldn't manage to eat it all but it was tasty .
author: Ani D.

description:
Was happily surprised to stumble into this place. Never been to a hipster Vietnamese spot in the mission before. The decor and diversity of staff threw me off at first but I was quickly transitioned to amazement by how much servers really knew their menu and how seriously committed the restaurant is about using quality and fresh ingredients. 

I had the Bun Rieu. It was not my first choice (Bun Bo Kho) on the menu which coincidentally was not available. A bit bummed about that, therefore one less star. When I got my bowl of Bun Rieu it appeared a little less tomatoey and bland than I expected but the taste was fantastic! Flavorful soup and the crab meatballs were truly delicious. 

I think this is a great place to go to be introduced to Vietnamese food for sure. Those with a more adventurous and experienced palate might not be won over completely but the flavors here are pretty on point. Great job!
author: Bettie L.

description: Nice Vietnamese place! Had a bowl of Bun Bo Hue, which is just a variant of Pho. The broth was flavorful, on the spicy side (which I happen to like). The side veggies looked standard, but I was surprised to find lettuce, which doesn't really add any taste, rather than basil. Oh well. I also had a "Hemingway" cocktail, which happens to be an awesome name for a drink. Price was fair, on the expensive side. Would definitely come back.
author: Aviah M.

description:
This is definitely a trendy Vietnamese place.  Not your normal ma and pa restaurant.  It was crowded when we arrived and I was surprised that there were that many people there.  I was also surprised to see that the menu still had the Vietnamese names for the dishes.  I ordered the beef pho and my bf got the bun bo hue.  We also ordered spring rolls and the banh xeo.  The banh xeo took a bit longer to make and it actually came after our entrees and was a bigger portion than I had anticipated.  That honesty could be a main dish on its own.  A shame we couldn't eat it fresh cause that's the best time to have it.

The spring rolls were nice and big and tasted great with the peanut butter sauce.  My pho was surprisingly well flavored and the bun bo hue also very nice.  There are a few other things I want to try so I'll definitely be back for more.  Great Vietnamese spot in the mission!
author: Nyla K.

description: I recently ordered a shaken beef entrée here. The beef and the accompanying sauce was wonderful but the rice wasn't completely cooked. Biting into a halfway cooked rice kernels isn't my idea of a good dining experience.
author: Gerard Y.

description: Love love love this place. My boyfriend and I live a few blocks away and this is one of our favorite go-to spots. Bun ga xa and hue rolls are simply amazing as is the pho if you're in the mood for something more light and healthy. Prices are reasonable too.
author: Sarah H.

description: Time for another relative "miss" at Mau, where the service was a bit lacking.  We walked in around 2:30 on a Sunday, and were acknowledged by a host within a couple minutes.  We stood around for a few more minutes and were offered a high top.  We saw that a regular table was vacant but not yet bussed, and we asked if we could sit at that one whenever it was ready.  The host said yes, but another five or so minutes passed and nothing happened.  A manager saw we had been waiting, and got the table bussed.  We waited another ten minutes to order, and another ten to fifteen minutes for our food.  Much longer than usual wait between entering and getting our food.  Most importantly - the beef stew pho was very tasty but could have used a little more cilantro to give it a fresh flavor.
author: Christina G.

description:
Happily, Mau took us by surprise. The food and service are of the highest caliber. The decor gives no clues as to the cuisine, minimalist, clean & nicely done. So happy to enjoy a quality lunch experience @ Mau, that may just be setting a new high standard for "Vietnamese" cuisine in EssF. It is a quality over quantity orientation that we loved. Some reviewers report that Mau does not serve authentic Vietnamese food, without any specific reference to their disatisfaction. Believe it or not, Vietnamese cuisine is almost as varied as "American" cuisine. This joint was originally put together by the former Slow Club chef Sante Salvoni and Tín Vietnamese Cuisine owner Hung Dang. The food & service:

Papaya Salad: -Great- Nicely done w/ Shrimp and Squid. Perfect balance of spices, roasted peanut pieces and fresh/crispy papaya & carrots with the requisite cilantro sprigs. 

Chicken clay pot: -Great- Nice quality chicken and a sauce that could be bottled. Excellent spice combination with ginger slivers. 

Xiu Mai: -Superb- Done in the traditional Vietnamese way, 3 meat balls served in a bowl w/ a savory broth. Sliced cucumber, cilantro and basil sprigs and a banh mi (the Vietnamese version of "French" bread). 

Service: -Superb- Jorge, our server was friendly, knowledgeable and cheerful.

Will be back dining @ Mau very soon !
author: Matsuo U.

description:
The food is fine. I would be happy to come here if it were not for the terrible service.

First, it took about 10 minutes to get a table even though there were several available and only one person in front of us.

Then, we waited at the table for 10-15 minutes before the server showed up. We ordered one appetizer and two bowls of pho. It took maybe 20 minutes for the appetizer to show up. Maybe, they had to make the dough first or something?

The pho also took a long time. Shouldn't pho be a quick thing? At PPQ in the sunset, your bowl of pho is likely to arrive in under 5 minutes. At Mau, it's a 20+ minute affair.

Finally, we were unable to get the check at the end. We asked 3 times for the check. First, we asked the bus boy. He said he would get it but never did. Then, the hostess said she would get the check. Right after she said that, she spent 5 minutes cleaning the table next to us and never got the check after that. Eventually, we just got up to leave and flagged down the waiter on the way out to get the check.

Definitely avoid this place if you're A) hungry or B) trying to eat dinner in under 2 hours.
author: Alex O.

description:
I knocked off two stars because of the extremely slow and non attentive service. It took us over 45 minutes to receive our food because the servers miscommunicated and forgot to ring in our orders. They took our order but did not even give us water until 15 minutes later when I had to ask (and constantly ask when our water was empty). Get your shit together.. I don't expect to order a bowl of pho and have to wait that long for my food. So I was extremely disappointed in that. 

The food itself was good though. I would recommend starting off with the Hue Rolls - plenty of good and plentiful slices of marinated beef wrapped in rice rolls and dipped in fish sauce. Bun Bo Hue was pretty tasty, has a nice kick of spice although I definitely needed to add more spice in mine. The crispy noodles were tasty, but the portion was not too big. 

All in all, I did leave feeling pretty disappointed in the service unfortunately.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I had high expectations for MAU, given the reviews, location, branding, menu ... I may have had an atypical experience but I left satisfied, just not blown away.

The host/hostess situation is kind of a mess. There's no organized way to get your name on a list or figure out how long you'll be waiting. The staff was very nice, but also seemed overwhelmed. I think we waited maybe 15m (on a Monday) and once we did get a table we waited at least another 10 before anyone came over. 

Our waiter also seemed rushed and took all of our orders (drinks, apps, dinner) at once. He then came back ten minutes later to tell me they'd run out of what I ordered, and helped me pick something else without bringing back a menu. To keep things easy, I requested "something spicy with shrimp." What ended up arriving in front of me later was neither spicy, nor contained shrimp... but it was good, and the place was busy so I accepted it and didn't complain. The waiter never came back to ask how anything was.

As far as pacing, the appetizer came before our drinks did. Drink refills took awhile, but water was replaced regularly which helped. My friend ordered the lemonade which was strangely really salty. It wasn't bad necessarily, but something to be prepared for. 

It took a frustratingly long time to get our check, and have our leftovers packed. I had also requested sriracha to-go (the house-made is delicious!), but the waiter forgot it. I think if I had been on a more relaxed schedule this would have been ok, but I was tired and wanted to go home. In all I think the experience took almost 2.5 hours, which is a long time for such a casual restaurant with a limited menu. 

MAU serves tasty food from an interesting menu, but the experience leaves something to be desired. I'd go back, but with more time and lower expectations.
author: Catie F.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend. Service was wonderful. They were very polite and we were seated quickly. Place looked very modern compared to other Vietnamese places. Place is clean but a little cramped.

Neither of us were very hungry so we got something small. We got the Spring Rolls $8 and Garlic Noodles $7. The garlic noodles were on point! It's almost as good as Perilla garlic noodles. Good balance between garlic and butter. For a "side," they gave a nice portion. Pretty filling. WARNING: I think there were nuts in the garlic noodles so those with allergies, beware. The spring rolls were refreshing. Not heavily minted and didn't fall apart easily. Ingredients were fresh as well. The dishes had really nice presentation.

They had Soju Shots for $2 each. My friend and I got one. It tasted so gross. It was like rubbing alcohol. My friend said this was just not good soju (IDK I don't drink so I can't say). Definite skip.

I can see why this place has really good ratings. The service was great and food was great. I will come back just for the garlic noodles or if I'm hungry, would try their other entrees.
author: Benita M.

description:
If possible, I would give Mau 3.5 stars--for the nice ambiance, wine/cocktail options, and fun 80s music--but I simply didn't feel there was anything spectacular about the dining experience.

The restaurant doesn't take reservations, so my girlfriend and I hopped in an Uber and headed over hoping there wouldn't be too long of a wait. Luckily, even though we arrived at 8:30 PM on a Sunday evening (of a long weekend) there was no wait time. Possibly the cold, rainy weather helped us out there a bit. 

A very nice server quickly greeted us at the door and ushered us to our table. After giving us some time to peruse the menu, our order was taken and we were promptly served our food. Our waitress was extremely friendly and accommodating and I have no complaints about the service. The decor of the restaurant is quite pleasing as well and fits in nicely with the rest of the restaurants lining Valencia Street. And as for the food, there was no problem (well at least not with mine). The problem though is that I felt as if I could have something fairly comparable at any number of Vietnamese restaurants in the Bay Area.

Here's what we had to eat:

Spring rolls: The ingredients were all fresh, and the nut sauce was delicious, though it wasn't better than what I've had elsewhere.

Frog legs: These were actually quite delicious, especially when paired with the accompanying  salt-jalapeno dip. That said, this was actually my first time trying frog legs, so I have no basis of comparison.

Pho bo: It was very tasty and took care of the pho craving that had been building up over the evening. Then again, it wasn't especially better than other pho I've had in the past.

Bun Thang: My girlfriend ordered this, but neither she nor I particularly liked it. I don't think it's fair to include this in my personal rating of the restaurant as it contained mushrooms, which I dislike, and I would have never ordered it for myself. I will note, however, that it is not specified on the menu that the dish contains mushrooms. That should be corrected.

To drink I tried the Pho-get-me-not and my girlfriend had a glass of pinot noir. Both drinks were good, but neither was something I would be overly eager to try again.

So, with the exception of the frog legs, the meal was good, but just not very noteworthy.
author: Rodney G.

description: Not the most authentic Vietnamese restaurant for sure, but it has grown to be old faithful when the husband and I are in the mood for "clear soup."  Pho places are hard for people like us - I don't eat beef, he doesn't eat meat. We appreciate Mau's clear labeling of the broth used in each soup, as well as their generosity when it comes to condiments (husband goes through ALOT of jalapenos!). It's a win win!
author: Archana P.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite spots when I'm around the area. I have tried many of their dishes and I have not been disappointed by any of them. One dish I definitely recommend is the Fish Clay Pot with a side of garlic noodles, is the best. 

I always feel really welcome by the staff who are all very friendly and attentive, always kind and professional.
If you're around the area you have to stop and get some Mau.
author: Mario G.

description: I've been having lunch here weekly for the past month and I love their tofu Vietnamese sandwich. It's very tasty. I would suggest that they add shisho leaf to the sandwich.  The combination would provide an even more robust flavor. Please note that the sandwich is only served during lunch.
author: Kenji S.

description:
You would think for the location and how lovely the ambiance and vibes are here that the food would be kinda on the meh side. But, you'll be pleasantly surprised on how good the food is and how they can also keep a customer happy in all the ways.

Atmosphere is amazing. Lively, beautiful, fun, and cozy. It's on Valencia, so location is also super easy.

Food is great. I've been here twice once for just the Hu rolls, and this time for the rolls plus the PHO BÒ. Really good pho. The broth is tasty, the portion size is out of control. Even my bottomless pit of a stomach couldn't finish it. They do not go light on the beef slivers. Chunks of delicious meat.

The service was impeccable. Great restaurant for a Friday night out.
author: Priti K.

description:
I generally do not like any pho spot that's not a mom and pop type shop but the food here is so good!

+Food
Spring Rolls: Good egg rolls, I love when they use that egg roll skin that gets all crinkly and yummy.
Hue Rolls: Wow, this was delicious.  Grilled meat and fresh herbs rolled with rice paper.  I need more of this in my life.
Pho Bo: Add the beef balls, those are always my favorite.  The pho broth was nice and flavorful and there was plenty of meat to go with the noodles.

+Service
Everyone was very nice and polite

+Ambiance
Cool and hip and clean.

-Price
Everything is in the $10-$15 range.  That's a little steep for me since I'm used to my $6-8 bowl of pho.  However this is a "hipster" type place and the food does taste good so I'll accept the higher price.
author: Mui K.

description:
All about the catfish clay pot.  Could eat it with a spoon.  It's been perfect every time except for one instance where it was way too salty (shame, shame chef for that night).  

Good service, nice ambience, this is a solid place.  Oh, and their pho is pretty good, too.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Came here for lunch because reviews seemed good but was thoroughly disappointed by the slow service and the mediocre food. Grilled pork was dry and burnt. Chicken in ban mi also dry and burnt so bad I could chew most of it. Adding to the insult, I paid $8 for this sandwich when I can get way better for less in other places in the city. 

For such expensive prices, I expect way more than what we got.
author: Emily L.

description: Amazing pho!! Service was so quick, pho was delicious, and so were the crispy rolls!! The bun bo hue was the perfect level of spice and so much food I took half home for later. Thai iced tea was delicious and not sickenly sweet like a lot of place. Definitely a go to place in the mission and perfect for a quick bite.
author: Amanda L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised with Mau.  We were wanting pho one chilly evening and ended up here.  The interior and ambiance is very nice and the food is good with very reasonable prices.

Pho-  I was kinda expecting some Americanized pho when I saw all the pepper in my bowl, but to my surprise it was really good!  The beef was flavorful (fatty? lol) and broth was on point.  I may have found a new pho place
Catfish claypot-  very popular dish that is also really good.  I do think there was too much pepper but the catfish is still a solid meal choice  
Imperial rolls-  large enough portion to be shared or have as a light meal

Service is a bit on the slower side, so if I do decide to be a regular I may just do pick ups.  All in all, a really great find!
author: Lyn C.

description:
This is a great spot that is reasonably priced while also nice enough where you'd want to enjoy a drink with a friend. The pho is about $10 and they have a decent wine list - it is a bit sad when your glass of wine is about as expensive as your entree. 

I was there on a Thursday night and had no wait at 7. By the time we left at 8:30, it was packed - not sure how long the wait was but you should be prepared.
author: Wendy L.

description: This is my comfort food! Love the grilled shrimp vermicelli and fresh coconut here. Also the pho with veggies or crab soup. Ambiance is nice, if a bit noisy. Great price, service. My go-to in the Mission.
author: Lulu S.

description:
Surprisingly authentic for the neighborhood...

There's a small wait on Fridays and Saturdays, but it's not as long as other places and turnover is quite fast. You have the option of bar seating or tables.  

Cost more than other vietnamese places in SF, but given the neighborhood and patrons, I'm not so surprised.
author: Angelica C.

description:
It's funny how there aren't that many upscale/trendy Vietnamese places. Not funny ha-ha but funny like Michele Bachmann explaining how gays are fully responsible for pedophilia while she maintains her seat in Congress. Except that's more scary-funny. Mau isn't scary-funny, but it is funny that Charles Phan has pretty much sewed up this market with Slanted Door and Out the Door. There was Zadin in the Castro - but that closed, and Sunflower in Potrero Hill except they're about as edgy as Aunt Martha's Old-Fashioned Salad Dressing. Mau definitely fills a void, and while I was ready to drink the haterade when I first saw this hipster-centric Viet spot on Valencia, I don't. The food's good, and the service is friendly if a bit harried. And why not since the prices ain't that bad.

It was about 6PM on a Tuesday evening when I went, and the place was already jumping. Long tables crowded with high-squeal Asian girls, tables for two where young marrieds squeezed in their state-of the-art baby pram. Even the main counter was packed with lonely young men slurping their pho bowls before they pursue their net failed Kickstarter campaign (photo: http://bit.ly/VaRMpW). Strangely there was a skinny counter that cuts down the middle of the restaurant where nobody was sitting, so of course, I sat there even though it doubled as their menu and water-glass storage space. The menu is pure Vietnamese with no attempts at pan-Asian acceptance (photo: http://bit.ly/1sxMEHX). I believe they abandoned that idea when they first opened a couple of years ago. I ordered what I was told was a must-try, the $11 Lotus Root Salad (photo: http://bit.ly/1sxMEHX).

Quite a variety of fresh ingredients here with the sliced lotus root surprisingly complementary to the shaved pig's ear. There was also shrimp and a lot of snappy vegetables - carrots, celery, red bell pepper, onion. Rau ram and mint was used in place of cilantro, a nice touch, chopped peanuts were used as a garnish, and there was the welcome crunch of shrimp chips. Yep, I liked this one, and it wasn't heavy. But I obviously came for the pho, but my choice may shock you. I went for the $9 bowl of Pho Ga, probably their simplest variation (photo: http://bit.ly/1yh7UDA). It's a ginger-chicken broth with shards of poached chicken and rice noodles. That's it, a bowl of pho my Yiddish mommala would approve. With plenty of siracha, it's delish.

FOOD - 4 stars...traditional Vietnamese with fresh ingredients, good stuff
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...hipster-heavy and buzzing in the evenings if you can stand it
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly and trying to keep track of the overflow
TOTAL - 4 stars...Tin is more like Tintin compared to Mau...if you know what I mean
author: Ed U.

description:
I had a mini middle school reunion at Mau... yes, middle school. Growing up with homemade Vietnamese food makes me skeptical about going to more expensive Viet restaurants. I was pleasantly surprised with how good Mau was. Yes it's Americanized in the essence that it caters to a more Americanized crowd, however the food is pretty authentic tasting IMO. 

They have dishes from all regions of Vietnam - north, middle, south. I ordered the Bun Cha Hanoi - which is a rice noodle dish served with fresh veggies (lettuce&various herbs) and grilled fatty pork with a mixed fish sauce. Looked like all my friend's dishes were great as well, everyone really enjoyed it. The service was also very nice, the only complaint I had was that it was super hot in the restaurant, not sure if that was a normal thing or just something that was going on that day. Other than that we had a great experience and I'll definitely be back, maybe with my mom next time to see what she thinks!!
author: Elaine N.

description:
This is good pho for the Mission, and I'd probably come back if I'm in the area and in the mood for Vietnamese because the space has a good vibe...but I won't be going out of my way to get this again.

The pho is subpar as compared to smaller, hole-in-the-wall type places I've been to in San Francisco.  My personal favorite places for pho ga (my go-to) are Pho Ha Tien and Joy Hing Bar-B-Que Noodle, which are more authentic / less hipster and also significantly more affordable (~$6 versus ~$11).  If you want a kind of funky / hipster spot for a date, however, Mau is a much better choice.

The pho ga broth was OK - pretty heavy on the ginger, but under-salted.  The noodles were interesting insomuch as they were thin rice noodles, but they arrived totally congealed.  The chicken was entirely white meat, which was way too dry.  I ate the broth and almost none of the noodles or chicken - basically wasting half of the dish.

The garlic baby bok choy is awesome though - totally on point.

P.S. They have terrible cell reception in here and no WiFi - my boyfriend and I wanted to plan a vacation over dinner, but we couldn't do anything.  Some people might like having to disconnect - I don't...
author: Tay H.

description:
4.5 stars. Mau is my go to Vietnamese place in the mission. Yes, service is sometimes shotty, but the delicious food makes it all worth it. That being said, I think you have to have the right perspective about Mau. It is not the authentic vietnamese cuisine found at a hole in the wall in the Tenderloin. It's not going to have your mother's pho broth that is cooked for over 10 hours. It's more modern and fusion-y and you definitely pay a premium for that. I mean, come on, it's on Valencia in the mission.

I always order the spicy chicken vermicelli. The chicken is so flavorful. Normally, I never order chicken because I have a phobia of dried meat but not in this dish! It's sooo moist (Ew, did I really just say moist?) And because I don't want to forgo my second favorite dish, I force the boyfriend to order the pork chops. So juicy and thick (This review is getting too rated R). Now drench everything in fish sauce and enjoy! 

-.5 for the overpriced coconuts. Mf*ing $6!?!
author: Xinxin W.

description: Huge apps that will fill you up. Pho is ok but pretty white washed compared to some other places in town. There were always a lot of families with their kids every time I went and also some couples on dates. Restaurant has a hipster/cool vibe and I would go back if I was close by but not trek across town for this spot.
author: J Y.

description: Love this place. Not only is the food super tasty and affordable but the waiters and manager super friendly.
author: Carmen C.

description:
This isn't the usual traditional Vietnamese restaurant, however, as a cool spot that serves the most popular Vietnamese dishes, I highly recommend this place hands down. 
My husband and I come here often because we can always count on the quality of the food here at Mau, and also because it is one of the few restaurants in the Mission that is also reasonably priced.  The ambience is lively, and you can come here for a casual date, friends or solo.  I have to admit, however, that when it is crazy busy, sometimes some of their dishes aren't as good as it normally is. But I would say 4 out of 5 times I frequented this place, I am always completely satisfied and don't feel like San Fran is stealing money from my pocketbook, which is a rare combination these days.
author: Luna R.

description:
love the environment and ambiance. casual but hip. 

the pho bo, spring rolls, and catfish claypot are sooo good that we always end up ordering the same things rather than trying other dishes :( pho bo has lots of beef, perfectly cooked noodles, fresh ingredients, savory broth that isn't dehydrating (you know what i mean...when you need to drink gallons of water after eating pho). 

we've sat at the bar twice and the bartender/waiter there is always super friendly and efficient. food comes out quickly (clay pot takes a while longer). sitting at a tables sometimes requires more patience for service. 

wish they took ressies. food can sometimes be on the salty side. but this has been my go to place in the area when i have pho cravings!! always look forward to going back to mau :)
author: Yin H.

description: I was skeptical of the hipster cabana decor and the tony Valencia Street address... these things do not correlate highly to authentic Vietnamese food. But what can I tell you? They're the Real McCoy, and offer way more than the standard pho ga / pho bo / bo bun hue etc etc. The brothless noodles were a treat -- I got the Hu Tieu Kho and I definitely be back for that. The shaken beef is almost as good as the same at Slanted Door but for half the price! The claypot is a little too salty. Overall, though, good value for the price.
author: Ken H.

description:
[Old review from May 2015]

How to motivate yourself to go for a run: pick a restaurant destination and order take-out from there. Knowing you have skin in the game (I.e., you've paid for food) and delicious food awaiting you, you'll want to get there stat.

This time around, I called in one order of Hue (hoo-ay) rolls from Mau. In short, these rolls are: lemongrass pork, lettuce, scallions, and cilantro wrapped in thick rice paper. Or in other words, deliciousness. They also provide a small container of sweet dipping sauce. Only downside is that these babies are a bit pricy for the size of the portion. But getting them once in a while won't break the bank..

Hope to be back to try some other offerings!
author: Julia N.

description:
I love Mau! More like 4.5 stars but I decided to be generous because we just went there for dinner and it really hit the spot on a cold, rainy SF night. 

It is our go to Vietnamese place in the Mission, if not the city. The restaurant is trendy and clean (definitely a plus and not an adjective you'd use to describe 95% of pho joints) and they have a full bar in addition to serving beer and wine. Granted, it isn't the most "authentic" pho place I've been to, but it definitely has better quality meat and ingredients. 

I end up getting the papaya salad every time I go because I love their take on it - the calamari, shrimp and rice puffs are unique and add different texture to the dish. I also like the bun thit phoung (lemongrass pork over vermicelli noodles) and the pho bo. Both are delicious! I've also tried the bo kho before as well, which is a spicy beef broth with brisket, carrots and basil and your choice of baguette or egg noodles. I liked this one but not as much as the others. 

Can't wait to come back again!
author: Sally C.

description:
Mau did a great job with the decor and overall atmosphere. But, the food here has been americanized and does not taste as authentic as other Vietnamese restaurants (eg: Jasmine Garden on 14th St). I can't deny the variety they have here though. 

We ordered spring rolls, pho bo, and lemongrass chicken. There was nothing super special about the dishes. The spring rolls were great (fresh and light), but the entrees weren't as yummy. I typically use the pho broth as a measuring qualification and the broth here did not taste rich or unusually flavorful. If you happen to be in the area and the other places have long lines, this place is not a bad substitute-- but I wouldn't come out of my way to come here.

Though the food was okay-- the service was great! They really know how to serve their customers.
author: Connie L.

description:
Food: Chicken pho was mediocre. Something is off about the noodles. I can tell they were dry noodles that haven't been reconstituted in boiling water long enough. Broth was watered down and lacking in flavor that good slow cooked bone broth would have. MSG doesn't give you that flavor .. just a headache or stomach problems afterwards. Also who serves Pho with pickled red onions?? I grew up eating great pho made by my Vietnamese mama so I have higher expectation but the pickled red onion is just plain weird. My BF had the beef pho, he said the meat in the soup was tasty. 

Service: poor. After walking through the door, was ignored for a good 5 mins before we could even achieve eye contact with tall skinny host guy who without a single word or smile walked right pass us. A nod, a smile, a "be with you in a second" would have been great. You're in the business of service and this is basic good customer service practice. Maybe he was too cool to smile? Once seated, waited maybe another 15 mins before anyone acknowledged us. Our actual waitress was nice though. She apologized for the delay service and had a genuine smile. To the manager on duty that day (red sneakers)- when you have so many people complaining about service on Yelp, it's a management problem not necessarily any individual staff's problem. When you ask a customer if there is a problem and she tells you, acting defensive is not the way to respond. 

Price: chicken pho for $9.50 is the going price for SF now a day so I'll give them that. 

Location: heart of hipsterville..that has its own pro's and con's. Parking is always difficult in that area in general but we snagged a spot right in front that day. 

This was my third attempt at this place and I likely will not come back..I'll just drive 45 mins to have pho at my mom's house and leave happy.
author: Tien L.

description:
Mau knows how to make a broth.  

Not the best pho broth I've ever had but, a solid respectable option surpassing many other SF offerings. 

It's the right proportion of salty, sweet and fatty.
author: Liss T.

description:
Who is in the mood for hipster Vietnamese food that isn't actually as overpriced as you might think? Mau is a good place for that. It's definitely not going to be the best Vietnamese cuisine you've ever had but they have a surprisingly decent pho.

The decor is bright and fresh and the menu consists of pretty authentic Vietnamese dishes. It's not high on my repeat visit list but I was fairly satisfied with my dinner.
author: Yi Z.

description: sooo glad they opened back up! 5 spiced chicken is to die for!!!! love the service and great prices!
author: Shane T.

description:
I'm a 2nd gen Chinese so I can say this....Guys, this is a white person's Pho house. I mean, what else would you expect in the Mission? Yelp is gonna take this post down so up vote it while you still can. 

But YEA! It's CLEAN, PRICEY, CLEAN, tastefully decorated, not squished, has great servers and IT'S CLEAN. Really. Unlike other places, I don't feel like the walls are made of fly paper.

That ALONE should intrigue you enough to come here.
author: Joshua F.

description:
My friend and I ordered four items - papaya salad, chicken wings, pork rice sheet rolls, and a tofu claypot.  Looking at the prices, we didn't think the portions would be THAT big.  The wings and sheet rolls were enough but the food was so good we couldn't stop eating!  The flavors were perfect and the sauces definitely made most of the dish.  The atmosphere was casual and since we were there on a nice day, they had the large windows opened and a few outdoor tables.  The crowd was chic (and young) and our server was polite but busy.  

It was a great place for lunch (they also have a pretty decent selection of wine by the glass) and I'm definitely coming back!
author: Gwingie L.

description: A very Westernized take on Vietnamese food. Definitely don't come here if you're expecting authentic, ma and pa kind of Vietnamese restaurant, but if you're not into the whole hole-in-the-wall, dirty restaurant scene in which most authentic Vietnamese restaurants reside, then I guess you can come here. I ordered the bun bo hue and the broth itself as a decent flavor. Is it real bun bo hue flavored broth? Not really..and you DO NOT add rare steak in BBH! I think one person complained about not getting tripe in it. You don't put tripe in BBH either!! Save that for pho, please. My boyfriend did get the grilled shrimp and pork vermicelli noodle dish and it was good but you can't mess up that kind of dish either. If you want good Vietnamese food, go to Yummy Yummy in Inner Sunset! You won't regret. That place is moderately clean if you're worried about it being dirty.
author: Kristina D.

description: When down in the Mission this is a good place to go.  Very nice interior and bar area, good selection of wine and great menu all at a reasonable price.  Have been here several times and never disappointed.  You can sit at the bar and just hang out, or have a full sit down meal in the main dining area. It is all very casual, super relaxed and comfortable. The quality of the food is very good, and the portions fairly generous. Waitstaff is friendly, helpful with any questions you may have about the menu and seem also to be having fun. So if you're feeling like some Asian food while in the Mission I would check this place out.
author: Lori H.

description:
We were excited to try out this place.  It was definitely a disappointment.  We ordered an appetizer, two noodles soup and garlic sautéed Bok choy. 

The appetizer was good and arrived on time (5-10 mins after we ordered)

The noodles soup took more than 30 mins to make and that was after two follow ups with two different waiter and waitress.

The bak choy came, but it will deeply soaked with soy sauce.  Saltiest bak choy ever!  The two noodle soups finally came.  Pho Ga and pho bo.  It was just mediocre.  The waiter asked if we want an appetizer and apologized for the delay.  As I mentioned earlier, we already ordered an appetizer! They obviously forgot our orders.  Then he came back with two shots.  We just looked at him and said we don't drink, please take this away.  Already super awkward.  

We just quickly finished our food and asked for our check. The waitress came by and gave us the check and started to clear out our dishes.  Somehow, the chopsticks flipped and got some remaining soup splashed all over my jacket!!

Epic failed and not coming back for sure!
author: Deb L.

description:
Came to Mau after a nice sunday at Dolores park, and we were hungry.   I have tried to come to Mau before but there was always a wait, so we just kept it moving, but on this day the wait was short so we jumped on it.  

I had the pork chop and I thought it was just okay.  The flavor was decent enough, but there was no wow to it.  I've been to much cheaper places that left you wanting more, savoring each cut you take out.  It might be that its a thicker cut so the flavor gets lost.  It was also dry.

Also we split imperial rolls.  Again, nothing spectacular, but to be fair, a lot of places fail at these, with the veggie to meat ratio being way too high, resulting in a more sweet, less savory experience. 

The pho was just okay.  

For the price of Mau, I would imagine more creativity and flavor expressions, however I was just left feeling like it was an okay pho house with fancier plating.  Not even the service lived up to the pricing.  Maybe they are trying to imitate the pho house experience with rude waiters, but usually the rudeness comes from the language barrier, here its just plain arrogance or indifference, after all it is in the Mission.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Although I am not too much of a Vietnamese food fan, I was quite happy with Mau, albeit a tad pricier than most Vietnamese places.

Came in and ordered the pho bo and bun thit nuong and split both with my gf. The pho was good - a bit on the salty side for me, but they put a lot of meat in there, which I appreciated. The bun thit nuong was where it was at though. BBQ pork was so delicious over a heaping amount of vermicelli noodles. Even though the weather was a bit chilly in SF, I would go with that dish over the pho any day.

Overall, generous portions, and I was happy with the lunch and cleanliness of the place - again, expect to pay a bit more than your usual Vietnamese place though.
author: Brandon Y.

description: The pho ga was not bad here but I really wasn't a fan of their tofu bun. The tofu itself was so overcooked it was dry and unappetizing, and I wasn't really a fan of the seasoning they put in the bun itself. I also added fried eggrolls / cha gio and honestly wasn't very impressed with this either.
author: Stephany L.

description:
Stopped here for lunch.  Place wasnpacked hut luckily our timing was good and didn't have to wait too long.

The food was well prepared.  I had the catfish in claypot.  It was supposed to be spicey.  It was actually quite sweet.  Presentation was "upscale".   

Call it the millenial SF fufu.

That aside, i would go back and recommend it if you are in the area.
author: P.Y. H.

description: Great , flavorful food. Very nice experience. Kid friendly. Very nice customer service. It was hot and didn't take long to serve. We got Pho and the Clay Pots. My first experience. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Asia R.

description: Great food, flavorful. Nice relaxed environment. Staff very friendly quick to seat me until my group arrived
author: Eric J.

description: We were walking around looking for somewhere to eat and noticed this was highly rated but there were many in the neighborhood. I was very impressed! A lot of food for the money and so fresh I wish there was one in my neighborhood! We had spring rolls to begin with but at the end of it all it was a lot of food but what an experience!
author: Joel M.

description:
The food here is pretty tasty. My friends and I love, love, love the Hue roll. The Bun Bo Hue and Pho Bo here are pretty good also! Normally, we have pretty pleasant visits but unfortunately ......

Our server (tall, skinny, male) was unpleasant and condescending since the moment we sat down. And to make matters worse.. I don't want to be all prissy but the reason I'm giving this place 2 stars is because sanitation should be emphasized at any restaurant... & during this visit, my friends and I were not happy about the way our straws were given to us. The server handed the straws to us with his bare hands, and his dirty bandaid touching the straws.. With that said, we were pretty grossed out and that just ruined the experience for us because we were worried about the rest of our food that we had not received yet.
author: Mei-En D.

description:
Young coconut, please. I order it every time. So. Damn. Good.

The veggie pho is flavorful, packed with fresh veggies, and they hook up fried tofu with it when I ask. Yummayyyyyy!

Service is great, although the kitchen takes a minute when they're busy.
author: Gabriela W.

description: The food is a bit pricey, but solid. Sure, you can find cheaper pho elsewhere, but it's Valencia. What do you expect? I always just stick to the original pho with chicken, and it's quality food.
author: Nicole Y.

description: I generally enjoy Mau. Their buns are consistently flavorful and hit the spot.  However, looking at my credit card statement, I noticed that they overcharged me for my last takeout order.  Always check your statements!
author: Robin C.

description:
When i go to a vietnamese restaurant, I always order pho noodle soup as an indication of their overall food quality. For that reason, Mau gets 5 stars from me because their pho noodle is ON POINT. The broth is rich, their meat tender and tasty. Did I say the broth is rich? A lot of the pho places don't use real broth; they use stocks or flavors, but using my best judgment and taste buds, their soup is real broth. 

I'm now a regular here. Dinner visit after my long clinic shifts on Saturday has become my ritual. 

Highly recommended.
author: Jason I.

description: This little Vietnamese bistro was so cute! It had a bar and open kitchen! I'm impressed with the look and feel of this place because I'm so used to hole in the walls in San Jose. The service was really nice and the bartender refilled our waters, constantly checked in, and gave us a "don't rush" vibe when we were deciding on what to order right before the kitchen closed. I got the pork clay pot which had slow braised pork belly and shoulder in a rich, savory sauce. The jasmin rice was super good too! I heard the zonirushi rice cooker go off in the background so that explains the fluffy, moistness! My boyfriend got the bun bo hue, which had super clean and spicy broth! I've never had it so good! We both shared a hue roll appetizer, which was humongous and that fish sauce dipper was like the icing on the cake!
author: Elise G.

description:
There are a lot of places I would drive to and fight for parking just to eat again. Unfortunately, this is not one of those places. Pho was pricier than it should be and in the end, just disappointing in every aspecr. 

ahah well, cool spot though
author: Joey C.

description:
The food here is actually decent, but the service knows how to steal defeat from the jaws of victory. 

Sat down and one of the busboys dropped a tray full of glasses onto the floor which shattered right next to us. We had to move tables and brush glass off of us. Not a good start!

For the second course, The waiter didn't seem to understand what we wanted to order (we were reading off the menu...). Also asked for a vegetarian version of the papaya salad, which he said couldn't be done. We schooled him on the menu (asterisks next to items indicated they could be made vegetarian). So yeah. 

The Main course was incredibly slow service. And a missed item that we were charged for and had to amend. 

This is a solid Vietnamese spot but you can find so much better in close proximity. They will also be less expensive (and note this meal was on the company's dime).

I would simply look elsewhere. Another Valencia spot that misses the mark :/
author: Farooq K.

description: Came here for. a group dinner. Food is excellent and the service is amazing. It tends to be way too noisy almost every dinner time. Is it the building or the people just lousy I couldn't tell what but everytime I come here there r loud noise.
author: Thyra K.

description:
This time it really was a Vietnamese place and it hit the spot. Farm raised frog legs from China? I'd like to have a frog farm some day just so I could fall asleep each night under the stars listening to a chorus of frogs singing in the moonlight. Served with lime and cilantro. 

Fresh young cold coconut beverage conjures up visions of topless island women playing in the surf in a lagoon on my private fantasy island. 

Vietnamese vermicelli and giant man eater prawns make me think of her.
author: Joe W.

description:
Whether you're inclined towards (what I consider to be) more exotic cuts of meat such as frogs legs or pig ear, or you stick to "old reliables" like pho ga & five-spice chicken, Mau's got you covered. 

Questioning its authenticity isn't gonna make you look cool, so don't even try it; Mau is too easy of a target -- they don't use MSG, they're located in hipsterville, & the chefs are from south of the border (always a plus in my book!) rather than from Southeast Asia. We both enjoyed lunch & that's all that matters. We ordered: 

-- cha gio: fried rolls with shrimp, pork, woodear mushrooms, jicama, taro, glass noodles. Perfect crisp, bubbly wrapper. More meat than veggies. Super good! 
-- pho ga: I added shrimp & pork wontons b/c I was in an indecisive mood, & could not be happier with my culinary mashup! Wontons were small, but flavorful, delicate skin, would definitely order again. Ginger-chicken broth was so delicious, it didn't need as much sriracha as I normally use. Huge portion of noodles & white meat chicken. 
-- grilled prawns over vermicelli noodles: did not try, but he definitely approved.  
-- thai iced tea & iced artichoke tea: strongly flavored, not diluted at all. 
Total: $53, not including tip

An absolutely satisfying lunch! Will definitely return to try their sides of garlic noodles & garlic sautéed baby bok choy, & to get my wonton fix!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
This food wasn't good. I got a pho and the meet was too dry. Tasteless. The bride was bad and too salty. 

I won't come back.
author: Mauro P.

description: Love it. Very nice place, and good food. Smell of pho is so good from other customers. I tried the mango salad lotus root salad. I love them both. Will try other dishes next time.
author: Minh N.

description: My review is based only on two dishes (Pho Bo and Chicken Lemon Grass) and unfortunately, we were very disappointed.  The Pho tasted like they added beef broth powder that you buy in grocery stores to add the beef flavor.  Pho should be cooked using real bones and not fake powder.  It was very salty so couldn't even drink the broth.  If they can't even get pho right, why bother opening a pho restaurant.  The chicken lemon as just ok but nothing to brag about.
author: John L.

description:
Rude staff and poorly run by greedy managers who'd rather fill more tables than feed and serve those who've been waiting. Maybe the consistent queue makes you think you can treat customers poorly and get away with it, but watch out for that karma.

This is normally one of my go-to's for a quick affordable meal, but this last visit left me angry, annoyed and worst of all, hungry. Ended up leaving after waiting 45+ min after ordering with a dismissive and condescending manager. 

Get your act together Mau, you used to be one of my weekly go-to's, but with staff and service like this, you're going to lose your customers, starting with me.
author: Andrew T.

description: It was ok. I had high hopes given the excitement about Mau reopening, but wasn't really blown away. I order the Pho Ga, and it was pretty bland. Lots of noodles and chicken though, if that's your thing. Not going to rush back. Service was also pretty bad; not sure if they were training new servers, but it took a long time to seat us, despite there being open tables, our drinks went to a different table, and we were missing a spoon with the Pho.
author: Tom W.

description:
Meh, this place was ok.  Would I return?  Unlikely because nothing was spectacular.  There was a group of 9 of us & nobody was enthralled.  There are many other places to enjoy more flavorful, authentic & better priced Vietnamese food.  There aren't many competitors in the hipster Mission area so this place will probably do fine.  The service was great & friendly.  Our group had fun socializing.

From what I remember, we ordered these items, none of which were anything special:
$9 BUN THIT NUONG grilled lemongrass pork, vermicelli noodles

$12 BUN THIT BO NUONG grilled lemongrass niman beef, vermicelli noodles

$9 PORK SHOULDER grilled shoulder, lemongrass, shallots, garlic

$9 LEMONGRASS TOFU* twice-cooked tofu, lemongrass, shiitake mushrooms - person barely touched it.

FYI - $7 BANH MI (lunch only) - hit the TL for authentic sammies for $4
author: Kim S.

description:
Solid.  Clean. Not dirty.  Great staff that's respectful and helpful to food allergies.  

Their appetizers are a hit.  Their pho is okay, but hard to expect more unless it's from Mom ( I'm part Vietnamese and my mom makes pho from the motherland)
author: David L.

description:
Every so often I'm wrong. I know, i know, you're shocked. I was too. But there are, in life, those rare exceptions to the rules that you've fairly internalized. Sometimes you get a genuine Rolex from a guy on the street that was obtained legally. Occasionally your AT&T iPhone actually DOES get more bars more places than any of your other friends' smartphones. I'm sure at least once in recorded history, some billionaire from Malaysia needed assistance with a funky tax loophole and actually deposited money into some American's account, and let him keep 5% of it when the transaction was over. 

And, every once in a while, a stylish upscale Vietnamese restaurant in a non-Vietnamese neighborhood with non-Vietnamese staff actually serves awesome Vietnamese food. I seriously would've thought that my chances were better of getting the aforementioned $250,000 hookup from the dethroned prince of Terengganu.

My new yoga buddy recommended this place after last night's class, and I was quietly skeptical. My general experience of Vietnamese food is that the places that look like they're about to be shut down are the truly awesome places. Grungy fish tank in the corner, staff look harried and rushed, cash only, the register is covered in a hazy plastic sheath. THAT is usually where you strike culinary gold. Those are the places you can't wait to go back to.

Generally speaking, upscale Vietnamese is like a T.G.I.Fridays with a side of soy sauce. Lacking genuineness, and appreciation for authenticity, and just all kinds of Americanized. This place was NOT like that. The food was as authentic as I ever had, the flavor palate was spot-on, and the presentation was beautiful. It's Vietnamese food for your foodie snobs who require an upscale aesthetic. 

Just keep those friends of yours away from here, come to think of it. They bug me, and can go back to the Marina.
author: Sean B.

description:
I was here late one night with my wife after a long day in the City before heading back home to Sacramento. We were absolutely starving and this was one of the places still open late in the night. 

My wife is a huge pho lover so I was more than happy to shack up here and order something else. 

It's a pretty trendy looking place, typical of a bistro fusion style joint so I was taken aback to discover frog legs and quail on their appetiser menu. I ended up ordering both, so my wife could try both out and they were fantastic but took a little while to arrive. 

The pho was good if not my cup of tea after the hoisin sauce goes in. I didn't enjoy my tofu and vegetables pot. The sauce was both too salty and too sweet. It tasted like it had come out of a jar and was too unbearable for me to eat more than a few mouthfuls of.

I wouldn't hesitate to come back but would probably stick to a soup based dish. 

Thai iced tea and Vietnamese coffee were both good but I think the tea was better.
author: Therese L.

description:
Nice casual atmosphere with jolly servers. Modern with a bar; the place had the whole fusion vibe, so I didn't have high hope at first. The papaya salad was really fresh and came out quickly; the nuoc mam hit the right notes and got our appetite prepped nicely for the main dishes. I was surprised to see bun cha Ha Noi on the menu at such a place. It was good and much more authentic than I anticipated. The girlfriend ordered caramelized gulf prawn clay-pot served with rice. She wasn't too impressed saying it was a little underwhelming after papaya salad, but i thought it was nicely done and pleasant. 

Sitting is a little tight for 2-person table near the front. Thumbs-up to the Caucasian waitress for pronouncing bun cha Ha Noi pretty on point.
author: Minh V.

description:
Get the Hue Rolls, Craw fish claypot, and Pork Vermicelli. These are all 5 star dishes! 

Skip the pho though. I tried some of a friend's pho and it had a strange flavor to it. If this were the only dish I got, I'd probably give this place 2 stars. 

I like this place because I have never had to wait for a table. I do see a line sometimes, but it doesn't look that long and you can grab a drink at the bar while you wait. 

I like the overall vibe of the place, busy but not chaotic. It can get pretty loud though.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
The atmosphere is the familiar new American that everybody has seen before, hip wispy music, rustic wood accents, and upscale decor. However, don't let that and the fact that they serve japanese sake fool you, the food is definitely cooked by a Viet. The bun thit nuong was actually really impressive. 

The wait staff was nice and the prices were on par with most Viet places. Considering all that, I would definitely come back for a casual meal.
author: Patrick P.

description: The food is good, but every time we order delivery they give us one half of the garnishes for the Pho even though we order two bowls. Wished they'd pay attention to detail and give us what we order. So minus two stars for service and another for bad to go experience.
author: Drew T.

description:
Good vietnamese place!
Were there with our friends who come here often. We were introduced to this cooking style for the first time and it was delicious. Not sure I can remember the names but there were vietnamese crepes and good rolls with some bbq pork in it.

A bit disappointed the place was short on some items in their menu : Weird for the middle of the week. We couldn t enjoyed the pork clay pot tonight! :(

Also strange they would not seat us until our all party would have arrived...

Still a place to definitely come back! :)
author: Fabrice L.

description:
Mau offers pretty solid Vietnamese food in the Mission. It's not exactly authentic -- it's far too trendy and upscale for that. However, where else can you drink coconut milk out of a hollowed out coconut?

The pho is pretty solid as well -- they are certainly generous with both the meat and noodles. It's not as cilantro-heavy as some of the other joints out there, but I'm ok with that.
author: Casey S.

description: Holy cow. I've spent quite a few evenings walking up and down this street, knowing I can't go wrong if I just walk in somewhere but it's always impossible to actually PICK. When I stumbled into this amazing Pho restaurant, I expected to have some great food but I didn't expect to have the best pho I've ever tried! I had the Hu Tieu, and honestly didn't talk to the friends I was with for a solid 5 minutes because this combo was so great. The broth is incredible, the meat was fresh and tender, and the ground pork added this amazing flavor. Yes you can go for the more traditional phone and be perfectly happy (my friend had the pho bo and was extremely happy) but I have to recommend stepping outside your comfort zone and trying something different! This was also my waiter's favorite, which I think says something. And the price is very reasonable for the area, especially for how large the portions are. So go for it-get here early, the wait for a table is WORTH IT, and enjoy some incredible food.
author: Sophia B.

description: My girlfriend and I love Mau! If we're craving nice pho, this is the place for us. Tasty, quality food at reasonable prices for a dinner in the Mission. Only 4 stars because of inconsistent taste: sometimes it's the best pho I ever tasted, but sometimes it's simply good. Early, non-rush days seem best? Hue rolls, pho ga and hu tieu are our go-to orders. Bon appetit!
author: Justin B.

description: Honestly this place is trash. I wish i could give this place a zero. Me and my lovely date were just trying to have a nice dinner at this place thats been reccommended to me from friends, although the experience I had was awkward, unnecessary, overall a negative time. First of all the couple sitting next to us was just being incredibly rude fucking staring at me and my date. Mind you we have just been seated for about five minutes. Secondly the waiters were equally as rude, just were not attentive. Didn't look like they wanted to serve us. I seen it in their body language and it was all over their face. Me and my date done nothing wrong to have this treatment bestowed upon us, made us feel completely and utterly uncomfortable. This is San Francisco for christ sake so I dont know how this type of shit gets tolerated. I thought this place was better than that, however it wasn't. I really hope the management takes care of such sub par service.
author: Jazmyn R.

description:
I honestly thought they'd be a little more authentic than it was but was wrong.. and not non authentic in a modern/creative twist sort of way. Alllll of their soups are made in chicken broth.

Regardless I still wanted to try their bun rieu. Wasn't bad, but I wouldn't recommend it if you're really craving bun rieu. The broth was pretty thick in flavor but seemed to rely too much on pepper flavor. I did enjoy the richness of the tomato though. I think the fact that they chose not to have any crab meat  (usually made with a shrimp crab "meatball") was their downfall.

Bun Bo Hue was decent as well.. but also not recommended if that's the dish you're craving. It's definitely lighter in taste because of the chicken broth. Unfortunately we couldn't taste the lemongrass flavor at all. Could also be spicer but that's subjective. 

I think you could enjoy the soups if you keep in mind they don't really taste how they should. I guess they are "healthier" versions. 

I will say that we did enjoy the hue rolls. Pork was nice and crispy without being dry and and rice wrap was nice and creamy.  The mint and cilantro helped balance the roll out, would definitely order again.

I would come back to try some clay pot and noodle dishes but wouldn't come back for the soups except to try the pho ga maybe.
author: Melissa C.

description: Quick and easy place in the mission. Service was very good. Pho was good. Noodle bowl was good.
author: Zachary C.

description: Cool spot for lunch. As a newbee to Vietnamese cuisine, I was a little underwhelmed at the choices. My co-workers love the menu -- especially the vegetarians! Today, my choice was the Chicken Claypot. The meat was very flavorful and tender - if only there was more! Next time, I will ask for the brown rice. The spring rolls were fried a little too hard and took a long time to cool down, but the upside is they were freshly made. My co-workers ordered super big tofu soup bowls that were served with a nice assortment of garnishes. Will definitely have to visit in the evening, so I can cozy-up to the bar!
author: Tony B.

description: Good pho, but no better than the $6.50 bowl I'd get back home in Santa Clara. The inside decor and atmoshphere is nice, which I guess is what you're paying for.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Mau is a spunky place to eat. We had no problem getting a seat and the staff were very friendly and attentive.

The food looked great, and tasted pretty good, too. It wasn't the best bowl of pho I've ever had, but I would definitely give it another try.
author: Nick M.

description:
Ordered for pick up last night with my mom and decided to get two vermicelli bowls with beef and a spring roll. 

1. Vermicelli bowl was extremely overpriced for what it was. I've had vermicelli bowls at more authentic restaurants and this place didn't come close. It was mostly pickled veggies, three slices of meat and noodles. Due to mostly being pickled veggies the whole bowl was extremely pickled/ vinegary which made it hard to consume.

2. Shrimp spring rolls were the exact same as the vermicelli bowls but wrapped. I've never had a pickled spring roll and to make it worse, their peanut sauce wasn't even peanut flavor. It was an espresso flavor which was incredibly strong. 

The total was $45 for two vermicelli bowls and an order of spring rolls which I think is personally over priced. It wouldn't have been a problem if the food was actually good. 

Will not be coming back
author: Shannon M.

description: This is truly my favorite pho ever! It is my go to and I'm pretty sure I could eat here everyday:) The service is absolutely amazing and they know how to do tofu the right way! It's always a challenge to find awesome tofu and they just get it. My favorite dish is the tofu pho, it is everything! One time they ran out of the veggie broth and I was so sad but our server made an amazing recommendation, the lemon grass tofu noodle dish, and it was another winner! If you're happy, sad, cold, sick, just feeling a-ok, this is your place:)
author: Roxi P.

description: At first I thought this place was just a hipster pho wannabe kinda place but turns out the food is pretty good. The bun rieu and bun bo bue which are my go-to's when eating at a typical vietnamese resto tasted really clean and flavorful. By clean, I mean, no MSG (woohoo!). And the prices are very comparable to a vietnamese restaurant in the city. If I were to break it down: healthier, cleaner, same price = better!  You also have to try their home made hot sauce (infused with this lovely lemongrass flavor). It's not the one at the table. You have to ask for it. I actually bought a jar to take home with me. Not sure if they offer that anymore though.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Awesome, unique Vietnamese food in an upscale-looking place? Are you kidding me?!
