My date kept recommending the pho to me, and after tasting the broth, I wished I had enough room in my stomach to eat it. So fresh, with nary a hint of MSG. The other components looked absolutely fresh, from the noodles to the cuts of beef. Sure, it's a little pricy, but it IS SF. And it IS good after all...

But I'm still thinking about those "Hue Rolls"! It's obvious that what makes this roll special is the lemongrass pork, which was fried to perfection. I need more of these rolls in my life, seriously...
author: Viet N.

description: Go to Pho place -- consistently delicious, non fussy, service is friendly, lots to choose from.
author: Melissa W.

description: Went to mau with a friend after smelling their delicious food while walking down the street! The server was very friendly and informative, helping us with their unique menu. We decided on spring rolls to start, followed by bun ga xa (a chicken noodle bowl) and the shaken beef rice platter. We found the spring rolls very bland and probably wouldn't order them again. The chicken dish was good but also a bit plain. The shaken beef was out of this work delicious!! Plan to go back next time I'm in San Francisco just to have it again!
author: Elise B.

description: Lovely place, in the heart of mission - delicious pho! Im semi-new to the 'pho-world', but this is one of the best i've had. Large portions and reasonable prices. Beer and wine selection, cocktails too. Service is quick and friendly. Modern and clean atmosphere. #onelovephoreal
author: Cady S.

description:
Came here around 9pm on a Wednesday & it was packed! Didn't really mind the wait. The host and my waiter was friendly. The food took awhile to come. Waited almost 30 minutes for the spring rolls appetizer but it's understanding since it was a busy night. The food isn't bad but if you want to talk about authenticity of this restaurant, I will have to say it isn't authentic. The broth of the Bun Bo Hue tasted like the broth from Pho Do with spices thrown into it. 
Even with the peanut sauce, the Spring rolls tasted simple and bland in my opinion.
author: Joanne H.

description:
Love this place! I love pho, and while I'm not that adventurous when it comes to trying all they have to offer I am happy with the large selection of food I can still eat! First off everyone must try the garlic noodles they are absolutely delicious! 
The pho ga is my go to I like to add a mix of vegetables and tofu when I'm a bit more hungry! 
The cha gio and hue rolls are a great way to start your meal both very popular and tasty!
The atmosphere is very fun and happening, and it gets very busy on the weekends! My mouth is watering just writing this review! Too bad MAU is already closed, I'll be there tomorrow though!
author: Melody M.

description:
Vietnamese food hit the spot this evening at a spot I'd passed many times before, but not ever given a try.  We started with a plate of spring rolls and a papaya salad.  Not too sweet, just enough a spice, and plenty to share family style (like we always do).  

The salad had poached shrimp, calamari, thai basil, and just enough papaya to make the starter a fresh, not-too-filling dish.  The spring rolls were a bit heavy on the rice noodle filling---I would have preferred more veggies.  I'm also not a huge fan of peanut sauce, so this app wasn't my top pick.

My main course was the home run of the meal, hands down.  Bun Thang was a spicy noodle soup dish with chicken, shrimp, fried egg, pork sausage, and plenty of cilantro. It was meat-heavy and everything I wanted in a steaming bowl of rice noodles and broth.  

Delicious, and fun atmosphere in the heart of the mission.  I'd recommend for anyone seeking some Vietnamese noms in an exciting, trendy part of SF.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Hipster upscale Vietnamese food.

FROG LEGS (allow 20 min) grilled,  sh sauce/black pepper marinade, cucumber, salt-jalapeno dip - $12
- super meaty and larger than I expected. Juicy!!

BANANA BLOSSOM SALAD fried freshwater eel, banana blossoms, onions, fried garlic and shallots, peanuts - $11
- the eel bits were smaller than I expected. It tasted almost like Chinese salted sardines.

PHO BO rare niman ranch eye-of-round, brisket, rice noodles, beef broth - $9

BUN BO HUE beef shank, rare niman ranch eye-of-round, pork sausage, spicy lemongrass chicken broth - $10
Not that spicy, initially disappointing, but it did leave a nice little "after-burn" to my throat.
Overall I still preferred the regular Pho Bo more than the Bun Bo Hue.  The prices at this place are obviously going to be more than in the Tenderloin... (location location!!), and not as tasty, but it was still good for satisfying a craving.

Actually, the one thing I would come back for would be the frog legs.  (They're also much juicer and larger than the ones from Lers Ros.)
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Delivery through order ahead. Was about 50 mins. 

Good pho - nice light broth. Pretty generous amount of rare beef and brisket. Not as large as some hole in the wall pho. 

Good fried rolls - nice filling and good crispness. 

This is expensive Vietnamese but it's good.
author: Shanee B.

description: I liked the pho! This place was fancy enough where it felt like I was treating myself, but not so much where I didn't meet my craving for pho. Plus nice cocktails.
author: Rosy H.

description:
After a year and a half in San Francisco, I finally came to Mau for pho! The whether as always was a bit chilly and the rain had just stopped, the perfect combination for a bowel of hot, steamy soup. 

We ordered a Pho Bo and Shaken Beef; the pho was nice, and had just the right amount of meat and noodles. I wish it was a little hotter and saltier, but the soup was still delicious. 

Now the shaken beef was off the charts! The beef cubes were so tender, and the sauce with lemon juice mixed with ground pepper was a nice touch. I would get this again. 

The servers and staff were great and they let us dine even when the kitchen was going to close in a few minutes. They were courteous and helped us with the menu.
author: Zorayr K.

description:
I've never dined and dashed, but this place almost made me do it.  

Service is nonexistent. Had to ask for water after we got our drink order.  Had to flag down three people to not get condiments and walked up myself.  

We were at the door and ready to leave because after being acknowledged by the wait staff the bill still did not come.  I had to walk to the back and demanded my bill.  No apology, just a quick wave of the hand and head nod.  I'm never coming back here.  I get better service at a hole in the wall.

Food:

Crunchy rolls has good filling, but it was more soggy than crunchy.

Banh xeo was overly crunchy where pieces of it was sharp enough to cut the roof of my mouth.

Iced coffee tasted like watered down burnt coffee beans.

Best thing about the meal was the Dang butterscotch root beer because it wasn't made by them.

Ambiance:
Trying too hard to be hip and not a Vietnamese restaurant.

Seating too close.  It was annoying to have the waiters ass next to my face while trying to take the order of the table next to us.  

Techno music, odd film projected on the wall, and extremely loud atmosphere.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I have a confession to make. I think Vietnamese food is the greatest invention ever. Whether it's simple or complicated, one fact remains true, it's all about fresh quality ingredients. MAU delivers on that premise consistently. 

Garlic noodles, garlic bok choy and a shrimp or fish pot are all I need to live a happy life 2-3 nights a week.
author: Karen G.

description:
A very trendy Vietnamese gem! My family came here after a long flight, cranky and hungry. Although it was a little busy, the 10 minute wait was definitely worth the wait. All five of us were surprised with how good the food was especially my mom who is expecting fatty/cheaper cuts of meats. Their meat is quality and prepared perfectly. No sauce needed! Highly recommend this place to fulfil your cravings. 

P.s. the staff is cheerful even during busy times!
author: Kyle F.

description: It has been said that the quality of one's life can be directly correlated to their proximity to Mau. Ok, I said that. That was me. I love Mau intensely. Nadim and his team are infectiously pleasant and the food is bonkers. I love the hue rolls, all the pho, the turmeric catfish, the xiu mai, the wine and beer selection, and the wonderful company. I cannot be without Mau.
author: Julia A.

description:
How does this place have a higher than a 3 rating? interesting.

I flew into SFO on a rainy, chilly night. I felt the chills... and what's the best remedy? Pho! 
I was staying in Mission District - so went ahead and checked out Mau. 
The ambiance was pretty clean and cool. And of course, I went ahead and got my pho.

First off, there's no diversity in their pho. You only get ONE "option" haha
I am a broth girl. I believe that makes or breaks your pho. and boy oh boy, it tasted really weird. Very bland and sour. 

However, this is what they did right. They had alot of meat in their pho. pretty nice. (which got them the 2 stars). 

I am not sure if I'll be coming here again (at least not to try their pho). Other items on their menu looked nice. maybe next time....
author: Johanna S.

description: Environment was good.  My pho Ga order was testy and healthy.  Diverse group of patrons.  Not one of the places I would have thought of In the heart of Mission.
author: Chi H.

description:
This restaurant is the epitome of trendy, hipster Mission. If I really wanted Vietnamese food, I would go to the Tenderloin, but that's not to say this place is bad. I would still come here; after all, the Tenderestloin is not my favourite neighborhood after hours.

I came with two friends, and we were able to snag some bar tables up front pretty quickly, while others had to wait. I ordered the Bo Kho, which was a good. It came with an impressive amount of beef shank that I could not finish, so + 1 for Mau! It's not better than any other soup noodles that I've had anywhere else, though.

The main reason I wanted to write a review was to tell ya'll that if you can, you should download the app that Mau is promoting / using, called "Cover." You will get $10 off your meal!!! Every person at the table who downloads it will get $10 off. Then you can delete the app afterwards because that's what I did.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've been to Mau several times and this review is not about of the flavor or quality of the food.  this is a review for the service my wife and I received.  We walked in on 11/13/16 at 9:45pm knowing that they close at ten.  We knew what we wanted and it shouldn't have taken too long.  I'm a cook and she's a server so we understand that it sucks to have last minute customers.  We wouldn't have gone inside so late if there were not people eating.  There was still plenty of people talking and waiting on food.  We could see right away that the staff was frustrated and irritated that we walked in.  

Our server came by, Keric A, and gave us the menus and let us know that the kitchen will be closing.  I said we are ready to order.  

1 order of hue rolls
1 chicken pho
1 bun bo hue

I told Keric that I would like to substitute the chicken in the pho for lemongrass pork instead and he immediately said "uumm... no, we don't do that."  I told him that we were here last week and it wasn't a problem then.  "oh okay, the reason I say no is because the chefs always change the menu."  

what the hell does that have to do with anything?  I said I would like you to check for me because we substitute it all the time.  the chicken meat is not really good.  so he came back and said "the chefs were willing to do it this time but I can't serve you the pho anyway because we are out of chicken stock and we also don't have any more hue rolls...its been a long week."

again, wtf!  I don't give a shit about your week.  why didn't he know that he was out of hue rolls to begin with?  he didn't even offer spring rolls or any other substitute.  how do you run out of chicken stock?  I told him that's fine.  can I just get the stock that she's getting with the bun bo hue?  "well... that's a beef stock ..."  I told him that it reads chicken broth on the menu.  so I told him I'll take pho but with the spicy bun bo hue broth and lemongrass pork.  

we waited a short while and than he dropped of two bowls and walked away.  my wife called him back because she noticed that there wasn't any meat in my bowl.  she asked if I was getting the lemongrass pork and he said " oh... they didn't put it in there? I'm sorry... I guess they didn't make it.  let me check with the kitchen."  when he left I told my wife that the pork should be on the side and I'm surprised that he doesn't know anything about his menu.  I was actually upset because the noodles in my broth was the round noodles that come with bun bo hue.... I wanted the regular thin pho noodles.  at this point I was super upset and he came back with the lemongrass pork and he was excited to drop it off...." here it is!  they did make it for you."   was it really that fucking hard?  thanks for doing me such a big favor.  my wife started to tell him about the noodles but I just said forget it... its late... let just eat and get the hell out of here.  

I tipped him a big fat zero... I kept tell my wife that he must be new.  I hope he's new.  we haven't gone back since.
author: beach m.

description: Very hip atmosphere compared to most Vietnamese places. Food was great and prices were reasonable. Perfect place to stop by if you are galavanting around this part of the city.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Came here with the boyfriend last night and we were pleasantly surprised with the crowd on a Wednesday night.  We arrived around 6pm and there were quite a few tables open.  By the time we left around 7:15, all the tables were full and there was even a wait.

We started with the spring rolls which we both agreed were dry.  The steamed pork wasn't doing anyone any favors and there could have been more veggies to keep the rolls moist.  The peanut dipping sauce was quite good but we wouldn't order the spring rolls again.

I had the bun rieu while he had the bun bo hue.  The broth for the bun rieu was flavorful and sweet.  I did not try the broth in his soup but he said it was very good and spicy.  Overall both were very good, although I would've preferred more noodles in mine and less steamed pork patties.
author: Erica A.

description:
I've been here twice within the last month, the first time being better than the second. They do somethings well, but I think I prefer Thanh Tam II (right down the street) if you're looking at just getting pho.

Banh Xeo $10 - This was very tasty and had good crispiness to it. I wish they gave more mint & lettuce, but at least their fish sauce was on point.

Frog Legs $12 - I thought this dish was pretty mediocre and would probably recommend skipping this. The salt-jalapeno dip was pretty good, but overall the dish was too salty to keep dipping it.

Bun Rieu $10 - This bun rieu was good, but not great. I asked for some extra shrimp paste sauce on the side and made it a bit better to my taste. Not the best I've had, but still decent if you were craving bun rieu.

Bun Thit Nuong $10 - My friend got this and she couldn't finish it because it was huge, so I finished it for her. The lemongrass pork was great! Lots of flavor and the bowl had a good amount of vegetables to balance it all. 

Pho Bo $9 - I added tendon for an extra $1. It was quite pricey and really bland. The tendon was really small and almost non-existent. The bowl had a terrible noodle to meat ratio too... too much noodles. It may have been that they westernized this dish too much. I tried to ask for nuoc mam (cooking fish sauce) to salvage it, but they gave me the sweet & sour dipping one (nuoc mam cham) instead.

Service was definitely below average. I think they were understaffed both times or something. The first time I came was during lunch and there weren't many people around so there's no excuse. The second time was super packed during dinner and we sat outside. Our waitress barely came to check in on us.
author: Andy T.

description:
This place has really good Viet food! I got the BBQ lemongrass pork w/ egg roll & vermicelli noodles, which was delicious. My friend got some rice plate & that was also very yummy. The portions are good, filling but not bloating.

The ambiance of the restaurant is also very nice, with polite waiters.
author: Alice H.

description:
Some of my friends tell me that I should be a food critic one day because I'm overly opinionated, highly critical, and yada yada yada. I think it's just a nice way of them saying, "You're such a BIATCH."

I may be an overcritical biatch, but I'm an honest and detailed one. *Hmmph*

I will never be Michael Bauer nor do I aspire to be. I don't look like Matlock (which I envision anonymous Bauer to look like) and I don't listen to Mozart unless it's a trance version that I'm doing figure eights with a glow stick to (I haven't raved since 2003).

Credit given where is credit due with a side of sarcasm. That's all. =)

The newest addition to the ever growing foodie scene in The Mission is Mau, a Southeast Asian restaurant that opened last Wednesday. With 95% of the food being local and organic, former Slow Club's Chef Sante Salvoni focuses on Vietnamese and Thai cuisine with a California twist. No MSG is used.

Just like with most ethnic cuisine in The Mission, Mau was a mediocre hipster attempt at Southeast Asian cuisine. I wasn't expecting authentic cuisine rivaling the crackheadville Tenderloin but I expected more than uninspiring and uniformly bland dishes (where are the bold Asian spices?). I shouldn't have to douse everything with nuoc cham (Vietnamese dipping sauce) just to get some flavor.

F O O D
A very limited and unbalanced menu with just four appetizers, one vegan noodle dish, one rice dish, three soups, and two entrees, Mau seriously needs to beef up their menu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#m9cAGCRQqwNT_7VjZutDiQ). Why are the only two entrees on the menu both fish dishes?!?! 

*Grilled Pork Sausage ($8) - 3 Stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#Aw6kcEBDz0He4OzKkrJXpg
A rendition of the Vietnamese Cha Bo, the housemade sausage patties tasted more like slider patties. They lacked a rich fattiness and severely needed some herbs and spices (i.e. lemongrass).

*Pork Belly Bowl ($13) - 3 Stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#QEGjBP0-UEkAfS-kQLOicA
Several thin slices of pork belly thrown on a bed of rice with some garnishes? BORING. Don't get me wrong, the pork belly was tender with a nice fat to meat ratio but there was no braised fatty skin or crackling skin which is the highlight of Asian style pork belly. Perhaps an egg would have helped jazz up this otherwise lackluster dish.

*Fried Whole Thai Snapper ($26) - 3 Stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q
Normally covered in a tamarind or a sweet spicy sauce, this rendition of a whole Thai fish was as naked as a Playboy model with the exception of useless, excessively large garnishes. The snapper was beautifully presented and had a lovely crunchy exterior with a tender flaky interior flesh but it was SO bland.

*Bi-Rite Ice Cream ($9) - 3 Stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#mVy6XPix-vKdisHurZ6e1Q
This was the only other dessert other than sliced melon. If you're going to serve partially melted store bought vanilla and chocolate ice cream, please do more than sprinkle peanuts and toasted coconut on top for $9. Total cop out.

S E R V I C E
Pleasant and attentive but food service was slow. A 20 minute wait for an appetizer is almost unheard of for an Asian restaurant, a nearly empty one at that.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
A contemporary minimalist decor with wooden bleacher benches, large pumpkin colored hanging lamps, framed wall mirrors and an open kitchen. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_-7VgjSfibitQ1-TBvE0Aw?select=dA5FFN-pZRcEh46lcpkd9Q#YDp1tYvEP6TkYjFBnYItfQ  Seating area is fairly large (60+) with window seating and counter seating with a front-row view into the open kitchen.

P A R K I N G
Horrendous street parking. 

I may be an overcritical biatch but I'm also an empathetic one. Mau is in its infancy stage and definitely has potential IF they step up their game in the flavor AND creativity department so a generous 3 stars from me. 

In the end, what's going to make nearly 1 million San Franciscans want to go to a restaurant and keep on going back?

Sorry, you can't eat nice décor and service. If you could, I would be rich and skinny. *Sigh*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Let me first start off by saying I am Vietnamese and from San Jose, so my standards for Vietnamese food is pretty high. 

Sick with a cold, I was in the mood for pho. There are not many options in the Mission, and knowing that we were walking into a hip Americanized Vietnamese restaurant, my expectations weren't too high, but the food was better than I thought it was going to be. 

I ordered the beef pho ($9.50), which was just okay. The broth was saltier than I like, and overall a bit lacking in the traditional flavors. The noodles were also slightly over cooked. I was only given one tiny sprig of fresh Basil, and had to flag the bus boy down for some hoisin and sriracha. My husband got the papaya salad ($10) which was surprisingly tasty and came with some shrimp chips.

Even though it felt so very wrong to be spending over $7 for a bowl of pho, I feel that the food was decent for what it was - trendy, Americanized Vietnamese food. Service was pretty good. However, I probably would not come back if given a choice. There are too many other delicious eats to try in the Mission, and I prefer more authentic Vietnamese food.
author: Diana N.

description:
Date & Time:  Wednesday September 26, 2012 @ 6:30pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Guys in Business Attire & Girls in Moto Jackets over Tanks, Minis & Moccasin Booties
Music:  Jazz & Blues
Decor:  Urban Rustic.  Dim-Lighting, Bar Tables, Cozy Tables for Two & Banquette Bench Seating
Service:  Nice & Efficient
Devour:  Grilled Sausage & Pork Belly Rice Bowl
Skip:  Cucumber Salad & Halibut Pho
Total:  $55.38
author: Genevieve Y.

description: I love this place and eat here once or twice a week. The service is fantastic and the pho bo is delicious. When I want something more hearty, I get the shaken beef, also excellent!
author: Jake M.

description:
Was here for lunch with a couple of friends. Server was attentive. Food came quickly.

It's trendy alright. It's popular alright. Authentic and down to earth goodness that you'd get from real Vietnamese cooking? NOPE!

If you want trendy, if you want popular, if you want Vietnamese-fusion-with-whatever, come here. Otherwise, if you are looking for real Vietnamese food, go where the Vietnamese eat!
author: Mango M.

description: Been here twice for dinner and hands down the best item on the menu are the Hue Rolls. Absolutely delicious and unique. The Pork Clay Pot was very good too. The marinated hard boiled egg in there was a delectable surprise and the pork was so tender and flavorful. The Five Spice Quail was over fried and very dry. Also they were so TINY. The wing was about 1/2 an inch long! The frog legs were also over fried. Note to the fry chef: either turn down the heat of the oil or cook these items 1 min less. Overall a good experience. Thanks!
author: Mr S.

description:
PROS:

Generous portions, well prepared meats and slightly more refined takes on casual Vietnamese fare. 

CONS:

Service can be inattentive, low effort. I don't really care if my server is nice or polite, as long as it's reasonably timely. Our waitress was slow to the table, forgot to add the spring rolls to the noodle bowl, and took forever to come give us a check. It was a busy night, which is why I'm not really docking stars for it, but it was frustrating even for my high tolerance. 

Their wall art looks like when you were in kindergarten, and every class got to paint a different section. It's a definite eyesore.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Worst service ever! 

I understand waiting for full party to be seated, that's ok. We got seated, order taken, 30 mins....no food....40 mins still waiting for waiter to come back to give us update after asking hostess for status. The restaurant was packed around Sunday by 7:30p and more people waiting to be seated. 

Looking around maybe 2 tables seemed to have maybe just half their orders. Everyone else had nothing. After about 40 mins of starving and frustrated status, I went back to hostess and told her we can't wait anymore and are leaving because we were really hungry. Her response is what got me really upset. She just said, "ok perfect" I didn't even receive an apology or anything. 

Only the lady bartender provided great service.

Never going to attempt to try this whack place again.
author: Dee T.

description:
Great place for a good meal, reasonable price and nice setting. It can be really packed over the weekends but I believe is worth the wait. 
The Pho is great but the wings are to die for!!!
author: John F.

description:
My girlfriend and I met up with one of my very good friends from high school the other night. None of us have been in the Bay Area for very long, so we really didn't know how the waits were going to be in the Mission area. For those of you not from around here, if you don't have a reservation, expect about an hour wait on the weekends around dinner time.

ATMOSPHERE & SERVICE
The atmosphere is pretty lively. There's always a diverse crowd around. But the service here is pretty mediocre, which might be because it's just so dang busy, but our server came over three times: give us water, take our order, give us our check. I usually prefer our server not come by because I like to eat in peace, but when he doesn't come by to refill your water or check when we need something, I mind a little.

FOOD
I ordered the Hu Tieu, which features pho in a garlic chicken broth with poached chicken, xia-xiu pork, ground pork and one shrimp. I'm torn because the garlic chicken broth and the pho were really really good. But the chicken itself was way too tough, and surprisingly dry, despite it soaking in the broth. The xia-xiu pork is really good and makes up for the lack of moisture in the chicken. I could do for more shrimp though -- there's literally only one.

Tough meat might be a recurring theme with Mau's pho. My friend couldn't finish her bowl of Pho Bo, and so I got a chance to try that as well. Her eye-round and brisket were also pretty tough -- though not as much as chicken.

OVERALL
It's a bit expensive for mediocre modern Vietnamese food. I'd eat there again for sure, but if I have to wait that long to eat there, forget about it.
author: Zi-on C.

description:
Food was a 3 but staff were great so I added a star. 

Went with some friends to this place, it was really crowded so we assumed it would be good. I Ordered veggie spring rolls and vegetarian pho. The spring rolls were pretty good, around a 4. 

The veggie pho came in some weird broth which tasted like apple and cabbage juice with soy sauce. I tried eating it but couldn't make myself swallow. The wait staff were very nice about it and let me send it back. I asked them to just bring me all the stuff that goes in the veggie pho without the broth - I just flavored it with sauces and ate since I was starving. I have eaten veggie pho at at least 25 different places and never experience such a weird tasting hipster twist on the dish. 

My friends who ate the chicken pho said it tasted  pretty good. 

I like the staff a lot, the atmosphere is also nice but would only recommend this place if they updated the recipes.
author: Serina J.

description: Mau was legit authentic Pho. My boyfriend and I were arguing whether this restaurant is fusion or not because he feels that the food here is authentic. However, I feel that it's fusion because of the ambiance and the different tweaks they put into their menu items. I will definitely be coming back here for pho and noodle dishes, both very full of good flavors
author: Tracey K.

description:
Food and ambiance is an area where they aren't lacking quality at by any means. 

I've been here a couple of times gotten the bun bo hue (highly recommended) quality at one off my favorite spots in the city. 

But needs a lot more organization on how they have their servers are placed. It's a lot of repeating of asking for simple things such as water when it's clearly empty, and basic necessities .

Mainly the reason I've chose to write this review I felt really disrespect on how this server treated my girlfriend and I with slamming the water down, forgetting items and being just outright rude. 

Working In the restaurant industry I would never ever treat a customer they way I felt. I'm having mixed feelings on returning after the way I was treated on his 4th time going now. 


Hope things change for MAU because they have amazing food, ambiance, and location is super prime.
author: James G.

description: Awesome place. Yummy food. I ordered the spring rolls, forgot which ones but they were pretty good. Tried the sake cocktail with cucumber, cilantro,lime.. didn't care for it. It wasn't bad, just not for me. But the beef pho was so tasty. Like I ate the whole bowl . The beef was tender and they weren't stingy with it..yesss! The broth was perfect,piping hot and the noodles were on point. The service is a bit slow, tables are very closed in.. But the quality of food makes it all worth it.(Smiling and rubs belly)
author: Toni L.

description: Some of the dishes are very authentic. I craved for braised fish in claypot so I ordered Claypot Catfish. The dish comes really like what I had at home in Vietnam. Thumbs up. I was a little concerned when I stepped into the restaurant as the look and ambience is not typical for a Vietnamese restaurant. I was wrong :)
author: Vy T.

description:
Haha. Are you people joking? 

First of all, trendy over priced Southeastern Asian food is one thing, but to have bad and incredibly slow service on top of that? Ouch.

My company eats here often, probably because its cute and seems clean. Unfortunately, I don't eat pho or noodle bowls for the cleanliness nor for the cuteness.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
I came in early on a rainy day, so didn't have to wait at all for a table.  Mau is pretty good, but not great.  Expensive for Vietnamese food.  If I'm hankering for Vietnamese food but am feeling lazy about leaving the neighborhood, I'd come here, but I wouldn't wait more than 20 minutes for a table.  If I'm seeking out good Vietnamese food without breaking the bank, I'll make the trek to the Tenderloin.

Cha gio (eggrolls) -- A+ -- On point, perfect amount of crispness & chewiness.
Nuoc cham (fish sauce-based dipping sauce) -- B -- Too diluted for my taste, but I get that they're catering to the majority audience here.
Cuon Hue (Hue rolls) -- B+ -- Meat was a bit dry, but was otherwise solid.
Bun bo Hue -- C- -- Not very spicy and tasted like they just added some chili flakes to a pho broth.
Bo luc lac -- B -- Good flavor, small portion for the price.
Uncle Ho cocktail -- C+ -- This was pretty good, but for being a sake cocktail, the sip-sized portion left me wanting more, particularly for the double-digit price.  I am okay paying that much for a real cocktail like a Manhattan, but for something to be mostly coffee and ice, with just a bit of sake, the price seemed a bit much.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
The ambiance is nice, very clean and modern.
But way out of Authentic Vietnamese food.
We had spring rolls, papaya salad, and five spice chicken. Totally average, more like Panda Express Vietnamese version.
Price is good but never again.
author: Anna S.

description:
Bumped up from 2.5 stars.

The food is definitely tasty and fresh, but I can't justify the price. I guess it's about right for the area, and people are willing to pay it, so why change anything?

Service is friendly but slow. It looked like they maybe only had two servers and there was a full house. Bus boys are very friendly and attentive, though, but a lot of things are out of their jurisdiction. 

I think the long wait here can be attributed to how long it takes for food to leave the kitchen. We got our appetizers very quickly, but I think we waited at least 30-45 minutes after that for our food. There's no way a few bowls of noodle soup should take that long to come out. They also forgot to bring our drinks to us so we had to ask for them. 

I think I heard Gordon Ramsey yelling in the kitchen.
author: Sara K.

description:
Love Mau! 
It has become a dependable go to for us. I'm Vietnamese myself so I feel I can sometimes be a little tough when reviewing authentic dishes. Yes the decor and overall ambiance is more Americanized, and no it's not as cheap as the other hole in the wall places you can find throughout the city. But it's conveniently located and most importantly- the food is up to par with my authentic Vietnamese taste buds.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Ok so, the people here are super nice. They definitely deserve points for excellent customer service. Also they're open relatively late which is convenient.
I gotta compare it to other pho places unfortunately.

One, this place is fairly pricey, maybe around twice what you'd pay for pho outside of the city. I get it tho, rent is RIDICULOUS. $11 for bun bo hue, $8 for their spring rolls.

Two, they're stingy on the noodles, but the broth and meat is pretty tasty and I wasn't wanting.

Three, I'm not sure if this is a thing and I'm just pho ignorant, but they were passing out lettuce instead of cilantro, lime, and basil...what's that all about?? I saw one guy ask for more lettuce and couldn't help wondering what that possibly did for the flavor.

Anyway it's decent late night food overall, just not if you're on a budget.
author: Jenny G.

description:
I eat here at least once a week...LOVE the veggie pho the hue rolls and five spice chicken. 
Decent prices for the Mission.
author: Shannon P.

description:
Food was a tad bit too salty. Good and flavorful though!

Wait-time on a Friday night? 5-10mins. On-point... Then again, we did walk in a few minutes before closing. Still very accommodating.
author: Angela Camille D.

description:
Service was fast, came in a bit after 12pm on a Tuesday. It got super busy at 1pm. 
Had the shrimp and pork spring rolls and PHO BO with steamed veggies. 

So delicious and def would come here again!!

Good music, great atmosphere and decor.
author: farah b.

description: This place is the sh-t. It's probably the cleanest vietnamese place with quality food you'll ever go to. Great ambiance and interior design. Got the pho here and it was unphogetable. Pretty big portions that'll encourage you to overeat! Our waitress was a bit awkward but still nice and attentive.
author: Juliana P.

description: Mau is da bomb. Vietnamese with that San Francisco kick that always produces interesting and delicious restaurants. Everything is really tasty and high quality. Favorites are the shaken beef, catfish claypot, hue rolls, lotus salad, and their pho is the only bowl of pho i actually dig. Its spicy and flavorful. Pretty easy to grab a table compared to the rest of Valencia street restaurants. Highly recommend.
author: Daniel P.

description: Bad service. Waited over an hour due to a random party having the ability to make a reservation for a party of 12 which pushed back everyone to wait even longer! I do not know who the assistant manager is or how much that party paid but definitely doesn't look good for the restaurant as they say they don't do reservations.
author: Justin T.

description: Amazing food, reasonable prices, and friendly staff.  Expect a line,  as it is crowded until 9pm.
author: Guilhem F.

description:
Absurd place that caters to hipsters who don't know any better. The chicken was too tough, the tofu was grilled to the point of beyond dryness, the sauce accompanying the bun (cold rice noodle dish) had minimal flavor, the food wasn't spicy enough, soggy Romaine lettuce (?!) was used as part of the accompanying ensemble of vegetables... Just really not good. Especially when there are / should be other good places to eat around. And yes, pricey ($11 for pho? $8 for banh mi?) for what you get.

Also you can't get options for tripe, tendon, etc.

The screen in the back onto which was projected an artsy (or Hollywood classic, not sure which) black and white film doesn't improve the food.
author: Hubert H.

description:
Upscale Vietnamese food in the Mission.
Had the spring rolls.  The rice noodle wrap was too soft but the rest of the ingredients tasted fresh.

The pho bo was pretty flavorful.  The broth was good but there were diced celery pieces in there which was different from what I was used to. 

The bun bo hue was also flavorful. (pork tenderloin, beef shank, spicy lemongrass chicken broth) could've been a tad spicier.  There's no pork blood in this one. Instead there's thin slices of beef like the one you get in pho. 

The salted sparkling lemonade was way too salty.  Tasted more like salt water with a splash of lemon and carbonation.
author: Heejin L.

description: Excellent Pho broth, savory and soothing, perfect balance of noodles and beef. I've always found the service quick and friendly, without feeling rushed or overcrowded like many other restaurants on Valencia these days.
author: Nick K.

description:
Spring rolls were disappointing - mostly vermicelli and lettuce, skimping on pork and shrimp = not much flavor.
Hue roll was amazing and much better.

Best rolls I've had is still Dakao in SJ.
author: Matt W.

description:
Randomly ran into this Pho place late at night, did not expect much as it's not like a traditional pho place, modern decoration, nice bar area. But it came out surprising good! 

I love the soup, and the beef brisket is very tender and their spicy source is amazing! Will definitely come again.
author: Jya Y.

description: Nice large restaurant with good food.  Had the Bun Cha Ha Noi, which is pork belly and sausage with herbs and vermicelli.  It was a little awkward to eat as you have to make your own "lettuce rolls," but the flavors were great, and it was a decent amount of food.  For $12, it was a pretty good deal - I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Simon L.

description:
Great Asian restaurant addition in the mission. Very casual, high turnover. A bit on the louder side, but the food is excellent for its value.

My favorites:
FISH CLAYPOT (garlic, shallots, scallions, chili, caramel fish sauce) -- super tender fish, great flavoring with slight spiciness, and the fish sauce is not overwhelming. Great with jasmine rice.

FIVE-SPICE QUAIL (two steamed and crispy-fried quails, house marinade, watercress, house vinaigrette) -- this dish was quite large for an appetizer. The batter is light, not greasy. The house vinaigrette was perfect to act as an astringent to the fried quail. Moist and tender quail meat obviously sourced from a good producer.

Solid dishes:
LOTUS ROOT SALAD (pig ear, shrimp, lotus root, carrots, celery, red bell pepper, onion, rau ram, mint, peanuts) -- this one is on the 7x7 list. I liked it and thought that it was quite unusual. But in general, I like lotus roots that are more cooked. it would be great to try this with crispy pig ears and cooked lotus roots. I didn't love the lotus root - carrot combination.

mediocre ones:
SHAKEN BEEF (cubed tenderloin, house marinade, bell peppers,watercress salad, salt-pepper-lime): tenderloin cubes that are more on the chewy side. I think i would like it if it were cut a bit thinner.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I've eaten here at least 20 times since my last review so it's time for an update! Overall still one of my fave spots for Vietnamese food. Some of their yummiest dishes are

- bun thit nuong cha gio
- bun rieu
- pho bo
- bun bo hue
- hu tieu (my current obsession)

I removed one star because realistically there is room for improvement. The vermicelli noodles are usually overcooked every time. When I take home leftovers and microwave them, they become so soggy that it's inedible. I've also had dishes I'd recommend skipping like the hue rolls, bun thit bo xao, and shaken beef. Service is also slow and could be better.
author: Veronica T.

description: Messed up my order and didn't offer a refund or to make it right. Would not recommend this place,  there are plenty of other choices for Vietnamese food.
author: Tammy N.

description: Food is OK but service was terrible. So slow & we had to ask for things multiple times. Service hasn't always been this bad on prior visits so maybe it was an off day? But we felt very neglected.
author: Aurora C.

description:
Mau has become my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city. I come here about once a week. It's basically my go-to when I can't decide what to eat in the neighborhood and don't want to spend a fortune. The only small downside is that there is sometimes a small wait during regular dinner hours. Guess I'm not the only one who is a fan.

The decor is hip and the flavors are rich. At first glance, it may seem like an Americanized hipster joint, but the food here is fresh and authentic. My Vietnamese boyfriend can attest to this.

What's amazing here:
1. Hue Rolls - Fresh + flavorful dipping sauce 
2. Bo Kho - Beef stew. Get it with the french bread! 
3. Five spice chicken vermicelli - Oh man that chicken is tender!
4. Bun Cha Ha Noi - An alternative to the usual grilled pork vermicelli. If you love fish sauce, you'll love this dish. I've actually tried Bun Cha Ha Noi in Hanoi, Vietnam and it's better here!!!

Pro tip : Dip everything in the homemade lemongrass chili sauce that they have at each table. So good that I bought a jar to bring home for $8.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Note: I am part Vietnamese and grew up eating all kinds of fish sauce and stinky shrimp paste, so am in search of tasty, more authentic Vietnamese.

Overall, I'd go back, for a satisfying way to eat Vietnamese food with higher quality ingredients, less MSG, and as a place to intro non-Vietnamese people to Vietnamese food. Sort of like a more casual, hipster way to introduce Vietnamese food instead of fancy Vietnamese like Slanted Door.

- Hue rolls: good quantity of well-seasoned, grilled pork. Rice roll wrapper (like a banh cuon wrapper). Left a bit of grease on the lips though.
- Bun rieu: at first the soup came out a little ketchup-y tasting, due to the large amount of tomato overpowering the seafood of the broth. But after adding some lime and requesting more mum ruoc, the soup got the requisite level of seafood-y ness. Crab/tomalley was OK, served in meat-ball type form. 
- Bun bo hue: tasty, but same as above - tasted better after some lime and shrimp paste. HUGE slices of meat in the soup. 
- Ate at the bar - bartender/server was really nice, was refreshing to eat Vietnamese food adn get decent, friendly service. 
- Next time - want to try some of their cocktails, look very tasty! 
- Packed on a Monday night at 7pm. Lots of folks doing take-out too.
author: Annie M.

description: Love this place and have been many times w/ my husband and our toddler. They are very friendly, accommodating, the food is yummy and prices not too high. Good vibe there an nice staff. It's a regular for us. Gets busy so we try to eat on the 5:30/6 side.
author: Ms X.

description:
For lunch today, I have been looking at Yelp trying to decide what to eat ..... looking through yelp, I found this place has a pretty good rating so I thought we should give it a try and it turned out more than we expected.  The place is clean, modern and nice.  We were skeptical when we walked into an Asian restaurant that is served by non-asian people.  So, we are not sure if the food are authentic.  Anywho, we got there around 2:50 and found out the kitchen close at 3pm.  So, we immediately put in our orders.  

     Canh Ga Chien (Chicken wings) for appetizers
     Bung Thang
     Hu Tieu Kho
     Vietnamese Banana Cake
     Iced Artichoke Tea

Everything is tasty except for the tea, which I can go without.  While we were eating and the kitchen was closed, the kitchen staffs came out and have their lunch.  To our delight, all of them are Vietnamese - no wonder the food was so good and authentic.

The service?  The waiter we had was really courteous and nice.  He made us feel relax and enjoy our meal even though the place is already closed for break between lunch and dinner.  

If and when I am in the city and craving for Vietnamese food, I will definitely come here and try other dishes.
author: MyMy T.

description:
Good bartender very nice and attentive.

The chicken pho is very good one of the best I've had

My only complaint is the music is all over the place but mostly sad and depressing I think they season the pho with tears
author: Luis R.

description:
Mau was great overall, courteous wait staff, prompt service and attention, and good food that tasted very fresh. 

The atmosphere and noise level were great. I love dining in a lively place. 

I ordered a Bun Bo Hue pho and spring rolls. I'm a huge pho fan, a phonatic if you will. And there's was delicious brothy goodness. While far from life changing pho I've had in DC and elsewhere, it was very good. I really wish Mau had more extensive pho options available. 

Now back to the Bun Bo Hue. The spicy broth was great going down, but an absolute terror coming out. For real. Avoid this dish if you hold your bowels at all dear to your heart. 

The spring rolls couldn't have been more bland if they were made in Kansas. Yes, I could taste the fresh mint, but it lacked umami. The accompanying peanut sauce was also devoid of any perceptible flavor. 

I'll try Mau again and know to order something different.
author: Justin S.

description: Stopped by this place after a visit to Clarion Alley. Had some cocktails, cahn ga chien aka  some chicken wangs (the sauce was bomb dig), and chicken pho. The Jalapeño lemonade paired well with the chicken and the Hemingway didn't disappoint!!!Not bad overall, server was funny...AND life was good that day!
author: Dee R.

description: Tasty pho and iced coffee. Hue Rolls are a must. Got to try the banh mi next time. Service was efficient and attentive as well. Loved that they split the pho dish in the back for us too.
author: Yum Y.

description:
I go here too much- which is a great thing

Everything on the menu is awesome. A key recommendation for your meal- Hue rolls

Spice lovers out there- Mau has an amazing lemongrass, garlic, fried chili...chili sauce that is takes everything on their menu to the fifth dimension

Do yourself a favor and check this place out. Fun atomosphere and friendly staff; a good option for large, small parties or even dinner for 1. The bar is nice with a cool drink menu too
author: Josh C.

description:
My husband and I came here on a Sunday night around 7:30 pm right before the rush of people hit, perfect timing. We decided to sit at the bar which was a great choice. The guy working the bar was super nice and inviting. We asked him for a suggestion and he said to keep it simple and go with the Pho Bo, and so I did. Our food took a while to get cooked, as it was pretty busy so the bartender/waiter came over and apologized for the long wait and gave us each a free sake shot because we had been waiting for a while. We didn't mind the wait as we weren't in a hurry so his kindness was very much appreciated.

Both of the phos we got were very delicious. They were flavorful but not too overpowering. They also gave you a side of some sprouts, sauces, lime etc. to use at your own convenience which was nice if you wanted to add a little extra spice to your dish.

The décor was great and the place was really clean. I am a fan!
author: Courtney D.

description:
Modernized Vietnamese Food is the best way for me to describe their food. I've always been a fan of vietnamese food; for the value and the taste. Mau didn't disappoint during my last visit. 

Bun Thit Nuong is usually my order of choice whenever I go to a Vietnamese restaurant. Vermicelli with greens, carrots, cucumber topped by BBQ meats and sprinkled with peanuts - perfection. 

Looking closely to what Mau's take on this is, theres a couple of things i didn't like. The meat was a generous serving, and I mean ALOT! over a little amount of noodles. I also didn't like that the carrots were raw, well it should be raw, but they were cut in huge awkward circles that made it hard to eat.

Decor was quaint and would attract people that may seem to be picky and wouldn't alienate people too.
author: Jan R.

description: If you love Pho like I do, then this is a great place to find it. Due to Mau's popularity it can get quite busy, but on less hectic days, you can sit at the bar and order a steaming bowl of Pho. Since I live in the Mission district, I am thankful that I have a Vietnamese place just around the corner from my house. This is definitely a good place for a casual night out with friends and a desire for something warm in the belly.
author: Leah C.

description: I've been here a few times and only had good experiences at this place. Big fan of the fish clay pot, which is what I mostly ordered, but other dishes were good as well.
author: Aleksey ..

description:
We came here a couple of times when they first opened and we weren't overwhelmed. I'm not sure what's changed since then but they've made notable improvements and it's become my go to place for a pho hankering. It's generally pretty full but it's not too difficult to get seating and it's in a great location in the heart of the Valencia strip. 

What the place may lack in authenticity, it makes up for with quality meats and ingredients.  The Pho Bo (steak) was excellent. Great broth, good noodles and good salads (papaya in particular).
author: Baron C.

description:
Really really tasty.

Upscale Vietnamese, a bit more expensive than your true authentic Vietnamese meal but selections were difficult to choose from and all was delicious.

Went with 5 others and we all shared. Loved my bun, pho was raved over, and spring rolls nice and fresh. One friend did not like her crunchy noodles (although I was willing to eat them!)
author: Sarah G.

description:
Place is typical of the Mission, hipsterized monetized ethnic food with poor service and nice decor. We really wanted to try this place but we were seated at a table with no waiter. We even asked our bus boy for the waiter and he looked surprised. 

I noticed the diners around us at the tables that are way too close together were also still looking at menus or looking listless without food. When our waiter finally came by 20 minutes after being seated he looked like he had just clocked in for his shift and had just barely finished tying up his apron.

He actually asked us, "Have you had a chance to look at the menu?" 

That was our cue to give each other looks and make our exit.
author: Czarina B.

description:
This place is a completely average pho joint.

I got the chicken pho with vegetables and it was ok. Nothing super great about this place other then the fact that it's by my house. Service was ok too.
author: Diva H.

description:
I guess there comes a time when you admittedly, finally realize that what was one good and a go-to favorite is no more, no longer even should be in the discussion.

Last night, after hesitantly heading to my once favorite Mission Vietnamese spot. I should have followed my instinct.

To cut a long story short and get directly to the point; the service was lacking, I must have been overlooked as I ordered the same time as the gent, who occupied a bar chair one spot to my right, but did not get my food up until he was done with his.

The food verdict and final tally: The Spring Rolls were sooo bland and tasteless; it was never like that when Mau first opened. The only thing that had flavor, albeit subdued, was the peanut dipping sauce. The Bo Kho or Braised shank, brisket, carrots, basil, spicy beef broth, with egg noodles were so underdone and chewy that I pointed it out and turned it back for all gristle, minimal meat. It was almost like chewing on bad mutton. And I don't even like mutton.

Just my advise, if Mau decides to remain there and survive the great plethora of choices in the Mission and the Valencia street corridor. Trendy and Hipster can only take you skin deep. It's gotta be back about the food, as it once was. Good luck.
author: John M.

description:
Decent restaurant, nice ambiance, and not too pricey in a city that's overpriced.

FOOD- Pretty good. Doesn't blow my mind, has good vegetarian options. I usually get the Catfish clay pot. Although the serving is on the smaller side, it's pretty good and not too spicy. My friend likes to get the Lemongrass tofu over rice, she says it's very yummy and a great veg dish.

SERVICE- Simple and straight to the point, seems the staff gets spread a little thin sometimes.

AMBIANCE - Visually minimalist and appealing, though it's a pretty cramped space. Tables tend to be very close. It gets incredibly loud in there at busiest times so it can be hard to even hear what the person you're dining with is saying.

Overall, it's a pretty decent place to eat and has reasonable pricing. If you live in the neighborhood, you should stop by.
author: Marie O.

description:
Great food for a simple Mission area restaurant.
Almost always packed and noisy.
They close at mid-day - so don't try to go away from the typical noon or dinner times.
I love the Viet Coffee as well as the rolls - but the Pho is apprently quite good as well.
author: Pat D.

description: Food and Service both are great and portions are also right sized. Will surely go back again for a cosy meal.
author: Owen C.

description:
Eating over thumping techno music gives me indigestion. 

At least, I'd like to think it was the music. Cuz the food was delicious. Rich and heavy and lots of it. A good place to go if you don't want to talk to the people you're with, which was not the case for a bunch of high school friends catching up for the first time in months. But definitely good for a SF night in the low 40s when you wonder why you left all your thick wool sweaters back on the East Coast. 

The soups are dense and delicious, and we struggled to decide what to order. For apps we split the Cha Gio - fried rolls with pork, shrimp, jicama, taro, mushrooms & noodles - and a mango salad. Decent, not mind-blowing. We all agreed on "Noodles with Broth," an entire section of the menu devoted solely to soup. I wavered between the Pho Bo (thinly sliced beef with rice noodles in beef broth) & Bo Kho (brisket & carrots with egg noodles in spicy beef broth) - the latter was described more as a beef stew, the former as a clear-brothed soup, so I went with the Pho. I downed nearly the entire bowl, and it was huge. Despite the fact that I ingested a ton of fluid, it was so salty that I needed 3 cups of water afterwards. Nevertheless, it sucked the cold out of my bones. 

Kill the music and improve the service (who do you have to pay to get a waiter over here?) & I'll return for a second round.
author: Ray J.

description:
I had a cold yesterday so decided to take out some pho and an order of cha gio thinking it would make me feel better. The pho tasted different than usual but I didn't think much of it. However, after I was done eating I got a really bad upset stomach which has continued up until this morning as I am writing this. I used to absolutely love Mau but the last few times have been increasingly disappointing since the quality of food has been declining. And the incident yesterday was the last straw. Needless to say, my love affair with Mau is now completely over.

I'm breaking up with you, Mau! It's not me, it's you!
author: Namrata S.

description:
I got the pho bo and Hue roll. Hue roll was delicious and a new Vietnamese style dish I have ever tried before - my go-to is generally spring rolls but they insisted to give this a shot. Pho had broth exploding in flavor and good proportions of meat and noodles. Although I prefer only regular steak in my pho, the brisket was pretty good. I agree with some of the reviews that it's a bit pricey for Vietnamese food, but there is more to the restaurant than just the food. Fairly trendy layout and seems very clean, service was very friendly, and great selection of alcohol/cocktails. 

Also, try out their specialized chili flakes if you like spicy food.

4.5/5
author: Or R.

description:
Disclaimer: I come here 2 or 3 times a week. 

For appetizers, the Hue Rolls and mussels should be on your to-do list.

For a great time, just sit down. The waiters and waitresses are all charming, smile inducing, and happy to consult you in choosing a dish. The atmosphere is to the decor as the Pho Bo broth is to die for.

Mau down!
author: Wesley K.

description: Like other reviews have mentioned, food is good but service is hit or miss. You're definitely paying for the extra cost of being in the mission and in a "hip" area. My Vietnamese coffee was $4 and was very small.
author: Lily C.

description: I was bar hopping and saw a sign for $2 soju shots. So that's why we went inside. However, once in, all the food smelled really good and it looked like a lot of people got their pho. However this review is for the $2 soju shots. They came in a shot glass that is a pretty substantial size and they offered water to us as well. Service was speedy and friendly and it was a good and quick 5 minute experience inside Mau.
author: Anna Z.

description: I came here after leaving work early because I had a cold.  I had heard a lot of good things about this place.  I had the vermicelli bowl with chicken and the vegetarian gio rolls added on. Unfortunately, most  of the other dishes have pork in them which I don't consume , but I enjoyed my meal and the staff were very kind.
author: Arman J.

description:
Absolutely love the food here, no question about it. This low star rating is because of the service today. The way they sit people when you arrive is messy.
Mau, either have a list in which you add your name as soon as you arrive, available to everyone or have someone fully dedicated welcoming by the door that writes people down. Since the lady sitting and welcoming guests is doing both, she does not know who arrived first, creating uncomfortable situations among guests that should not happen.
author: Marta B.

description: Lovely little restaurant.   We got there around 9pm on a rainy Saturday night & were able to get a table right away. Food was great-- will definitely be back!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I got a Chicken Pho this past Sunday while trying with my friend whom has been there several times. Chicken Pho was hella good the only reason gave 4 stars is they only provide Siracha in a tiny container, wish they would just give you the actual bottle so can I unload on my Pho with some deliciousness. Otherwise this place is awesome and the wait staff are super friendly. 

Definitely will come back here again to Pho it up :)
author: Arno G.

description:
The food was adequate, but the service was terrible. My friends and I went here on a Thursday night and were seated immediately--the place didn't seem too packed. From what I remember, it took a bit of time for the waiter to take our order, and once we did, we waited around 45 minutes for our food to come out. The waiter didn't really check on us while we were waiting either. 

Once the food came out, we were all so hungry, and everything tasted good. I just wish we had a better server, but maybe the restaurant is understaffed and he was busy.

Side note: My non-Vietnamese server also tried to correct me on the pronunciation on Bun Bo Hue. What??? I'm Vietnamese...I know how to say it! lol
author: Lana D.

description:
Excellent service and food.  I came for lunch at 1:00 and it was full of happy people eating away.

I had the Pho Ga (chicken ) Pho.  Wonderful flavor with FRESH ingredients! !

I will difinetly come back for dinner and try the other dishes.
author: Manny R.

description:
Tasty food, including the delicious spring rolls and catfish noodles. We also enjoyed the $6 Sapporo + shot of sake deal. 

The service was on the slow side but we'd definitely go back again.
author: Reese A.

description:
Absolutely terrible service. Once we were seated around 2pm we waited 15 minutes before anyone acknowledged us to take our order. After taking food and drink orders, my sisters drink arrived within 5 minutes. After waiting another 20, our food arrived and I was still without my drink. It took me 5 more minutes to wave our waitress down who told me they were out of the drink I wanted...why did it take so long to tell me that? Didn't even bother to ask if I wanted something else.

Other people were seated, served, and given their checks before we had even gotten our food. 

Really wish I could've given this place a better review because the food was good, but I experienced some of the worst service I ever have in my life. Disappointing experience here and will not be back.
author: Sarah W.

description:
The seafood is expensive but they cook the shrimp so well on the grill that I can still recall the flavors. The veggie banh mi is a good deal for lunch and has incredible umami flavor with the mushrooms and homemade chili/garlic sauces.

They could use more vegetarian or affordable seafood options.
author: Matthew G.

description:
Though "new" to the Valencia corridor Mau has been here I guess for  two years. I ride my bike past the place every day on my way home from work but there are so many new restaurants in the area I stopped keeping track. Even the ones with awesome word of mouth can take me ages to motivate to try - probably because it's in my neighborhood so I figure it's always there, plus it's always so crowded.

I kinda assumed that any ethnic food along Valencia St was bound to be westernized - nothing unique and high prices - so I haven't been exploring those restaurants as much. And the ones I've tried haven't been impressive. However, 7x7's Big Eat 2014 had so many on the list I was like, alright, let's give it another try. 

Starting with the Mau and their lotus root salad ($11 - pig ear, shrimp, lotus root, carrots, celery, red bell pepper, onion, rau ram, mint, peanuts). The pig ear was the first sign that this may be interesting (in a good way). The lotus root salad should probably be called the pig ear salad because that's the predominant ingredient/texture. Lotus Root Salad probably sounds better. I also noticed that they have a freshwater eel salad - another good sign since both are yummy foods in Chinese cuisine that most people who didn't grow up with would squeal and wrinkle their noses at. Not that "exotic" ingredients are a sign of authenticity but because they aren't exotic at all in this cuisine and it's cool they have stuff my parents would love to eat instead of just chicken, beef and pork. Also, special of the day - grilled frog legs?

On a rainy Friday @ 1 pm it wasn't very crowded but I already planned on getting takeaway.
 
 *** Tip #1: order takeaway at the bar

 *** Tip #2: the lotus root salad is a pretty wet salad, best for eating in or if you take it to go, eat it very soon or maybe ask for a plastic container instead of waxed cardboard

I took the salad with me to run some errands and half an hour later at home I found it had soaked through the bottom of the waxed cardboard container but thankfully not through the paper bag. The salad was a nice balance of sweet, salty and slightly spicy. I liked the chewiness of the pig ear. Bonus star just for having pigs ear.

I'm very interested in going back to try the aforementioned eel salad and frog legs as well as the starters.

Side Note/Rant: I would think that Vietnamese food is quite varied yet restaurants always have the same dishes on their menu. Why is that? I just can't get excited about yet another pho bowl.
author: Jean K.

description: First time visit...Good food, nice ambiance, good service. Cute hostess. Will be back
author: Kevin G.

description: Went at around 6pm on a Tuesday, it was pretty crowded by the time we left at 7. The Pho Bo was pretty decent, I would have liked the soup to be a bit hotter! The broth was pretty delicious, although for some reason the noodles sat at the bottom of the bowl in a bunch that had to be forcibly separated. Maybe it wasn't stirred while cooking?
author: Emily Y.

description: I had the non-soup style rice noodle bowl with pork (cooked, not grilled). This was really over-seasoned and I mostly tasted salt and a raw onion flavor that was harsher than not. The raw carrots were thickly sliced in medallions by what seemed like an under-trained line chef -- this was neither appealing nor easy to eat with any utensil. They should be julienned and made to travel more easily with noodles into the mouth. I frankly could not finish my meal. Sorry, but wok-fried pork is a relatively easy dish and should hit on the feel-good comfort food note with any patron, Asian or otherwise. Unfortunately, this was far from delectable and I cannot say it was worth the money, unless you want to see how skill seems irrelevant. The item should be removed from the menu. I should have either gotten the soup or a grilled item.
author: Valerie S.

description: I was coming here for a great Vietnamese Dinner. I got the Shaking Beef with Garlic Noodles. It was pricey but worth the cost. I also recommend getting the biao xen, the Filled Vietnamese Crepe with lettuce to wrap around it, the Spring Rolls are also delicious!!! The Staff are nice, and there is a nice atmosphere!!! I would definitely suggest coming here for dinner on any day of the week!!! I hope to return here soon!!!
author: Will D.

description:
Great Vegetarian and Vegan options here, with a super knowledgeable staff in terms of what does and doesn't contain fish sauce. I've tried all the tofu dishes from multiple visits, but the tofu clay pot has been my favorite. That saying, you really can't go wrong!

No full liquor license, so just beer, wine and sake.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Food: more of a fusion/Californian than authentic Vietnamese, but still very good.

Price: on the high end of Vietnamese restaurants but worth it

Location: right on Valencia in Mission!

Place: trendy, but can be very noisy
author: Yoshikage K.

description:
so i got to the restaurant before my friends did. i'm guessing it's because they're normally really busy around dinner time, they couldn't assign me a table and told me to wait by the bar or wait outside. once my friends and we were seated, it took the waiter a while for him to take our order. it took them over 30 minutes to bring out our food and i was super hangry. i order the five spice chicken with garlic noodles. i thought my dish was pretty good. you could taste the garlic flavor in the noodles and there was a hint of sweetness too. i probably wouldn't go back. i prefer authentic vietnamese food and at least i know it doesn't take them 30 minutes to make my order.

food: 4/5, the five spice chicken with garlic noodles was good, but there are definitely better tasting vietnamese food elsewhere. unless you're into the hipster vietnamese food, then this is your spot.
service: 3/5, it takes the waiter a while for them to attend your order and the food takes a long time to come out. but at least they're attentive with water refills

notes: make sure your party is complete or they will not seat you. also make sure you don't go to the restaurant on a really empty stomach like me or you'll be hangry waiting for 30 minutes for your food to come out.
author: Sylvia H.

description: The food is fresh and tasty. The welcoming atmosphere is great, and the staff are so friendly! Wonton soup is a regular favorite. The fresh rolls are always delicious (both pork/shrimp and veggie). If you love Pho, this is the place. You'll pay a touch more than some Pho houses, but this one is really worth it.
author: Adam G.

description:
Excellent, attentive service - just the right amount (I hate when you get bothered every 5 minutes whilst eating but this was perfect service)! 

Food was fantastic. Warning: the crispy spring roll starter is huge. I'd recommend sharing! My boyfriend had the bun thit bo nuong (grilled lemongrass beef and noodles with added spring rolls) and it was so flavorsome, again a big portion! I had the papaya salad which I really enjoyed. The sauce had a bit of a kick to it. The calamari was perfect. 

Reasonably priced and definite good value for money!
author: Stephanie O.

description:
wanted to wait to try more of the menu before writing a review, but I couldn't wait, because I want to tell everyone how fabulous this place is asap! Before you roll your eyes at the crop of hip new restaurants in the Mission, let me just say that I'm Vietnamese, and I approve it ;] hahaha.

It's so nice to see a Vietnamese place in the mission. Don't be fooled by the hip, trendy exterior/decor, the food is unadulterated Vietnamese fare. It is not watered down nor "Americanized". The Goi Ga (chicken salad) had full-on, full-strength fish sauce, in full-blown authenticity, lol. Bun Rieu is hard to find, but it's on the menu here, and it's done really well (love that they are not skimpy on the toppings!!). Claypot fish is a classic, and it's a generous portion of deliciously prepared fish. The presentation and setting is nicer than you're probably used to when you think about mom-and-pop Vietnamese joints, but it's a welcome surprise, especially when the food is great and the staff is so nice. The food comes out a little more slowly than normal, but I'm sure that's because it's lovingly prepared, because I can taste it ;] 

Vietnamese restaurants are already hard to find, and even when they open, they are usually in close proximity to one another, so having an easily-accessible Vietnamese option is already one reason why you should try this place out NOW! Sure the prices may be a little bit higher than the grungy pho restaurant, but it's perfectly reasonable considering the location, service, cleanliness, and quality :)
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I went here with a friend on a rainy Saturday night - it was packed! We got seated quickly but service was pretty slow. But the chicken pho was a perfect hot soup for the night. The papaya salad was pretty good too, a little spicy for me but my heat tolerance is very low. I would have drank another 1-2 beers of the waiter had come back often enough. Overall, hit the spot. And it's a great location to begin a night of bar hopping. 
I wouldn't travel miles to eat here but it's a great, convenient neighborhood spot.
author: Lizzie R.

description:
Being Vietnamese, I'm pretty picky when it comes to Vietnamese food. And I'm really happy with the couple of experiences I had at MAU.  Like any restaurant, if you get the right thing, you're golden.  In MAU's case, the right thing is Bun Cha Hanoi.  They do this dish really well.  It's soooo good. 

Love that I can finally eat at a yummy Vietnamese restaurant that I don't have to trek to the tenderloin or chinatown for.  MAU is super reasonably priced for the quality of food you're getting - and the setting and location it's in.  The service is great, and the location can't be beat.  Go!
author: Tina T.

description:
I really, really didn't want to like this place. I've been living in the neighborhood for 4 years now and seeing the gentrification happen so rapidly and witnessing so many mom and pop shops be replaced by fancy restaurants, it's tough. I also generally don't like "fancified" Asian joints, because I adore the hole-in-the-walls owned by the folks actually know the roots of the food they cook, who couldn't give a rats ass about your fine dining etiquettes. 

But I liked Mau. I really liked it. Damn it. 

1. The service was impeccable. Super friendly host, amazing bartenders who also brought us food, and everyone was attentive and chill. Loved the vibe and energy. 

2. Food was excellent and not overly pricey. The food was of high quality and they weren't overpriced like I had imagined. Sure, it's not $5 for pho, but it's also not $25 for a piece of chicken. I liked how the menu had pricier ($15-30) and cheaper ($10-12) options for everyone on any budget.  

I got the pork vermicelli bowl with half the noodles and extra veggies, which they happily accommodated. The house-made hot sauces were great (the garlic chili one is better). My friend got their pho and the broth was legit.

I'll be back. Oh Mau, you've won me over big time.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Great clay pots 

Good drink specials 

Food is hot and fresh 

I would recommend you come in early 

Must say it's a little on the pricier side for pho .  Location?
author: Evan W.

description:
This place of one of my favorite new restaurants in SF. The pho specifically is hands down amazing. Great broth just all around good stuff. The mushrooms in the veggie pho are very tasty as well. I also like the veggie egg rolls.

It's pretty popular so it's always busy which is annoying. I'm sure that has a lot to do with the location. But other than that I love this place. I've been here at least 5 times in the past 6 months. 

All around good quality food and good service. Try it out you won't be disappointed.
author: Black Frankenstien ..

description: White washed Vietnamese food with meh food and decor that makes you believe you're paying for quality.  The bo kho was watered down and a poor substitute for the real thing.  Pho is the same.  The 2 stars on the review is really about the price being out of sync with the quality of the food.
author: Dan P.

description: I like to think of myself as a pho connoisseur. No one thinks of me that way, but who cares. Anyway - the pho here is just ok. So I can't give it more than 3 stars as far as vietnamese places go. They have a good catfish in clay pot and delicious spring rolls both fresh and vibrant.  But the pho broth is limp.
author: Kamael S.

description:
A delicious catastrophe...

Come hungry - but not TOO hungry. Mau has fabulous food and utterly atrocious service and timeliness. 

Each experience here has been a journey with its own ebbs and flows in and out of mediocrity. Do not expect the hostess to call you if you leave your telephone number. Do not feel comfortable waiting outside. Out of sight, woefully out of mind.

...and yet I keep returning, like the abused housewife who cannot resist the allure of her husband and what once was.


- C
author: Claire B.

description: I had a overall pretty satisfying experience. The server was nice and our food was brought on fairly quickly.
author: Angel N.

description: Always a favorite, such good food at reasonable prices. It's hardly possible to enjoy dinner out for less than $20 these days.
author: Megan P.

description:
The name of this place should be Meh.  I was jonesing for Vietnamese and relied on the  4 star rating this place has been given. I ordered the Bun Thit Nuong with Cha Gio.  The lemongrass pork was dry and tough, the noodles were al dente, the nuoc mam tasted like a midwestern librarian had made it-- all of the ingredients there but it just didn't taste good. Oh, the cha gio, was mealy, probably left over from the night before, not at all crispy on the outside or fresh on the inside.  Needless to say, this was an epic fail in my view.  So epic, I will not be going back. 

Yelpers, you need to get some standards or try real Vietnames food before you review anything.
author: ai f.

description:
Went with some girlfriends today for lunch.  I had the Pho Ga.  I thought the broth was really tasty.  The meat quality much better than I get at my usual spots on Clement and Irving.  I really enjoyed this meal, the ambiance and the quality of the food.   

Will happily frequent often.
author: Pauline C.

description: I came in here on a Tuesday afternoon around 2:30 and it wasn't too busy. Free parking is hard to find, but there are plenty of meter parking in front of the restaurant. Walked into the restaurant and was immediately greeted by a server and was seated right away by the window. The service was consistent with never leaving my water class empty and the food came out fairly quick! I ordered the Bun Bo Hue and it was AMAZING!! The broth was definitely rich in taste and SPICY! Halfway through the bowl, I was already stuff. So the bowl itself could be enough for two people to share if you really wanted to. I will definitely be returning to try other dishes on the menu! Two thumbs up!
author: Shelley L.

description:
Mau is located relatively close to my apartment in The Mission. I walked by it several times and noticed one day the chalkboard read "Pho" on it. I moved to SF a few months ago from Philadelphia where I regularly went out to traditional restaurants for a good bowl of pho to start the day (It's a great hangover cure). Finding a pho place so close to my new home I had to stop in and try it.

FREQUENCY: I've dined at and ordered take out from this establishment one time each.

FOOD: Both times I went to Mau I ordered the Bun Bo Hue. I'm a huge fan of spicier soups and this one looked like the spiciest bowl of noodles and soup on the menu. The pho contained beef shank, rare niman ranch eye-of-round, and pork sausage. The soup came out piping hot and was delicious. They also offered Sriracha sauce and BBQ sauce which I enjoy mixing together with a little sugar to make a great dipping sauce for the meats. The bowl was very filling and I was thoroughly satisfied. I plan on trying other bowl types in the future but haven't gotten around to it. When I ordered take out I was a little less impressed. I definitely suggest calling ahead to order pick up because ordering take out in the restaurant takes a long time. The staff has to switch between taking orders from the bar patrons and the line of take out patrons so it moves slowly. When I finally got home to enjoy my pho the meats weren't all thoroughly cooked. I had to cook several pieces before they were edible. Once everything was put together it was tasty. Though the downside is you miss out on the Sriracha and BBQ sauce. Honestly if you are considering dining at Mau just get a seat in the restaurant. That's my plan for the future.

DRINK: Mau had a nice selection of alcoholic and fountain drinks. I ordered a beer to go with my soup and drank several glasses of water to balance out the spicy soup I was consuming. A good selection and about what I'd expect from a restaurant this size.

ATMOSPHERE: So if you are looking for a traditional Vietnamese pho restaurant I don't think this place is for you. Man makes me think of an Americanized pho restaurant. It's a very beautiful place with a nice layout and interesting artwork but that's not the type of atmosphere I'd expect from a traditional Vietnamese pho restaurant. The atmosphere is very good. I'm just trying to point out it has a very American feel, so if the traditional atmosphere is very important to you you may be a little put off, but if you're open to good pho in a cool atmosphere than you'll be just fine.
