STAFF: When I dined at pho the staff was super friendly. I sat at the bar and the bartender was very conversational up until I was eating. I really like enjoying my food so I appreciate it when restaurant staff don't talk to me much while eating. When I ordered take out I didn't have much interaction with the staff besides taking my order, which was expected.

PAYMENT: Credit cards or cash were acceptable.

I really like this spot. Because of the proximity and the delicious soup and noodles I think Mau will become a regular stop for me in my food adventures. I don't recommend ordering out based off my one experience but dining in was fantastic. And if the traditional Vietnamese pho restaurant atmosphere isn't too important to you then I think you'll definitely enjoy it. Regardless I'd recommend that anyone living in the area or visiting stop in and try Mau at some point.
author: Christopher D.

description: Mau is excellent! I ordered the Chicken clay pot, and the marinade on the chicken is absolutely delicious! I paired it with the MAU cocktail. Highly recommend both!
author: Nina P.

description:
The day we came, we sat right across the table from what looked like some Italian Mafia guys. One dressed in a dark red Adidas track outfit was smoking outside leaning on someone's car before coming inside.

That started off our evening pretty well. On the other hand, we had some delicious family-style dinner among 5 of us. We just came from a conference happy hour before eating, so we couldn't wait to dig in. 

I've been to a lot of Vietnamese restaurants and I would say that I prefer the dishes here compared to other traditional restaurants around. I found some new favorite dishes here and plan to be back.
author: Moua L.

description:
This place is awesome but the chicken was a bit salty (review by an 8 year old).
I agree, pho was delicious. Lemongrass chicken was super salty.
author: N S.

description:
Really nice food, friendly people and nice atmosphere inside, this is a special place for brunch with few friends, the sea food was good and the wine too. 
Good job !!
author: Jeremy P.

description:
The only reason I'm rating this place so low is because of the service. The food was excellent--I usually get Spring Rolls with either Bun Thit Nuong, Hu Tieu and Tamarind Prawns, but to wait over an hour is a bit much. 

The first three times I went to Mau, the staff was lovely and attending. But one day they dropped the ball completely. I was with my family and we waited over an hour for the food. We were the third party to walk in the door and people who came in after us left before we did. 

I'm never going back there.
author: Julianna E.

description:
The service sort of sucks. 1 star

The food was actually pretty good. 

I got:

the chicken wings. 4 stars
The beef pho: 3.5 stars
author: Ahmed A.

description:
Fun place, great food, inexpensive-yes!!!
Went here with a friend on a weekend night and didn't have trouble getting a table, though it was pretty crowded. 

I got the tofu pho which was light and fresh-tasting and awesome. But all of the dishes looked great. 

They are also running a promotion right now for an app called Cover so if you download the app and use it to pay you get $10 off!
author: Marilyn M.

description: Super extra overly salty. Veggie pho is mainly tofu fried within an inch of its life and sodium. Also, I once had a hair in my tofu dish. I didn't return my food out of respect for my dining companions but it is hard to erase the image from my mind. I do like their fried veggie spring rolls but they lack diversity in their veggie food as they are obviously catering to the foodie trend of serving mostly pig parts. It's a nice space, but with many many other solid Vietnamese places in the city, I don't think I'll be returning here.
author: Valerie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I eat here at least once a week but usually twice. The Pho Bo is so wonderful and rich, especially when you are feeling a little under the weather. 

The Hue Rolls are my absolute favorite and I am always pleased with our service, food and experience.  Ingredients are fresh, beautiful and delicious!

This is my favorite restaurant on Valencia hand down!
author: Maggie S.

description:
With fresh, quality ingredients, Mau brings Vietnamese food to the next level. 

Upon entering diners will find an "urban-rustic" dining room with dim lighting, some high bar height tables, a few cozy tables for two, and banquette bench seating for larger groups.  Minimal decorations mean the focus is on the food.

With a moist and tender pork filling, the hue spring rolls were cooked to perfection. The pho bun bo hue had a generous portion of fresh and tasty meat, a very rich and savory broth, and delicious noodles. It's not for the faint of taste, however: be warned, it's pretty spicy.  With a sweet caramelized coating, the clay pot fish was a nice warm comfort food on a cold San Francisco day.

The service was great: the wait staff is friendly and attentive.  Orders were taken quickly, food arrived swiftly, glasses were refilled promptly, and used dishes were removed immediately.

Mau brings Tenderloin-quality Vietnamese food smack into the middle of The Mission.
author: CJ G.

description:
Everything is decent. What distinguish the place from the two other Vietnamese places I frequent nearby are 1) the salty lemonade, 2) it's more hipsterish 3) everything is about 30% more expensive, 4) wait staff are CUTE....

so sure, I'd occasionally go back for some expensive eye candies...=)
author: Xiu L.

description:
Really solid, affordable, fun ambiance - great place.  4+ stars for very good Vietnamese.
Chicken wings, papaya salad, prawn hotpot, greens sauteed in garlic, shaking beef - all was flavorful and well-prepared.
Slurped down a young coconut for good measure too.
This place rocks!
author: Andrew K.

description: I'd recommend the bun thit nuoung, clay pot catfish and the wings. Service was great, I'll be back soon!
author: Danielle C.

description:
Thank you MAU!  

I know y'all do not accept reservations-- and I wish you did.  But your staff is amazingly accommodating.  thank you- thank you!

I had a group lunch of folks that had been with our organization for over 20 years plus. And of course we had 20 people who were going to attend.  

I called the night before and explained my situation and Aaron suggested that I get to the restaurant right at opening and hope for the best.

I did and the day manager-- has a cool name starts with a N Needem-- was so helpful nice, and very patient with my group.  

Our wait person was very accommodating as well.  All of our  food was hot and delicious!  

It was truly a great dinning experience.  

Thank You!
author: Princess P.

description:
I'm really torn on how to rate this place.

I ordered the catfish clay pot.  I would've been happy if it had turned out to be a full meal, as have been all prior clay pot dishes i've had (admittedly all Chinese; do Vietnamese serve only bits in clay pots, not full entrees?).  The preparation was actually excellent, & since i go to restaurants primarily for the food (though of course the atmosphere can also have a significant effect on the dining experience, if it's either wonderful or grating; this place was neither -- a but busy/noisy, but not bad enough that it spoiled the meal or made it impossible to talk, so for more trendy-type places, i'd say it was fine but didn't add to the pleasure of the dinner), it's the food that makes or breaks most places, for my evaluation.

Here, while i found the preparation of the catfish both unique (something i always appreciate) & excellently prepared (tender, not under- or over-cooked; well executed generally), so i want to give Mau a high rating, the portion size was....odd.  By that i mean that the amount of fish was adequate ...or would have been if it had been accompanied by vegetables & such, as one (at least this one) normally expects from a meal.  Yet i left still hungry, since the actual pot in which it was served was MUCH smaller than clay pot dishes i've had in Chinese restaurants, & it was just the fish, no vegetables or anything else except some plain rice served with it.  I never thought to ask if there were anything but the fish in the clay pot; that just seemed so obvious.  Live & learn, i guess; but i have to deduct points for such a major lack in food preparation.

So while i'd definitely give Mau a higher rating if it were just the taste & preparation of the food i was rating, the lack of serving the full meal i'd normally get in a clay pot dish & the fact that the service was, to put it politely, "minimalist" (meaning that it was adequate, but the server seemed bored & just doing her job to get home as soon as possible; not sure she uttered a word the entire time we dealt with her, & certainly never cracked a smile or gave any sense of pleasantness), left me feeling i need to rate this place in the middle -- great in some ways, inadequate in others.  Average = 3 stars.
author: a b.

description: Mau is one of the few affordable sit-down restaurants with ambiance on Valencia Street, and I really wish I liked it more. The food, however, is subpar; there's a lot better pho in town. Eating at Mau is definitely not the wait.
author: Carol N.

description:
I am a big fan of Mau. I ate here for the second time tonight and liked it more than the first time! We ordered the chicken wings appetizer (Cahn Ga chien) and the Bun Ga Xa for dinner. I had the beef pho my first time, and I remember the broth being very flavorful - this time, I wanted to try something else.

The chicken wings appetizer is a must-have! The chicken is well seasoned and crunchy, the the meat is delicious. I could have done without the salad on the side though, it was overdressed and not very good. The Bun Ga Xa was great! It was a giant bowl of vermicelli noodles with lemongrass chicken on top. I ordered the bowl with veggies (+$1) and it came with thinly sliced carrots and cucumbers, then some broccoli and mushrooms on top. I think the meal should just come with veggies, without the veggies it wouldn't have been as exciting. I do love the food and service (servers) at Mau but it took a long time for us just to get our appetizer. I would love to come back to try one of their clay pots!
author: Lauren G.

description: This is one of my go-to pickup places, so no judgement on the service. We have tried most of their rolls. All were delicious. I am obsessed with their five spice chicken rice plate. It's addictive and delicious. The pho broth is deep and satisfying.
author: Laura G.

description:
They were full on a foggy week night, but we didn't have to wait too long to be seated -- both very good signs!

We started with the banana blossom salad. It was tangy and refreshing, and I loved the addition of crispy fried eel, shallots and garlic. 

The hubby always goes for soup, and the Pho Bo with rare Niman ranch beef, tripe and rice noodles in garlic broth did not disappoint. 

I had the five-spice quail salad, which was the highlight of the meal.  The quail was really crispy and nicely seasoned, which worked really well with the market greens and house vinaigrette. 

The price wasn't bad considering the generous portions. Service was very friendly and attentive, and the restaurant had a cool vibe. Definitely coming back!
author: Dawne L.

description: This place was great.  I walked in because I was starving and it looked busy... which is a good sign in any neighborhood.  It's white people vietnamese food... full of flavor... and the service was decent.  I read the other reviews here about horrible service and not authentic food.... and this is what I have to say to that... you are in the mission of San Francisco... of course it's not authentic, but it's yummy and clean... and the service isn't special, but it's not poor... the staff is just working a busy job... be patient!
author: Cristy M.

description:
I ordered the chicken pho and my boyfriend ordered the shaken beef.  We waited what seemed like 45 minutes.  The four top that was seated at the same time as us received both their appetizers and main courses before we received anything.  I finally asked another table's waiter where our food was when the couple next to us who had been seated a good 20 minutes after we ordered received their food first.  A minute or two after I asked the couple's waiter about my order, our waiter magically appeared with my pho and made a snide remark about me waiting patiently.  

It took another couple of minutes for him to arrive with my boyfriend's shaken beef which consisted of five small cubes of beef with a tiny salad for $16.  The dressing for the salad contained WAY too much salt.  In fact the salad was caked in salt.  I complained to the waiter and he literally rolled his eyes at me and told me that that was normal.  It was not normal nor was it edible.  

No adjustment to the bill.  No explanation for the wait.  No apology for the wait or the ruined food.  Instead we received a lot of attitude from our waiter.  What should have been a quick 45 minute dinner turned into a 90 minute ordeal, and we left still hungry.  And to our waiter, I have no clue why you were so rude to us, but you're lucky I left you any tip whatsoever.  You're a jerk!
author: Gianna S.

description: Great place to grab some vietnamese food in the area. The place is very clean, and has good food. I had a dry noodle with lemongrass pork (can't remember what it's actually called on the menu), and it was good. I also liked how there is plenty of seating on the weekends during brunch/lunch hours, so you can get seated almost right away when you come.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
I'm picky with my Vietnamese food and Mau is now my go-to place. So far, I tried: 
- Mango salad & chicken salad - tasty and tangy 
- Beef & chicken noodle - savory broth and tender beef 
- Bun Cha Ha Noi - I can't believe how authentic it is. 
Plus the maitre d. on the weekend is fast and so nice
author: Meo M.

description:
Bo Bun Hue is crazy good. They have great soups beyond the typical pho, and even passed the test of a very picky vietnamese girl I brought. 
Their service can be flighty and forgetful or confused, and the prices are higher than but food is 5 stars.
author: Christian W.

description: Delicious Vietnamese food. The kind of pho place you wish you knew about.
author: D D.

description:
1/8/13 Lunch

Right off the bat I can tell you Mau is not the most authentic Vietnamese place but the food tastes good. Very good. We walked in shortly after noon and were promptly seated. The decor is mostly of wood, reminding me of a cozy cafe. Server greeted us with huge smile. 

The menu is very simple: a mixture of appetizers, noodles, claypots and pho.  The portions are surprisingly big as we offered a dish from each of the categories to share:
*Cha Gio were crispy-fried rolls with pork, shrimp, jicama and glass noodles. I like how they were made to order and very crispy. Served on a huge bed of lettuce. Tasty.
*Bahn Xeo was crepe with pork, shrimp and calamari. A bit greasy but nonetheless tasty. 
*Lemongrass Chicken Bahn Mi was served on a very crispy baguette. The Mau version of the Vietnam staple comes with pickles, cilantro but no pate and splash of soy sauce. The sandwich is slightly Americanized. 
*Vermicelli with Grilled Pork is not bad with big portion.

Service is friendly and attentive. Good value--most dishes under $10. It's worthy to mention that this foodie-hipter Vietnamese joint is run by former Slow Club chef Sante Salvoni and Tin Vietnamese owner Hung Dang. 

I'll be back to try other stuffs on their menu.
author: Matt Y.

description: The hue rolls are really good here and a staple every time I go here. If you're ordering for yourself, then it's a great place to go but if you're ordering family style the menu doesn't have much variety. It's all some variation of the same rice noodles and meats
author: Jin N.

description: I've never stepped foot inside, but I've had the rolls twice. SO GOOD. If those rolls are any indication, everything else must be delicious.
author: Jenny J.

description:
I came here for dinner on a weekend night and sat at a raised table by the door - really casual vibe with great service and a really nice waiter. We ordered Bun Thit Nuong and the Cha Ca La Vong (both noodles with meat, both of them REALLY delicious).

Only issue we had was that they accidentally brought us Cha Gio (which we didn't order), and they charged us an extra $10, but simple mistake!
author: Amanda L.

description: The food at Mau was very good, we got the spring rolls, lemongrass tofu and a bowl of pho. However, I have a severe food allergy and have to double check EVERTHING before I order. I asked our waiter if the food contained the particular allergen and he what he was supposed to do and checked with another employee . That employee scolded him in front of us, saying "why would that that contain ------""??? . A.  It was nasty to see a server treated that way B. NEVER question something that may be allergy related . When Mr. Attitude saw our horrified expressions, he attempted a cover up, saying that it was directed at his employee "not knowing the menu". I responded that without a double check, I could die from the allergen . He apologized but the damage was done. I am from NYC and visit SF frequently, this is not a restaurant that I will be returning to.
author: Amanda Z.

description:
WHAT!!!? A viet spot that has real beef broth with good quality meats!!!? I'm there!!! Although it's not one of those super authentic spots, it's bordering the bougie line. I must say the food is amazing here. Everything I've had is on point. Your Vietnamese grandmother would be proud of you if you owned it. 


PS: STOP HIDING THE CONDIMENTS!!!! Hotsauce, fish sauce, lime, peanuts...
author: Fredo L.

description:
Stumbled upon this place with my friend after we discovered a ramen shop down the road did not serve ramen during lunch hours (... D': ) and i'm glad we came here instead. 

The place: 
Mau is very well lit, and the interior decoration is extremely modern. The entire restaurant is clean and has an overall very "relaxed" atmosphere.

The eats: 
My friend and I came here on a rather gloomy day in SF, so we both decided to order noodle soups and share a spring rolls appetizer. Their spring rolls contained very fresh ingredients, but what really impressed me about the dish was their peanut sauce. I personally am not even a big fan of peanuts, but I absolutely loved the sauce.

Shortly after we got the appetizer, our bun bo hue arrived. The soup was very tasty, and the noodles good as well. I loved the amount of garnishing vegetables they used for the bun bo hue, and the ingredients were plentiful. My favorite part of the dish was the rare beef, though. The meat was so tender and so flavorful after being "cooked" in the hot bun bo hue soup.

Overall, this place was more on the expensive side in terms of pho, but I'm glad I got to try it. :)
author: Selina S.

description: I mean its good. I really really loved the HUE ROLLS though. I made the mistake of ordering the spring rolls which are what you expect when you order spring rolls. But my friend ordered the hue rolls and i was in love. The texture of these rolls with the combination of cilantro and fried shallots was very delicious. For my Pho i requested no noodles and a lot of bean sprouts and the waiters were very accommodating. The broth was savory and delicious. The restaurant has a nice trendy ambiance. Next time ill try the frog legs.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Thank heaven for MAU. 
Never have I enjoyed Vietnamese cuisine so much. The flavors are on point, with the freshest ingredients, and a kitchen that is consistently putting out one perfect dish after another. The pickle onions in house to garnish your $9 pho (completely worth every penny.) 
If you're feeling ill, order mau. 
If you're expecting the kind of service that has time for your every need, think again. You're in the mission. It's a busy place. Don't be needy. Just enjoy. 
I recommend trying the hue rolls and and order of their papaya or mango salad. All the entrees are great, so you can't go wrong.
author: Sarah S N.

description: The pho is good, but the catfish claypot is something to write home about. The service is pretty spotty though.
author: David A.

description: Super tasty bun, with special points for offering a turmeric catfish one, and some dings for being kinda stingy with the portion sizes of the cha gio rolls.
author: Aiko S.

description:
Their bowl of pho will not leave you wanting more. At least you won't be wanting more noodles. While it's obviously a bit pricier than other bowls of tai nam sachs pho the ambiance will get people that normally don't step into a "dirty" pho restaurant happily slurping away, which is somewhat of a win I suppose.

The shaking beef wasn't memorable for me but I was pretty heavily taxed with finishing my hefty bowl of pho and fishing for the tendons I ordered. Overall, it's not a go-to for me, but I'll bookmark it as a "safe" bet for those friends that aren't so comfortable with hole in the wall spots. Kinda like Osha for Vietnamese food.
author: Krystle S.

description: So delicious, after you stop pretending that it's the most authentic Vietnamese spot in SF. Great chicken pho in ginger broth - I could have it every time it rains in SF. Wait, that's not often enough...every time it's foggy? Also, they have a great homemade sriracha, low prices, and pretty speed delivery the one time I tried it. This might just be my new favorite super affordable meal place.
author: Erin W.

description:
Mau is modern and slightly overpriced, but serves up some close-to-authetic Vietnamese food. It's definitely Westernized (I mean, we're on Valencia, so...), but the herbs and meat are fresh and the portion sizes are giant. The interior incorporates a lot of natural wood elements and is very clean and spacious.

- Spring Rolls ($7): Two standard spring rolls with peanut sauce on the side
The peanut sauce is thicker than most places, which is how I like it. We were also impressed by how thinly sliced the pork/chicken was inside.

- Bun Bo Hue ($10): I love spicy food, but if spice isn't your thing, the chili oil in here is a tad strong. The broth is just an explosion of flavor in general, so it's not for the weak-tongued. The Niman Ranch beef slices (along with the other beef toppings) were tender and rare.

I came for lunch with a friend on a Tuesday and only about half the tables were occupied. Still unsure what Mau means...
author: Jessica F.

description:
This place truly serves quality food. I am a noodle loving girl and these guys offer the best! 
The Bo Kho Pho was an generously sized with a fantastic array of flavors- the kind of dish where you can't stop yourself from finishing all the broth even though you are stuffed! 
Also, I highly recommend trying the chicken wings as an app. They are NOT your regular puny wings, no-no they are huge with crispy golden brown skin! And the lime & pepper sauce, YUM. 
The atmosphere was pleasant, not stuffy- we had a drink at the bar after dinner nice selection  of beer & wine.  
The place looks and taste great- we'll definitely be back.
author: Sparr G.

description:
This place was good. Very trendy place with a nice space. The food was good, the service was slow, and my experience was fine. Nothing stood out and nothing was bad or not good. I'd go back if I was in the area but I don't think it will stay on my radar and I probably wouldn't self motivate to go back in the near future. 

Good food, slow service. In the sea of greatness in the area there wasn't a lot that stands out about this place.
author: Jill T.

description:
Mau is....good. Was waffling between three and four stars, and I'm sticking to my guns and going with four. If there's better Vietnamese food in the Mission near 16th, I can't find it. 

Fast service, good beef, tasty pho. Is there anything else to know? 

They do quick take out, too. Order ahead and scoot on out.

The good: tasty, reasonably priced food.
The bad: waiter was hard to flag down when it got busy. If you're in a rush, get the bill ahead of time.
author: Amanda B.

description:
came here for lunch.. friends were able to grab a table before we got there.. after we were done, the place was packed

ordered:
-cha gio (fried imperial rolls)
-pho bo (rare brisket)

both were good but not amazing.. if i were in the mission and craving pho i'd come here, if not i'd rather go to the tl or sunset for pho
author: Raquel T.

description:
Fantastic food. Marinades are fabulous, every dish skilfully executed.
Would go a little lighter on the sodium (salt? soy sauce?) on dishes like the catfish claypot etc.
Go. Eat. Be sated.
author: C J.

description:
I remember when this place had its soft opening. Took several months to really start spinning it's wheels, but most new places have that ramp up period here in SF right? Getting right to the standards with ordering the chicken pho noodle soup with the signature ginger/chicken broth is pretty stellar indeed. Side of spring rolls of course with the pork and shrimp inside just has to be present as well.
You leave that place with a smile four shore. :)
Hanoi Rocks! \m/
author: Sven S.

description:
I love Mau! Mau and its sister restaurant in SOMA, Tin Vietnamese, have some of the best Hu Tieu I've ever had. 

I'm a huge pho fan and I'll take every chance to eat Vietnamese noodles. Mau does Vietnamese food so perfectly: great, deep, herby flavors that you come to expect from pho and other noodle soups, with higher quality ingredients than most neighborhood pho joints. Granted, you will be paying a slightly higher price point than other pho places in the city. My hu tieu was around $11 and other favorites like catfish claypot and lemongrass beef rice bowls will go up to around 13-15. However, I don't mind, because you can really taste the difference in the meats especially, that the food is much fresher.

The interior of Mau is also great, it's airy and big, huge bar space, and located right on Valencia and 18th. My go-to dishes are the hu tieu (can't go wrong with garlic-ginger-chicken broth yum!), claypots, and the lotus salad with pig's ear.
author: Kate M.

description:
I was shocked at how misinformed/rude the staff is at Mau. For a restaurant that seems to get a lot of positive press, its incredibly disappointing to have had the experience that we did. 

We called the restaurant and began placing an order only to have the call drop halfway thru. When we called back, a different person answered who seemingly decided on the spot to refuse our business. 

To make matters worse, he seemed to be unsure of the restaurant's policy and was very rude about refusing our order. There were multiple conversations going on in the background while we were on the phone focused on whether or not we would be allowed to eat their food. It was fascinating to listen to (we weren't on hold for any of it).

I simply don't get it. What an astounding experience, going from great to terrible in a matter of seconds. Try one of the many other Vietnamese spots in SoMa that treat their customers with respect.
author: Sam L.

description: Really good broth for the pho Bo.  The pho was bit clumpy which suggest it might have been cooked cooked a little early and left for a while. Overall the food was great and we all enjoyed our meals.
author: Han Teng W.

description: Loved the pho! U would definitely come back regularly for that. I wasn't a fan of the vermicelli tho. Pho definitely shines
author: Erika J.

description: If you want authentic Vietnamese food, go somewhere else. If you want american food with Vietnamese names and spices, then try at your own discretion. The pork chop is thick which is not how it's supposed to be coming from a Vietnamese establishment. The imperial rolls are okay but have way too much taro.
author: Catherine L.

description: Came here for dinner with a few friends after a day in Dolores Park. The atmosphere is slightly upscale and modern for a pho place. I ordered the Bun Thang noodle soup- it was  super filling and fresh! Also received great service from the wait staff
author: Allison D.

description: food is good and the place is clean. service can be off here and there but decent vietnamese food in the mission. the pho is good, not too 'greasy spoon.'
author: Roy N.

description:
Best pho ever!! Get the Hu Tieu; it's absolutely amazing. Plus, the lemongrass hot sauce is just to die for!! 

I'll definitely be coming back!!!
author: Victor C.

description: Walked past this place dozens of times. Happened in just because I had a meeting nearby and wanted to try it. Holy cow. I've eaten at many a Vietnamese restaurants throughout the bay area, DC, NY, Houston, etc....hole in the walls and of course the Slanted Door. It's cliche hipster heaven, but the braised pork belly, broth, noodles, the entire lunch was amazingly great. Authentic and tasty. Price a little on the high side, but what do you expect. Very satisfed and will return. Hope they are consistent.
author: Chad R.

description: I had an awesome rice paper roll with beef followed by Pho. The food was fantastic the service was good, but I happened to drop by on a very busy Sunday. I have been back once and it was less busy and the food is consistently good.
author: Gabriel B.

description:
Attention Management: LOVE your food. HATE HATE HATE your service. 

You never get it right ratio of customers to servers!!! It is 1215 on a Saturday. 11 tables and 1 server. And this is not the first time this has happened. 

My suggestion: put two servers on at open and avoid this train wreck!

One off duty waiter sitting at bar. Lovely.
author: C K.

description:
The 5 stars are only for the pho. I can't speak to the rest of the food, nor do I care about the rest!

I thought some of the pho places up by China Town/North Beach were the best, but then I went to Mau and got their beef pho. The broth is SOO much better, and it seems cleaner than the pho in North Beach. It's only a $0.25 more expensive, which is nothing for the leap in quality and atmosphere!

I WILL be back.
author: Caroline B.

description:
I totally hated on this place at first because I thought it was way too clean and modern looking to have legit Vietnamese food. All bomb Vietnamese restaurants that I have been to are complete hole in the walls,I feel like it's some kind of universal rule or something. 

I was tricked into coming here by some friends and was pleasantly surprised. Yes - it's fancy, yes - it's clean, but yes - it's also extremely tasty. 

Here's what I had:
- Bun Cha Ha Noi (Vermicelli w/ pork belly, sausage) - Super flavorful meats that go perfectly with chewy vermicelli noodles. They also have crazy good spicy dipping sauces that I could inhale by the spoonful. 
- Cha Gio (Crispy fried rolls) - Okay, let's be real this is your run of the mill imperial rolls, which always seem to hit the spot.
- Banh Xeo (Vietnamese pancake w/ shrimp & other goodies) - My boo and I visited Vietnam last year and had the best Banh Xeos ever made by a woman who probably has been making them her entire life. Mau's banh xeos does not stack up but comes as a close second. They did a great job capturing the crispiness of the dish. 

I shamefully ate here twice in one week. Yah, it's that good.
author: Grace Y.

description: I've never been disappointed with Mau. Tasty, casual, inexpensive.
author: Julia V.

description: Best Pho in The Mission. They also play the Dopest music! I've had all of their Pho and every choice is an amazing choice!
author: Aaron G.

description:
I was feeling a little under the weather and in the mood for some hot soup and happened to pass Mau on Valencia. I stopped out front to read their menu and saw that they were closing in about an hour, it was 2:00pm at the time. I debated on whether or not I would be one of "those" customers but figured I would be ok as people continued to walk in. 

I entered the same time as another couple and watched the many eye rolls of the Front of house staff. You could tell they had already stared closing down and they seemed bothered that we were there. It took a couple minutes for the staff to greet either of us and another few minutes for us to be seated in the very open dining area. 

I was seated at the high counter opposite the bar. My server passed by a couple times without acknowledgement until I finally flagged him down and put in my order.

I got the fresh squeezed limeade and the pho bo. The limeade was nice and refreshing and the pho bo satisfied all of my soup cravings. I understand those customers that come in right before closing but being in the hospitality industry I would hope that guests would get the same treatment that they do at the opening of the restaurant to the closing hours. Good food but the service and this experience won't have me going back to Mau any time soon.
author: Justin L.

description:
This restaurant is awesomely delicious. We had: the beef salad, the mussels, the fish for two, house pickles, and the pork belly rice bowl. Everything was absolutely fabulous, and the bread in the mussel dish was so good (the sauce was delicious and we kept mopping it up and asking for more bread to help us in our dedication) that we all want to go back for lunch and bahn mi's STAT. 

I love that you can just walk in to such a great restaurant on the Valencia strip, but I doubt that will last for long as word spreads. Delicious fun restaurant and they did such a great job with the inside decor! The waiters were all very friendly and we had a great dinner.
author: Tasha D.

description: Pretty bad service; friendly but slow and not around when you need them. However, I'll never stop coming because their tofu pho is amazing!! I can't find any vegetarian pho as tasty anywhere.
author: Tracy W.

description: Best Vietnamese food I have had so far. Have been here twice and both times had a really good experience. Spring rolls and pho ga are a must try.
author: Shalini O.

description:
I had never really had Vietnamese food before coming to Mau, and I have to say- I can't wait to eat here again!  The atmosphere is lovely and the service is great.

The Pho Bo is positively delicious, especially with tripes, and SO filling.  One bowl was more than enough for me - but I also indulged in some creme puffs for dessert.

Totally delicious, looking forward to my next visit to Mau!!
author: Haley G.

description: The food was very tasty and fresh and in large quantities. Their hot sauces are homemade and I was pretty excited about that, so I ate a bunch of it. Four stars  because the hot sauce gave me incredibly intense stomach cramps almost immediately after eating. Nothing has ever affected me like that. I have no idea what was in that sauce, so be careful about eating a lot of it. This is the red watery one.
author: Julia D.

description:
Was here for dinner yday, for a Monday night, as expected It wasn't crowded and we were immediately seated. 

Ordered fresh young coconut, papaya salad and a tofu noodle soup.
Portions are good for sharing
The person who served our table was alright, while he wasn't super friendly, he wasn't rude either.
Tofu noodle soup (pho) tasted fresh and had a few veggies in it (broc, mushroom, carrots and bok choy)

The papaya salad was lame... it should be called fried tofu salad, there was hardly any papaya in it.

I'd probably go again to try other vegetarian items on the menu.
author: Kinjal S.

description:
I wasn't impressed with the service and the food was iffy. We sent the spring rolls back - they were that dry and stale. The pork bahn mi was fantastic. The noodles were somewhere in the middle (3.8). 

My review is based on a totally American palette. I haven't spent time in Vietnam and don't have too much experience with their food. So take that review with a grain of salt:)

The service was on the neglectful side. We saw our waiter only when he took our order, delivered our food, and scurried over with the check. They could at least improve upon that.
author: Joy W.

description:
I love this place so much!  If I lived a bit closer, I'd eat there at least once a week. 
I wanted to write a review because I had such a wonderful experience the other day for an early dinner.  Chris G. (as it shows up on my receipt) was so incredibly hospitable and attentive during our dinner at the bar.  And not overly attentive which is also important!  The food was delicious, ambiance was perfect, and the service 100%. Thank you Mau.
author: Julie T.

description: I had the tofu clay pot with brown rice, it had fried tofu, Shitake mushrooms, carrots and a bit of cabbage. The sauce was great (believe it was an oyster sauce) but the portion was not a large as I expected. Quality of food and service was excellent. Although, a bit more pricey than what I am used to for Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Sheila C.

description:
You know that feeling when you walk into an Asian joint.....

The restaurant is full but there's only three Asian people there and they are not employees...

I had the Five Spiced chicken rice plate,  it was cheap but not Vietnamese cheap. Neither was the quality, Vietnamese I mean or traditional or whatever you wanna call it.

Only plus side here is the big liquor list. Take your white friends here who are afraid of foreign foods.

So what. It's ethnocentric but true.
author: Connor M.

description: Loud, busy, hip(ster)/eccentric crowd.  Had a drink at the bar while waiting for our table. The bartender was strangely annoying.  We tried 3 reasonably priced, undistinguished wines.  Started with some below average chicken wings with not enough dipping sauce.  The best dish was the garlic bok choy.  My wife had a tofu dish that she really liked.  My daughter had grilled beef with noodles that was very good.  I had the spicy pho with beef and sausage.  It was very good. The service was earnest.  I felt pressure to turn over the table.  OK restaurant with good and bad points.
author: Joel S.

description: In general, this was a disappointing dinner. With time to spare in Mission, the menu looked promising. The hostess was delightful and greeted warmly. The restaurant was moderately full and there was plenty of space at a community-type table. To be fair, I only ordered two items from the starter section of the menu - the quail and seafood crepe. Both were overdone. The quail was dry and crepe was fried to oblivion, crusting the seafood pieces inside, and way too overloaded with stewed onions. Service was erratic with at least 3 different people taking care of me. $45 total including a glass of wine and tip. Perhaps this place shines elsewhere on the menu, but I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Charley C.

description:
I've always exclusively eaten at mom and pop Vietnamese restaurants.  Fancy decor seemed like a way to compensate for lack of authenticity.  That was until I was introduced to Mau through my Vietnamese friend.  She speaks fluent Vietnamese and talked to the head chef, who ran a restaurant in Vietnam before coming to SF.

The Hu Tieu, which is a rice noodle soup, has been my go to dish.  The broth is a very delicate and sophisticated mix of roast pork and shrimp with a hint of cilantro.  It looks like a very basic dish from the outside, but any foodie will be busy trying to deconstruct the different complementary flavors that make this dish so delicious.  The umami flavor of the roast pork makes my mouth water every time I think of this dish.

I'll definitely be visiting Mau on a regular basis, especially as the weather cools off.   Nothing says comfort food like a hot bowl of noodle soup on a cold day.
author: Craig S.

description: Driving through town decided to stop by for pho. We waited 15 minutes for a young John Stamos to come say hi (his name is Evon). Other guests had been sat and greeted long before. Didn't bring water like we asked and seemed to be more worried about his hair then us. The food came out finally and we were quite disappointed, the noodles were thick like spaghetti like. Food was alright and the customer service could have been better. Would have rather spent my money somewhere else not the best experience.
author: Maryanne M.

description: The interior and food quality are a step up from the average Vietnamese restaurant in SF but I can't say it was so wonderful that I'm a fan, though I'd gladly eat there again. That said, the gulf prawn clay pot was delicious and if you like greens, order it with the delightful baby bok choy. The papaya salad with prawns is good and the hue rolls are good but neither is crave-worthy. It was so busy during lunch hour that it took 1.25 hrs from walking in to walking out and it was quite loud.
author: Marina N.

description: Hip bun and pho. Yummy in my tummy.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
So I'm an educator who serves the Mission community. This summer I am teaching middle school students ethnic studies and gentrification. One of the things we do for fun however is go to local restaurants to try different types of food (we actually have been teaching a food diaspora from Africa (Ethiopian at Moyà Who was awesome, came to talk to the kids and were incredibly accommodating), through Asia, eventually across the Bering straight to Food from the Americas). 

So today we went to Mau for pho. They cannot sit ten kids in one spot so I tell them it's ok to sit three groups separately. They say ok except when they hear that students would be sharing and we would not be buying each student their own individual pho bowl they tell me it's something they cannot accommodate. Something about it just not being worth it considering the work involved and amount of smaller bowls used.

Now these students, as well as this program, are not some Google funded dream. Still, however, they deserve the best from their community and their educational experience. Shame on y'all at Mau for not being willing to give these kids the experience; I understand you are a business but it is obvious that money talks and is more important than the experience of these underserved and underprivileged middle school children.

In the end we went to Thanh Tam 2 down the street who had been much more pleasant and friendly (not to mention delicious!). Needless to say I will not be giving Mau my business out of principle. In these times of extreme gentrification in the Mission I only stand with businesses who actually care about this community over profit.
author: Lawrence F.

description: I'd never been here before and I was a bit worried about the service due to several of the reviews on here. However, I had nothing to worry about! The interior is very hip and the open layout of the restaurant still had enough separation to feel fairly private. We had a party of 7 and ended up waiting a while because it was extremely packed despite it being a Thursday night. The hostess was very friendly though and gave us continuous updates throughout the wait. Once we got seated the wait staff was attentive and helpful with all of our questions. We got our food sooner then expected and it was delicious! The one thing I would say is that the pho broth could have been a bit more rich and flavorful. Pretty reasonably priced if not a bit on the more expensive end of pho places but totally worth it with a great combination of food, good service, and ambiance.
author: Greg H.

description:
I'm really surprised that Mau doesn't have more reviews! It's in a fantastic location, the interior is awesome, the food is great, the portions are huge, and the prices are cheap. This is one of those lesser known places that is going to blow up in popularity. We had:

Pho Bo with beef balls ($9 + $1.50) - this was great, and I had so much leftover that I took it home, and it filled an entire bowl the next day.
Spring Rolls ($7) - 3 pieces cut in half = 6 pieces. Each piece was substantial, with entire whole prawns wrapped inside. Yum.
My friends got the Lemongrass Chicken ($10) and Five Spice Chicken ($10), and they really liked their dishes too.
 
Can't wait to come  back and try one of those fresh coconuts! (The price on these recently went from $5 to $6).
author: Cynthia W.

description: Ate clay pot chicken. Got food poisoning. And it tasted terrible. I feel gross and keep vomiting. Stay away!
author: S M.

description: Not even one star. I ordered the catfish clay pot and it tasted like tough fish doused in soy sauce, and my girlfriend ordered the tofu 'pho' that had no flavor whatsoever. Campbell's chicken soup has more flavor than this pho.
author: andrea k.

description:
I was traveling in Vietnam over the summer, and I would say that this is the most honest interpretation of vietnamese food I've had in the states. Most people think Pho when they go with vietnamese, but the real authenticity is in the Lemongrass Chicken. It has a good balance between the lemongrass and chili. Usually they add a hint of honey to sweeten the dish, which gives it a great overall flavor. 

It is a bit upscale, but I'd say this makes it all the better spot to do dinner or date. The prices don't reflect the decor, and I thought they were very reasonable for being so close to Valencia. $9.00 for an entree isn't bad at all. 

Beyond that, word on the street the pho is very good. I've been surprised there isn't more pho places in SF, so if that's what you are looking for this (might) be the place.
author: Jake B.

description:
My boyfriend and I are always saying, how can we live in San Francisco, one of the most dynamic, delicious food capitals of the world, and never be able to think of anywhere good to eat? Turns out that everywhere "good" is crazy expensive or out of the way. Except Mau, which has turned into our go-to going out spot in the city.

The food is really tasty and actually a really good deal for a trendy restaurant on Valencia in San Francisco. I go for the Pho Bo ($9!) when it's a chilly night outside and my boyfriend tends to go for one of the vermicelli bowls. We even had the frog legs last time we were there and really enjoyed that too.
author: Mirage G.

description: This was my first visit to Mau, I was there to satisfy a Pho craving (and boy was that craving taken care of). The Pho Ga at Mau is dynamite! It's better than any other PG in the city-hands down. I like it spicy and typically ask for siracha. Mau's chilli paste is off the hook; not just spicy but also packed with flavor.
author: Vivek N.

description:
Tofu pho is delicious! 

Also, get the papaya salad. It is such a good blend between salad, seafood, vinegar, and a bit of sweetness :)
author: Ari C.

description: Spicy spicy spicy! So good. The pho and the lemongrass! Hollaaaa! Lemongrass sauce is bomb too.
author: Dom P.

description: Food and ambiance was good, however the service was definitely not.  Ordered hue rolls for appetizer/starter, tables seated after us got theirs first.  we never received our appetizers and they already brought out the our main entree.  Major fail, we waited long enough already so we began eating our entree, brought us out the appetizers a few mins later "because of a mix up" but at that point we declined the appetizer.  Got the vermicelli with pork belly and meatball, perfect portions and tasted great. My fiance's clay pot fish was good but salty.
author: Ree'Ay I.

description:
Really amazing food here. It's solid Vietnamese fusion with a nice cocktail menu. I don't recommend coming here if u want some cheap fast pho - it has a different  experience to that. 

Homemade hot sauces are awesome as well.

Will come back again!
author: Erica H.

description:
I eat at Mau about once a week... sometimes more and on consecutive days... It's a problem. 

I've tried many of my friend's dishes but I'm stuck on the BUN GA XA with the crispy rolls. Honestly, I want to eat it every day. Anytime of day. 

(-1) Unfortunately the quality varies depending on who is in the kitchen. I've had the rolls served to me completely cold, they forgot the sauce on my take-out order, which makes the entire meal inedible. Really, it's disgusting without it. The chicken may or may not be caramelized and delicious, and I've had it lack any flavor. When it's good though, oh man is it good! 

(-1) The other issue is service. It's atrocious. Waiters have taken 20 minutes to take my order with few people in the room, which is pretty sad considering i get the same thing every time. Food is usually slower and god forbid you need more water. For the first time in years I found myself tipping 10%. It was just so damn bad and CONSISTENTLY bad. 

Also, it's a bit irritating when you call out your regulars as being, you know, regulars. :/ When I take multiple friends to lunch I don't need you commenting about how I was there yesterday. I'm aware! Shut up and take my usually generous tip you don't deserve!
author: pretty w.

description: Literally the BEST Pho I have ever had in my life. LiAlso, usually take out pho from other places leaves much to be desired, but even the takeout here is packaged in a way that makes it taste JUST AS GOOD AT HOME!!!! Literally. The. Best. 6 stars.
author: Carlos G.

description: My favorite vietnamese place. Yes it can be slow (packed or not) but if you're into great viet food you will love the style here. Good beer on tap and good rose wine.
author: David F.

description:
I got a yelp account just to review this place. I called at 6 for a small dinner for 2. Pretty quick options. One fried quail and 2 noodle dishes that have pre-made broth. 

I called at 6pm. They told me to pick up the food in 15 min. I get there 20min later. They said food wasn't ready, "it will be just a bit." 

Fast forward to 1 hour later, still no food. I checked with the server twice during this time and he very rudely said, "we're really busy ok? We're doing what we can." 

Meanwhile, at least 4 other quail dishes were served to patrons inside the restaurant and plenty of noodle soups. At the one hour mark, I realize they haven't even packed the food or prepared the quail. Are you kidding me? They served plenty of restaurant eaters who came well after me while I waited.

If you didn't have the broth pre-made, tell me that and I'll get something else. If you're busy and it will take an hour, tell me that I'll get something quicker.

Don't quote me 15 minute and treat me like shit for checking on my order when you're super late past that time. Is this food worth the wait? No. This was the only decent vietnamese food in the mission, but it's not worth that wait. Oh, and the beef in the bun bo was sitting in the broth still raw by the time we got home. 

I can't even enjoy my food because I'm so upset with the experience. I have never seen a place take my money and throw my patronage in my face.

Never coming here again.

Edit at 8:06pm 2/17/14: Upon seeing/eating the Bun Bo Hue, I realized the restaurant gave us pho (broth and noodles and all) with chili oil in it and told us it was Bun Bo Hue. TERRIBLE, TERRIBLE PLACE.
author: Dong Nghi H.

description: Love Mau soo much. Their Pho Tofu is the shit. Always easy to get a table
author: Gustaf A.

description:
I like my pho spots a bit more divey...

That being said, I went alone one afternoon when I was super hungover. I sat at the bar, ordered the hu tieu (pork, chicken, shrimp, ground pork, garlic chicken broth pho) and waited. They were a bit busy and I was in pain so I get it but it should not take over 25 minutes for some soup.  

The flavor was eeehhh ok. The flavors weren't as complex or strong as I would have liked but it did cure my hangover.
author: Melinda C.

description: I can't believe it has taken me this long to get to this restaurant seeing as how they have been here for four years and are less than a block from my house.  I had two lunches here over the weekend and was delighted each time.  Had the pho both times and was very happy with the food, pricing and service.  Ambiance is right where it needs to be for this level of food service.  Thanks for being part of our neighborhood!  You will be seeing lot more of me as I explore your menu.  Cheers!
author: Drew P.

description:
Nice little spot, good food, good price. We arrived around 9pm on a Friday and there was still a wait for 4 person tables (luckily we were only 2). The tables are packed a little tight so it takes some effort not to eavesdrop on a neighboring table's conversation.

Food wise, we shared an appetizer and two entrees and it was plenty of food. Total came out to $45 with tip, no drinks. Dishes we ordered below.

Papaya Salad: great to share, very tasty, surprisingly spicy
Bun Bo Hue: flavorful but very spicy. I would ask the waiter about it if you're unsure
Shaken Beef: it was alright, only dish that wasn't spicy, beef was very tender, but I would try something else
author: Emerson H.

description:
Mau was different than the Vietnamese food that I know and love. It was good, but not great. I had the 5 spice chicken rice plate and the spring rolls. Both were made with fresh ingredients, but somewhat lacking in spices and that true authentic flavor.

It's a trendy and somewhat upscale restaurant with some reasonable prices, but this is not the type of place I prefer to frequent.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I've been to Mau a few times and am never disappointed. I love their Shaken Beef dish ($16) and usually get leftovers out of it. The beef is tender and the salt and pepper sauce is the best.

Yesterday I had the House Salted Lemonade for the first time. I thought it was going to be sparkling lemonade with a salted rim. It was regular lemonade with salted lemons. It wasn't a great balance of tart, sweet and salty, as it was too much salt for me, even after I watered it down. 

Still, I dig their food.
author: Lauren F.

description: Ordered the noodle bowl with chicken thighs. It was good but something was missing....tasted kind of bland.
author: Reena T.

description:
Wewewewait! Before you dismiss your attempt to go to this restaurant (which is what my gf and I did initially...like 3 times), feel generous and give it a shot. This is because their pho (soup) is almost like out of a traditionally authentic Southern Vietnamese kitchen (and yes, I've eaten out of many of those kitchens). If you are a vegetarian, try their tofu pho and I swear, this is probably one of the best. Not greasy, the flavors are on point and just really really good. 

Spring rolls (vegetarian option) - wrapped in rice paper is SUPER FRESH and the stuffing inside - portabello mushrooms, vermicelli, lettuce, spices - was delicious. 

Shaken beef with salt and black pepper - is as close to an authentic Viet shaken beef dish one could get on Valencia street in this century. 

Beer: small selection of SE Asian imports. Wish they would have a more extensive SE Asian draft beer selection.

The flavors and experience were so good for my gf and I that we wanted to go back the next day! 

Try it!
author: Claude C.

description:
Best new restaurant I've found since forever!!! Absolutely love this place. 

I came across it on accident while walking through Valencia with some friends who were visiting from out of town. Randomly decided to grab a bite here. IT WAS AMAZING.

The staff was attentive and efficient. The food was seriously the best food I've had in a long time. I ordered a tofu veggie noodle bowl with a spring roll. Every part of the dish was killer! And the rest of my friends eating with me loved their various meat/seafood dishes too. 

Totally recommend this place! It rules and it's my new fave!
author: Rad S.

description: This was perfect for a light, but filling dinner. Service was great, and the food was wonderful! It was my boyfriends first time having Vietnamese food, and he really enjoyed it. Wish we lived here, because I'd be a regular.
author: Sevrina F.

description: Are there 6 stars!?? Great food, friendly staff and very reasonably priced. Can't go wrong with their spring rolls, a bun thang and a Hemingway!
author: Dino G.

description:
Growing up on Viet and especially Hue food, I'm always searching for the uncompromising real stuff and have usually been disappointed by SF's offerings. Mau however was pretty good. The food is fresh and flavorful. With a few tweaks it could be really great. 

Let me focus solely on the food. I'm judging from the standards of traditional Viet cooking. There are of course other standards but this seems most useful, because Yelp is generally awash with uninformed opinions about Viet and other ethnic minority foods. I would only ever write about food I know intimately.  

Bún bò hue: 3.5 /5

Some good things here: the beef shank is tender; noodles are thick with a good chew; the broth has the right whiff of fermented shrimp paste and a good kick to it. 

But....   the broth, savory as it is, could be better. Bún bò is lemongrass beef soup; the lemongrass should be abundant, bracing and aromatic. But here it was subdued. The broth also needed some acidity to balance it; in Vietnam this usually involves some combination of lime, tamarind, and/or pineapple (which adds a sweet-tart with the added bonus of enzymes that tenderize the meat). Some of the toppings were also incorrect. Sliced eye round steak is for ph, not bún bò. Same with thai basil; its anise-like notes goes with the star anise in ph broth but not with bún bò. Also, you will not find bún bò places in Vietnam serving lettuce as a garnish. The typical herbs include rau răm, red onions, and thinly sliced banana blossom. It's odd that they have banana blossom in one of their salads but don't serve it with their bún bò.   

Hue rolls: 4/5

The pork was flavorful and juicy; the herbs, greens, and rice noodle sheets were fresh. It would be even better if there were some lime and chilies in the fish sauce to balance out the overall flavor profile which was a little too one-note sweet. 

So overall pretty good. I didn't try the pho here, which seems to be their most popular dish. I'm at heart a Hue boy, always chasing a good bowl of bún bò...
author: Long L.

description:
This place is not delicious- it is tasteless and should be ashamed to call itself vietnamese food.

 My friend and i shared the veggie spring rolls - which were soy paper wraps filled with dry, tasteless noodles equally dry, tasteless mushrooms. The peanut butter sauce accompanying the rolls was not sweet, spicy, or tangy- the flavor fell flat on my tongue and was a disappointment. 

Then, we shared lukewarm tofu pho, with a bland broth. any vietnamese restaurant should know the key to good pho is the broth, and vegetarian broth is possible. Why put it on the menu if you cant achieve it? 



The only redeeming quality in this entire restaurant was the service. the waiter was kind and attentive as well as the bus boy.
author: Julia Z.

description: First time with the ever- famous Pho! Cool ambiance, cool spot. The broth had just the right amount of a spice kick. The reason for 3 stars is that I don't have other data points to compare it to. But pretty solid, overall.
author: Val K.

description: The Pho is awesome!  Especially the Bo Kho. Friendly staff and good wine cocktails.
author: Richie R.

description: Claypot tofu was ok: a bit too sweet for me.  Service was good.
author: Zachary S.

description: Excellent service, delicious soups!  If you have a cold...get any soup. They help!  Nice lighting..friendly staff...good prices.
author: Ara L.

description: I live nearby and find myself going a lot. It's comfortable, usually not much of a wait especially compared to other places in the Mission, and good food. These days I mostly order Bun, and maybe it's not authentic yada yada but whatever, I enjoy it. However... food and service does miss occasionally.
author: Ben K.

description:
This review for Mau is about an unfair policy, it has nothing to do with food nor customer service. The food, customer service, and the atmosphere is great in this place. 

We came for lunch to celebrate a Birthday and a Farewell for our co-workers and brought a cake with us. The restaurant has charged us $2/pp for our cake! I understand when they cut a cake and serve it to each customer; however, they just brought plates, a knife, and we had to deal with the cake on our own. I do not appreciate when a restaurant with your prices would nickel and dime customers. There were 8 of us, so we paid additional $16 for absolutely nothing. Just be aware, do not bring your own desert. As for Mau, you should be ashamed of charging customers for bringing a cake, considering that your average price for a lunch plate is $13.
author: V G.

description:
This the fifth time I've been here and I like it more and more each and every time. First, the food is very good. Not too heavy, lots of flavor, and generous portions. As Vietnamese places in sf it is in the top third. Second,  for a kind of trendy place in a very trendy neighborhood, the place is relaxed and comfortable, and the prices are very reasonable.
My Pho was good, not too many noodles, lots of fresh herb and a tasty broth. My friend had the tamarind prawns that were amazing. Perfectly balanced between sweet and spicy. 
It does get a bit noisy, but that is about the only criticism I can find. It is about time a good Vietnamese opened on Valencia
author: Matt A.

description:
4.5 stars! Went there for lunch and had fried roll and beef pho. The food was excellent. It was very fresh and the portions were big. 

I would also like to mention that everything was reasonably priced, especially for San Francisco. 2 orders of pho and a massive appetizer (the fried roll plate was so big I stopped the waiter and said "we didn't order this" as I presumed it was an entrée! lol) cost us about 30 bucks with tax.

The only reason I would take off a 1/2 star is because the place was understaffed. The service was great but the entire restaurant only had 2 waiters and as they scrambled around diligently, they just could not keep up. Note to owner: get more awesome members of your staff! 

I will be back!
author: R I.

description:
Their Pho is really good. A little too much meat for our taste, but very yummy. 
The service is a little frustrating though, it's kind of hard to get the waiters' attention. Can get quite busy too (long wait).
author: Roy F.

description: Their chicken pho is so tasty, which they serve in their ginger broth. The chicken (huge) wings come in an order of 4. They hit the spot every time. They are dry fried, extra crispy, with a tangy lime pepper dipping sauce. And the lemon grass pork is a must, the best I've had! Minus 1 star though for wait time. It took 30 minutes for a waiter to take my order one day, and that's after waiting to get seated. But it's yummy so i waited with hunger pains cus it was after work late night and i was starving. It was worth it, but now i drive by first to check if there's a line. If there's a line, i just go another day. But other than that. I love this place.
author: Sophia M.

description: I had on good authority that the BBH here was among the best, and sadly I cannot agree. The broth didn't really taste particularly apart from pho with some chili in it and the cuts of meat lacked the variety a good bowl of BBH should have. I wouldn't say it was objectively bad, but I was hoping for some SJ quality stuff and this was not that.
author: Misha T.

description: Hip and lively atmosphere, busy on the Thursday night I went. I ordered the Bun Bo Hue and was very satisfied; the chicken broth was as flavorful as beef broth. Ample amounts of beef and noodles. Service was attentive. I'll come again!
author: Robert Y.

description: Hipster Vietnamese place in the Mission. This place has staples like pho, rice plates, and vermicelli bowls, but it feels Epcot-ized. The food itself is pretty tasty, but it sort of lacks that sticky menu feel of the mom and pop pho shops in SF. Prices are generally higher too. And the line to get a table is long. It may be fine for others, but I wouldn't come out of my way to eat here value-wise.
author: J L.

description: Service sucks, the waitress sends her busboy to some of her tables instead of taking the time to see everyone. Takes forever to order and then forever to get the food. There's lot of options around for much better price and more authentic.
author: David L.

description:
The food is pretty good. Some of the better pho I've had in the city. The broth is flavorful but the hot sauces are unappetizing.  One has too much vinegar and the other too much oil. I ordered the veggie pho. It came with many bite size pieces of vegetables.  Finally a pho place that knows how to prep their vegetables!


This place food wise gets a 4-5 star approval,  however in typical Valencia fashion, our server seemed to have more important things than wait on us. Our pho came out missing a spoon and condiments plate, and the beers we ordered halfway through our meal didnt arrive until our check came out. I tried to get other staff members' attention but every one had a "thats not my job" attitude and ignored us. 

I really want to come back and try other food items but maybe on a day when I feel like being ignored.
author: Jacklyn H.

description:
Pretty poor experience at MAU yesterday for dinner with a group of 3. Extreme slow service and food was at most mediocre. 

We ordered two salads to share among three of us: Lotus root salad and papaya salad. The chef definitely forgot to put lotus root into our lotus root salad.. I called a server over to ask which part of the salad was lotus root, and he just pointed to a bunch of celery and said they were lotus root.. Either they found a new kind of lotus that is super duper thin with super duper small holes and taste like celery, or they were just BSing. The papaya salad was alright. The flavor did not stand out though.

Then two of us ordered beef pho (pho bo) and the other ordered the wonton noodle soup. I only had the beef pho and it was not great. The broth is very thin (you don't taste the glue-like texture of good beef bone broth) and does not have much flavor. Even adding the sauces did not help much. Also, they provided tiny lemon wedges instead of lime wedges in the pho garnishes, which was weird to me.

What really tipped me off was the wait time for the food on a not-so-crowded Tuesday night. After ordering, our salad was served rather fast. It took us 20-30 mins to finish our salad. We were hoping to get the entrees right after the salad, however had to wait for more than 30 mins for the noodles after they took away our salad plates. Altogether, it took more than an hour to get our noodles after ordering, which was ridiculous for noodles with pre-made broth.

Giving them one star for the portion size, and another star for the ambiance.
author: Christine C.

description: I must have ordered the wrong item.  I was visiting San Francisco and this place was packed.  I had noodles with tofu.  The problem with ordering tofu at many places is that it's fried and I forgot to ask for steamed tofu.  But even my boyfriend agreed that my dish wasn't a big deal.  I believe it's called tofu bun.
author: Maria S.

description: No service and soggy bread. I walked in at 12:15 and ordered a banh mi and iced coffee. 40 minutes later I have only received my coffee. When I catch the hostess' attention she brings me the check for the whole amount. I let her know  that I hadn't received my lunch. To her credit she was apologetic and got me my order in the next 5 minutes. But it was so late i had to head back to work. Now i'm sitting here at my desk with a sandwich that is soaked through with mayo and has obviously been sitting for 10+ minutes before I ever got it. Oh and I was charged full price. The coffee was good though.
author: Brice T.

description:
It started out not being a problem, being seated promptly. But, a whole half hour after ordering, when we had not even received our beverages for brunch, we had to poke one waiter about it, only to learn they had lost our entire order -- we had to reorder our first food of the day, with no written record of our original plans.

The restaurant interior never appeared entirely full, although we at least were given our drinks on the house. Also was given a rush order by that point. Still, a total wait time of 40 minutes (including the 10 minutes after our reorder) was spent before the first food was tasted... I ordered the Bun Rieu noodles in broth, which states it comes with minced pork, dried shrimp and tofu. Had a huge amount of tofu, but maybe three minced pork meat balls, and a whopping single piece of shrimp for such a deep broth dish. Minced pork was the first ingredient described in the menu -- I was expecting it to be the most prominent item.

Also, I had an Iced Artichoke Tea in honor of the Castroville/Monterey Artichoke Festival that was occurring that day. Probably the best thing I had there.

In summary, we won't be back. There's a better Vietnamese food restaurant a few blocks further down Valencia that has never forgotten about us.
author: Garett T.

description:
I've been giving a lot of 3 stars lately. I've decided to be more sparing of my 4 stars since places in SF tend to be SOO GOOD. 

This place is smack in the middle of all the Mission action. Parking can be tough, but the BART station makes this super easy to get to. This place doesn't take reservations, but on most weeknights, there should be plenty of seating. We were a table of 3 and got in with no issues. 

How is the food? It's not your typical vietnamese or pho place. I already had that mind set walking in (afterall, it is the Mission). 

We started with the Hue Spring Rolls. While I thought the rice wrap was a bit odd, the pork and sauce was cooked to perfection. It was super yummy. Then I ordered the Pho Bun Bo Hue. Be warned, it's pretty spicy, but in a good Tom Yum Goong type of way. The meat was quite fresh, but I wasn't a fan of the noodles they used and the savoriness of the broth. My husband had the meat/sausage bun. He wasn't a big fan. 

If it didn't cost $11 for a bowl of Pho, I wouldn't mind coming back here more often. But add in the clumsy and awkward wait staff, and this place dropped to a 'maybe i'll check it out if I'm really craving soup' place.
author: Winny F.

description:
Walked by this spot many times and refused to go in.  Being a vietnamese kid, I peeked in and judged the food (without tasting it) based off of the aesthetics of the place.   Great, another "bougie" spot popping up in the Mish-Mosh.  Well, I learned my lesson of being judgmental... 

After a drunken night following a friend's art closing, I stumble into the "bougie" vietnamese restaurant (it really isn't that 'bougie'.  I was just a judgmental prick.)  

I came to battle.  "Bring me your best Bun Bo Hue!" (from the region of vietnam where my father was from.) "Nobody makes Bun Bo Hue right, ever!"  (Aside from my mom, of course.  She's perfect.)

um...yeah.  I was too busy stuffing my face for anymore third-party voice overs.  

The Bun Bo Hue was AMAZING.  No shortage of meats or spices.  Rich flavors.  Piping hot.  If you are into spice and want to venture out and try something other than traditional Pho, go here and order a heaping bowl of Bun Bo Hue.  

My mouth is now watering.  Be right back...
author: Theresa D.

description: "I should've known better than to come to a trendy Vietnamese restaurant on Valencia st." First thought I had before stepping through the restaurant's doors and sitting down with my dinner date. We were seated extremely fast and the decor was minimal with hardwood countertops. It took a little bit of time to be greeted by our waitress and to order our food. I didn't think much of it, as the restaurant was starting to get busy, and I thought, "oh, they must be slammed. No worries." I ordered a cocktail (bloody something), the soy glazed chicken wings, and a bowl of Hu Tieu (rib eye, minced pork, chicken, and one shrimp) pho. My party and I waited a good 20 minutes prior to the appetizer coming out. Not soy-saucey or moist at all, were those wings. The app.' cleared the table and I was ready for some pho! I would say it took another 20-25 minutes to get my bowl. Seriously, a bowl of pho should never take 25 minutes to prepare and serve. Ever. The runner brought the pho to the table, but oddly, there wasn't any Thai basil, mint, lime, or jalapeño to accompany my meal. When I asked for at least jalapeño the runner said he'd get it. Never came back. The waitress wasn't very attentive either and only asked how our meals were when we were almost done. My friend asked the server to please take my cocktail off our bill, as we were finished and it never arrived. She apologized and we paid and left. I definitely will not come back to eat here again. Service was disappointing, the food was lackluster and expensive.
author: Josh S.

description:
This is a great casual place if you want to have a decent meal with no frills or if you need a great Vietnamese soup. Lots of stores and distraction in the neighborhood while you wait for a table (there will be a wait at the peak of dinner time).

I always go for the Pho Ga which is refreshing, hearty, and tasty. All the soups are pretty much a hit and you can't go wrong.

The Hue rolls are another favorite item of mine.

I would NOT recommend the Prawn dish. They don't cook it properly and though the taste is ok, you have to sit there and peel off every single prawn due to it's poor preparation.
author: Nasrin M.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night at 6:30pm and the place was pumping but was able to get a table for 2 soon after arriving. 
Considering their seating capacity is 77 people, it wasn't as loud as I expected it to be. The smell of Pho broth was good as we waited for our food.
The Goi Ga (chicken cabbage salad) was absolutely spot on and authentic - rather than a white cabbage they did use the purple but it was absolutely fantastic. 
We had a Pho Ga and a Pho Bo after that and I'd had to say the Pho Bo is better. Glad that the broth tastes different in both but Pho Bo was def better. Their hot sauce is their own - a twist on the Sriracha which was great along with the pickled onion.
It's a slight fusion but at $9 a bowl, you can't be complaining. 
I'll def come back :)
author: Van-Anh N.

description: Lov lov this place my favorite thing is the fish clay pot then the papaya salad. The pho ga is also great. Service has improved and always very crowded for dinner. The lemongrass tofu also stands out when your in a veggie mood I go here about 1 time a month since it's close to my yoga spot also great for dates though it gets really loud when crowded.
author: Ribec F.

description: I have been here several times for GF Pho.  Overall, it's good.  My only complaint is that their GF options are pretty limited and, at one point, they erroneously listed wontons as GF for their servers.  Fortunately, I questioned the item and they received clarification that it is NOT GF.  Sadly, the  last time i was there, the server still cited it as GF and i explained that I had asked about this in the past and the chef confirmed that it is not.  So...celiacs and others who refrain from gluten -- be cautious if they state the wontons are GF.
author: Min M.

description:
I came here while apartment hunting and was slightly skeptic since the place looked too upscale to have good food. However I ordered the Bun Nit Thuong and the lemongrass pork was excellent! Lots of meat and super tasty! 

I'll be coming back if im in the area!
author: Lillian C.

description: Well, what can I say.  I have lived in the area a long time and initially boycotted it, especially after they put Sunflower out of business.  Their Bun is great, which keeps me going back for take-out occasionally (it's the closest Vietnamese place to my apartment, and I'm a sucker for good Bun).  I feel like I'm using them for their Bun, actually, and putting up with everything else.  Unfortunately, I want to vomit each time I enter the place, as it's clearly ground zero for gentrification.  I hate being eyed by the young, self-conscious entrepreneur types, and the service (with the exception of one male server who works behind the counter, wish I knew his name!) is so snooty that it epitomizes what the neighborhood has become (and why we're moving!).
author: B E.

description: The food at Mau is delicious and the service there might be even better then the food... They served us generous portions and  were very attentive/accommodating to my girlfriend's many food allergies, which is a rare and lovely thing.
author: Alyssa E.

description: Absolutely LOVE this place. I've been here probably more than any restaurant in SF - mostly bc the location is great, but the food is always SPOT ON. I've tried quite a few menu items and everything has been great - tasty, fresh, cooked well, etc. but my absolute favorite is the Pho Bo (niman ranch beef pho). The broth has a ton of flavor, the beef is cooked perfectly, and the side add-ins are always fresh! Mau's not only offers great selections, but they're consistent, and the service is good! Definitely check this place out if you're in the Mission area. They get a bit busy during peak hours (7pm-8pm) but what restaurant DOESNT? I try and get in right before the crowd. But if you go solo, sit at the bar. The bartenders are all great and there's usually seating for one or two!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Hipster Vietnamese restaurant, cool ambiance but far from authentic Vietnamese food. Banh xeo was good. I got the bun bo hue and it had slices of pho beef in it. My sister got bun rieu that was lacking flavor, unfortunately
author: Sophia N.

description: This is definitely a cool spot. Be prepared to wait for a table during dinner hours, but the food is worth the wait. The chicken wings and mixed veggies are great choices. They have a great cocktail list, with some interesting combinations. I'd recommend this place for groups or a date.
author: Brooke D.

description: OK.  So I've become an IIFYM girl (if it fits your macros) and let's say budgeting has not been my strongest suit.  Armed with My Fitness Pal and a lowly expense acct for carbs, I ordered the BBQ CHICKEN rice plate (w/brown rice) and veggies.  I Also ordered a side of garlic bok choy.  Yum.  Very clean, took home the rice and the portion size (eyeballed) was about 3-4 oz of chicken.  The crowd = loud.  The service pleasant.  All in all recommended...not too expensive.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
Casual and delicious Vietnamese place with decent menu choices, drinks and reasonable prices.

The plates are fairly large, and we had hefty leftovers from two appetizers, an entree and side, shared between two. We had the spring rolls (standard and good) and mango salad with pork belly (surprisingly large and filling, this could be the dinner). The lemongrass tofu with rice was flavorful and hearty, "twice-cooked" means fried so it is definitely not your light veggie dish. The "garlic sauted greens of the day" was bok choy and delicious and also not small. The homeless guy on 16th got a good size take away bag for dinner...

We were also looking for a post Dolores Park outdoor meal on an unusually warm evening, and Mau has a few four-tops on the street on Valencia!  There is often a wait during peak dinner hours, but we were able to walk in at 8:30 pm on a Thursday.
author: Aki N.
