description: So we came to Mau for our first time because someone recommended us to come here. The atmosphere was lively and the food overall was okay, nothing spectacular. What was really noteworthy about my experience was how mediocre it is.
author: Ashby D.

description:
Solid Food but service left a lot to be desired. I honestly wanted to rate it higher because the food was honestly great but the service was so bad that I won't go back. 
Just a snapshot - server forgot our drinks, served 2 out of three dishes to party of three while last person waited 5 minutes for their meal, gave us check then never came back to get credit card (we had to ask another server to help us so we could get out of there). 
Anyway, maybe we just got bad egg but still reflects really badly on a place that could be great all round.
author: Caroline A.

description:
Mau is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant.  I'm probably there weekly and am never disappointed!

Mau is the (newer) sister of Tin in Soma. The decor at Mau is much swankier than at Tin; the food is about the same although the portions (and prices) are smaller at Tin. Love both places, although the ambiance is much better at Mau.  

I rarely deviate from ordering cha gio (crispy rolls) followed by pho ga. The crispy rolls  are a bit larger than what are served at other Vietnamese joints, which (in my opinion) allows the flavors to come through. No problem if you ask for more lettuce leaves. Yum. Definitely order them over the spring rolls (which are bland, and are the only thing we've tried on the menu that has fallen short of expectation.) 

The owner(s) are often out and about on the floor at Mau -- they are super sweet. 

I'm removing one star because (and it has happened more than once) it has taken over half an hour to receive our food after placing our order. Sometimes it seems like a few of the waiters are half-stoned.  

Overall, I highly recommend this friendly neighborhood place.
author: chloe w.

description: Food is great and excellent value for money. Bar staff are efficient and friendly but table service is often slow and very unprofessional. Recommend the catfish claypot curry
author: Hannah D.

description: Such a "cool" spot to enjoy Vietnamese Food! Great music, vibe, food, service. Really enjoyed their non-broth chicken bowl as well -
author: Herald A.

description: The food was pretty decent, ambiance was fun. The only complaint I have is of the service there. There's definitely needing of improvements. We ordered the "hue rolls" starter along side our main entrees, waited a good amount of time and mentioned to server them 3 times that we haven't received our starter yet. They instead brought our entrees out and half way through our entree we again had to mention we never got our starter so we cancelled it.  I wish I got to try them :(. O wells. This was for dinner by the way.
author: John D.

description:
I really liked this place.  the setting is stylish and the food is fantastic, had amazing bahn mi and banana blossom salad with fried eel.  really delicious.  

It's not 'cheap eats' and it's not 'quick hole in the wall fill your belly' -- it's very nice food made with nice ingredients.
author: Jaina S.

description: I was excited to try this place, #1 because of the food, I kept hearing rave reviews and #2 because the venue seemed pretty cool (large space with seating outside and window seating to people watch). The food was great, the service not so much. Our waiter missed one of our appetizer orders, and never returned to our table to check-in on us. We had to tell the busser our second app was missed when he came to clear the table, at which time it was too late given the main entree shortly followed. The next mishap was when I ordered my second drink, midway through our entree. Never saw the drink until I was almost done with my meal. I would definitely eat here again, but next time at home ordering my food to go!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
This review is just for the Bun Bo Hue, as it's the only thing I've ordered here. It's amazing! I ordered it to go and while walking home, I could smell all of the flavors coming out of the bag. Once I got home and put all the ingredients together, I was actually impressed. Normally, many restaurants don't make Bun Bo Hue correctly and it's not very flavorful. However, Mau does an amazing job! The broth is super flavorful and the ingredients are really fresh. 

I've been craving another order ever since that visit. My roommate and I tried to eat there on a Sunday for dinner but they were closed. It's also a little pricey but they make this dish very well!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I'm not claiming to be a pho connoisseur; but I am. I know a good bowl of pho. One that has the complex flavors from a day of simmering over low heat. Rich anise, oxtail, cinnamon, ginger etc all balancing yet fighting one another for your tastebud's attention. Assisted with plates of thai basil, beansprouts, and jalapenos to create your own culinary experience; saracha and hoisin to deepen the textures. This was not such a bowl or experience. My dinner companion described it as watery. 

Unfortunately to my knowledge this is the only pho option in the Mission.
author: Makoto L.

description: Been here four time already. Only tried broth noodle soup so far and I liked it. Bun
author: Minhnistah M.

description:
This place is actually pretty delicious. 

Server: Earl was super great. Energetic, honest and friendly.
Food: Deliciously authentic
Overall Experience: chill, relaxed, comfortable, go now!
author: Tom T.

description: Great value! HUGE noodle bowls for $10-$12. I'm a big eater and had trouble finishing mine. Would consider sharing one next time and doing some appetizers to supplement. Recommend the lemongrass pork noodle bowl without broth. The pork was thin and crispy, super delicious.
author: Andrew S.

description: Tofu mushroom spring rolls and lemongrass tofu rice dish were delicious! Great spot for lunch. Reasonable prices and really nice service. Solid choices on the menu--will try them for dinner soon.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Awesome food. We had the pork rice paper rolls, crepe, and two noodle dishes.  Everything was excellent, great atmosphere. Our waiter Jorge was the friendliest and so helpful!  You could tell him loves his job which has a direct impact on the customer experience.  We will definitely be back again based on the food and Jorge's service.
author: Jen N.

description:
Yum.

I'd never even heard of this place and was pleasantly surprised by the whole experience.  Lots of really tasty food for the price and the service is pretty quick and friendly.  We got a couple beers and were stumped on what else to order so we let our waitress take over.  We ordered the papaya salad which was huge and so flavorful.  The rolls we got (maybe cha gio? don't remember exactly) were awesome too - a lot of food here as well.  We were going to order a noodle dish but were too stuffed with only those two dishes!

Will be back to try more nomminess.
author: Laura B.

description:
We sat at a table at the window facing Valencia Street.  Great people watching.  We had the Hue Rolls first.  They were delicious. My main dish was a bowl of vermicelli noodles with grilled pork.  It's what I usually order at a Vietnamese restaurant.  The noodles were $11; more expensive than most other restaurants.  I wondered how Mau could improve a relatively simple dish to justify the cost.  Well, I was pleasantly surprised.  The serving was huge.  The vegetables were very fresh, plentiful and nicely sliced.  Most importantly the pork was of a very high quality.  It was tender and very nicely spiced.  The dish was delicious and well worth $11.  

We look forward to eating at Mau again.
author: Andrea P.

description: I've lived in the mission for years and this is my favorite restaurant.  The perfect price point for an inexpensive dinner with great service.  The lemongrass chicken and tofu pho are amazing.  Get a young coconut too!
author: Kevin K.

description: Almost as good as home at my parents place. Awesome pho bo soup, filling of the summer spring rolls has too much vermicelli and too less meat if you ask me. In overal, good stuff & super friendly staff.
author: Khanh L.

description: The food is great, great pho and some good noodle dishes..Service and waiting time could a little bit longer especially on weekend nights. My favorite is the Bo Kho.
author: Daniel F.

description:
Three of us went here for dinner on a Friday night.  We arrived a little after 6 p.m. so we were able to get a nice table at the back.  The place filled up in 30 minutes.
The service was good - prompt and friendly.
One of us loves pho so he ordered the beef pho.  Another of ordered seafood and vegetables in fried egg noodles that were shaped like a bird's nest.
I had the grilled pork chop with pickled carrots and cauliflower and jasmine rice.
We all enjoyed our meals.  My partner said the pho was not the best he's had but it was good.  Our friend liked his bird's nest.
My pork chop was bony but properly cooked.  The dipping sauce that came with it was a little sweet and provided a nice balance to the savory pork chop.
One minor complaint: We ordered frogs legs as an appetizer, but it did not arrive until we were eating our main courses.  My companions said the legs tasted good.
Mau is not a authentic Vietnamese restaurant but it's a good fusion place.  We would return.
author: Philip C.

description: What a sad excuse for customer service. Caucasian chick needs to word her excuses better. I understand that food comes out when it's ready, but you don't need to be rude about it. They probably forgot to place the order, but it would've been nice to hear them own up to it instead of wasting my time and patience. They initially gave us someone else's food and when our actual food came out half an hour later, it wasn't even fulfilled accurately. Too bad... I was excited to eat here. Nice try.
author: Tim G.

description:
I really like this place the Pho is awesome and the staff was chill and really friendly.
Jesseca was great!
author: Charlotte S.

description: Mau is the absolute. The garlic noodles, garlic bok choy, and tofu pho are my go to's and absolutely delicious vegan/vegetarian options. The service is always great, though sometimes it can get busy and therefore slow. I always try to go before 6 to miss the rush. The ambiance is good- it's only Valencia so very hipster chic. Mostly affordable, but their fresh coconut is $6 which is crazy! ALSO- make sure to use cover to pay! Just sign in when you get there, let your server know, and leave when you're done without waiting for a bill! Makes up for the lost time when your food takes too long. Overall delicious food and always a good time.
author: Meghan Y.

description:
Large portions, decent/reasonable prices (for San Francisco), awesome ambiance/environment and location.

The food is somewhat Americanized. They differ slightly from the traditional Vietnamese style, but the flavors are still there.

I've tried:

 - Pho bo (beef noodle soup) - really good, tastes authentic. I recommend getting this.
 - Bun rieu (crab/shrimp tomato noodle soup) - Not very authentic, but flavors are there. Was also a bit too salty.
 - Bun thit nuong with imperial rolls "noodle salad with marinated pork" w/ fish sauce - also pretty good and tasted authentic. The meat and imperial rolls are served on a bed of cold rice noodles and lettuce, would've been better if the noodles were hot or at least warm.
 - Goi ga ( chicken cabbage salad appetizer) - non-conventional ingredients but tasted authentic. 

You can expect Mau to be very busy during dinner on a weekday and lunch and dinner on a weekend. The wait is usually not too bad. My only problem with Mau is the lack of service when they are very busy... perhaps they are under staffed? During one of my many visits to this restaurant, my bf and I waited almost an hour for our noodle bowls to come out and our weekend lunch ended up taking almost 2 hours... The owners were really apologetic and kind, so we weren't angry about the lack of service, we were just kind of disappointed.

Despite that negative experience, we did return and we do plan on eating here regularly in the future. It looks like the service is improving, so I'm quite happy about that.

Overall, Mau is a great Vietnamese-fusion restaurant to grab a casual meal. The portions are large and the prices are good ($8-15). The restaurant is also very clean, modern, and located in a great part of the mission, the lovely and lively Valencia St.
author: Monica T.

description: Best pho I've had in a while! Not the biggest portions - but price reflects that. The broth was soo good! I was almost tempted to drink the rest of the bowl even after finishing the chicken and noodles (pho ga)
author: Sarah L.

description:
A+ for having Bun Cha Ha Noi. A-ish for the dish itself!

All told, I had a good time here, but I prefer less-polished if I'm just having Vietnamese food in the 'hood. That said, if I wanted Vietnamese but was going with, say, someone's parents (depending on the parents), I'd probably kick it up a notch and come here.

It's always lively in here, and I really appreciate it pepping up the block in that way. I also appreciate it being more mid-rangey on the pricier new Valencia Street.

Can I review the sandwich board sign outside? Because it probably has the best *grrrrroooooan* meets "ha! ha!" puns. A+ for those, too.
author: Tara R.

description:
So good.

Wish it was a little cheaper but it's really tasty. Their lemongrass pork is flavored well, and just as importantly cooked well. Nicely caramelized without being over cooked. That in a hue roll with shiso & fried shallots, not to mention the more interesting rice paper? Hell yes. Such a great appetizer.

Their salads pack quite a flavor punch. I'm someone who likes intense flavors, and their eel salad certainly does. The chicken is also delicious. Papaya salad is less good compared to the other two.

The lemongrass option broth in the pho is redonk, so much flavor.

So happy they opened up!
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I tried this place for the first time through Door Dash. My first order was the Hu Tieu in broth (Pho). It was so good that I ordered it a second time just days apart (again through Door Dash). 

The wrong order was delivered. They gave me the Hu Tieu Kho (no broth). I called Door Dash and they quickly delivered the correct item. 

Long story short, I appreciate that both the delivery service and the restaurant rectified the mistake without any fuss. I also got to try something new and it was very delicious. I found a new favorite dish from this place. It's pricier than most Vietnamese restaurants, but the quality and taste make it worth it.
author: F D.

description:
This place just continues to get better.  The staff are friendly, and helpful.  The owners have a presence in the place and have created a warm and inviting neighborhood spot for groups, couples or those dining on their own.  The menu has evolved to offer something for everyone with Pho, noodles, salads and a great beer and wine selection. Alcohol free options include the salted lemonade where you won't miss the booze.  

Last night I had the Pho Reiu, whose broth was a rich tomato broth that was the best thing I've ever eaten there.  

This place is heaven!
author: Unemployed D.

description: Great veggie pho -- but give it an hour to cook, it takes forever! Also love the rice roll appetizer done up vegan style.
author: Be F.

description:
To be sung to Swedish House Mafia's  "Don't You Worry, Child"

There was a time
I used to eat Vietnamese
In the Tenderloin
It was cheap, didn't need a loan
Those days are gone
Now Valencia has Mao
I hear the throngs
From the hipsters who look forlorn

Walked into Mao after a short wait
There's where I had my first heartbreak
I still remember how it all changed
The waiter said,
"Don't you worry, don't you worry, child.
Your food is on its way to you
Don't you worry, don't you worry now"
Yeah.

But we worried, and we worried, child
They couldn't fill our order too
Yea we worried, yea we worried now
Yeah

There was a time
I ate rice of a different kind
It ruled the world
I thought it never could go wrong
But Mao's is soggy, it's mushy to the core
Like it's sitting in water making porridge

They didn't have our tasty app choice
But only told us after waiting
They need to figure out how to change
The waiter said,
"Don't you worry, don't you worry, child.
Your food is on its way to you
Don't you worry, don't you worry now"
Yeah.

Oh, oh, oh!
Oh, oh, oh!

Your food is on its way to you
Your food is on its way to you
Your food is on its way to you

And we worried, and we worried, child
Hours later and we paid the bill
For some noodles, for some noodles, child
Yeah!
author: Christopher Y.

description: I have been to Mau a couple of times and I've always enjoyed my meal!  I am a vegetarian and I love the Tofu Bun, with a fried egg roll on top.  It is more expensive than other Vietnamese places in SF, but its location on Valencia and nice atmosphere make it a great place to meet up with friends for a weeknight dinner.  In addition, you can pay the bill via the Cover App which is very convenient (and gives you a free ten dollars the first time you use it).
author: Sophie S.

description: Super fast and attentive service. The Garlic noodles are some of the best I have ever had. The meatballs with baguette were also excellent. Highly recommend the chicken wings as well. Honestly don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu
author: Danielle B.

description: Really great flavor. Ordered the pork chop which was so good and the hue rolls. The server recommend the appetizer. Really good choice. Walking out of here stuffed.
author: Michael M.

description: Delicious Vietnamese food on Valencia at a reasonable price. The owner Hung is a super nice guy. The lemongrass chicken thigh noodles without broth is my go to.
author: Ezra B.

description: I had dinner here tonight and I was blown away by how authentic the food was. Walking in to this place at first, I thought it looked like a pretty Americanized vietnamese place, so I wasn't expecting much. They had a lot of traditional Vietnamese dishes that many Vietnamese restaurants in the Bay Area don't serve such as Banh Xeo and Bun Bo Xao. The options alone made me excited. But the food was what really won be over. Their five spice chicken is perfect and true to what traditional vietnamese five spice chicken should taste like. I also had their catfish which I loved. The prices were also decent in terms of SF food prices.
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Not super impressed with this place.

Came in around 2 on a Saturday and the place was pretty packed. Waited for about ten minutes before someone greeted us. When we finally got a table, service from the start was slow. Took forever for someone to bring us menus and water. Server, although he was super nice, was slow on coming in to take our order and bring us drinks. I won't ding him too much as the place was pretty busy and it looked the servers had too many tables assigned to their sections. 

We ordered the BANH XEO (shrimp, calamari and pork crepe with fresh herbs) to start. Not very good. There wasn't a whole lot of flavors, seafood was sparse and the crepe was drenched in oil.

BF ordered beef pho and I ordered the won ton noodle soup. We both liked our soups; decent portions and good flavors but for the price ($9-10, for a bowl of soup!), not really worth it. 

There are other places in the city where you can get awesome pho/won ton soup for a fraction of the price so unless the BF has a strong desire to try this place again, probably will not be coming back.
author: Pauline T.

description:
I WANT TO EAT HERE EVERY DAY!

We ordered:
Bun Bo Hue
Clay Pot Fish

I had never tried either dish but my BFF insisted on them

The Bun Bo Hue was so flavorful and delicious! It was a little too spicy for me and I had to take breaks but it was worth it! Tasty and filling.

The clay pot fish was delicious, a sweet caramelized fish sauce (?) coating! It was very hot temperature-wise but so tender and delicious I couldn't help but burn my tongue. 

The waiter was sweet and I never had to ask for water. I felt the dishes were VERY reasonably priced at about $10 each.

I was so happy to find this gem and can't wait to go back!
author: Alexandra H.

description:
Lately I've become quite the pho-natic. Looking to get my fix, I wondered into this Mission spot after boozing and dog watching at Dolores Park, and they were the friendliest cats, letting us in and serving us drinks before they even opened for the evening.
 Their menu selections run pretty standard to your local Vietnamese restaurants. I've tried both the Pho Ga and the Pho Bo (I prefer the Pho Ga, the Pho Bo had too many onions, leaving me with the death breath that 2 brushing sessions could barely cut through.) Their service is what sets them apart from their counterparts. Friendly conversation, helpful suggestions, and knowledgeable staff make all the difference in my book.
author: Danielle L.

description: We stopped at Mau while walking down Valencia because they had a $2 Soju shot special that I just couldn't pass up. After tasting the Soju we wound up staying for a beer as well. Our bartender was super nice and helpful, and if we hadn't just eaten breakfast I would have loved to try some of their delicious sounding pho.
author: Scott H.

description:
I've been here twice. But the most outstanding thing is that their garlic chicken soup cured my cold. Seriously. I'd had the cold going on THREE weeks! I ordered the soup for take-out, it was ready when I walked over (15 minutes later), and it was delicious and garlicky. Hit the spot. Immediately, I felt better, and I'm pretty sure it cured me (as the next day I was well). Of course, it could have been that my cold had run its course, but that's just unimaginative.

The other time, I ordered pho. Very good. We also got the spring rolls. My kid loved it. And they're also kid-friendly. No strange looks -- the opposite, in fact: super polite.

Thinking about going there again tonight for dinner. Yum.
author: Bella S.

description: I love this place because it's clean, fresh, and super yummy! The bun bo hue is the best, spicy and flavorful. Yes it's not authentic because it doesn't have the pork blood or whatever else but it's really the broth that sets it apart from regular pho! I recommend this place!
author: Tham H.

description: Good price, unpredictable service, but yummy food!!! Love their vegetarian pho and vermicelli dishes.
author: Christina C.

description: Not very good pho.. Bland and broth was not savory enough. Very disappointing if you are craving for vietnamese pho and been around the block. Hue rolls were interesting and decent.
author: Jayne C.

description:
Too bad there's no zero-star option in Yelp. Went there for "quick lunch" that turned into a 90-minute circus. All staff seems to be clueless and should not be working in a high-volume restaurant. Apparently our food was sitting on the counter for a while and needed to go back to the kitchen to be rewarmed.

Worst ending: they were cheap enough to accept our money. Too bad again there's no negative tip option.

Yeah not going there again. Call Ramsey or something to show you how to run a place.
author: Alex L.

description: The food was very good. Flavorful, fresh, and juicy. I've never had Vietnamese food like this particular dish (even in Vietnam). I would highly recommend. Moderately busy for lunch, nice decor, great service and staff, reasonable prices.
author: Andrew R.

description:
***Low Down***
This is a chic Vietnamese restaurant in the heart of the Mission that is unlike other Vietnamese joints in the city.  Walking in you get that hipster vibe of the neighborhood and the patrons who eat here.  The food can either be described as traditional Vietnamese or Californian Vietnamese depending on your past experiences.  They offer all your standard dishes like pho, bun bo hue, vermicelli noodle bowls, rice plates, springrolls, etc. and then some. .  Alcoholic drinks consist of wine and beer only. The service is hit or miss. I've had impeccable service on some visits and less than impeccable on others. Parking is definitely hellish in this part of the Mission. 

***Show Down***
I've eaten here many many times with friends and by myself (which I almost never do, so it says a lot that I dine here by myself). It's a great meeting place with friends for a terrific affordable meal before going out. I've had almost everything on the menu. The pho is spectacular as well as the bun bo hue. By far, my favorite is the bun thit nuong, grilled lemongrass vermicelli!  So good :-).  Can we talk about the fabulous house made sriracha and lemongrass hot sauce?  So good they should bottle it. I'll buy a case. My last two times dining here I've had some of the most attentive and jovial service I've ever had. I have to give kudos to our server, Don 'Avon, I believe is how you spell his name (pronounced like Donovan).  You rock, Don' Avon!  He gave great recommendations and was all smiles. I can't sing the praises of this place enough!  You have an eternal fan! :-)
author: Tara T.

description: Great atmosphere. Price isn't bad $9-$15 it seems is average. I'd come back. I noticed it had a good light setting with minimal noise but not to quiet that it makes conversation impossible without a listening ear.
author: Matthew F.

description:
I came here one night for a group dinner recently, it had a very inviting/warm vibe for a rainy night. The spring rolls were pretty much the same bland thing I've had over and over again at other places, so nothing really new. Papaya salad was $8 and fresh, but come on...$8? 

I ordered the pork shoulder rice plate and it was very tasty, super filling...pretty good value for $9. 

However, the food took pretty long to get to my table. We had a modest table, of like 6 people...and having been the first to order my food came last, by at least 10 minutes. It was awkward for my friends who insisted on waiting to eat because my food didn't get there, their food was getting cold. I think they all ordered the various noodle bowls and said it was satisfactory. 

I guess overall what I'm trying to say is the price kind of reflects the location and ambiance of the place, and not necessarily the food.

Otherwise the staff were nice and accommodating, but should get their timing better.
author: Rachel W.

description: Sorry Mau just didn't do it for me. The pho was perfectly fine. Nothing to write home about but certainly decent. The hair in my spring roll probably just grossed me out and set the tone for the meal. Thankfully said spring roll was pretty meh so I wasn't too eager to devour it. Overall it was uninspired pho (that you could find at any Vietnamese place) set in hipster surroundings..
author: Ritu K.

description: The food is this place is excellent.   We have been here twice and we have not been disappointed.  The place is crowded and loud but you get sited pretty fast.
author: Salvador F.

description:
I was dying to try this restaurant. It's near to my place and I would see it everyday on my way home back from work, always full.  Decided to go last week and... AFFFFFFFFF!!!  AWFUL service. I mean, really awful! The waiters have no clue what they're doing. My friend asked something about the apetizer we had ordered and the kid basicaly stuck his finger on our food to "show" and explain. Gross.  Plus we were waiting forever for someone to come take our drinks order. The place wasnt that full, so I didnt understand.

The food is ok, but not better than any other Vietnamise restaurants Ive been so far. Actually, the Claypot was kinda weird....   

No chance I`ll be back there, unfortunately, cause I love Vietnamise food and this would be a convenient spot....
author: Paula C.

description:
Affordable, high(er) quality Vietnamese food. 

Clean.

They need to do something with the acoustics as it gets a little loud.
author: Sanaz E.

description:
I love their vegetarian bun (noodles in broth).  It's my favorite in the mission, now that sunflower closed.
Ambiance is chill and not formal.  Servers are nice and helpful.
author: SF D.

description:
tl;dr: The service here is not just horrible, but willfully horrible. The food isn't even good. Don't go here. 

We were abandoned by our waiter, given the wrong order, had our correct order come out with the wrong modifications (we asked for egg noodles and they gave us whatever the default is). We waited over an hour after ordering for our food in the end. Probably waited 15 minutes for water and 15 more minutes to order after that. The same thing happened to the table on our left, except they only got their food as we were leaving and they sat down before us. The table on our right was sympathic to our two tables so they offered to pass their hot sauce down the line of tables after three separate staff members ignored our request.

This isn't even the worst part though. They actually don't want to improve. When I brought up the service to the manager in the middle of the meal he found (they had never shown up) and then comped our spring rolls, which was fine. They were pretty bad spring rolls, but who cares. Then the meal got increasingly worse after that and I got up to relay the experience to him. I wasn't looking for a comp. I just wanted to provide feedback so he could have the information to remedy the systemic service issues. He said, "We're busy. I don't know what you want me to do." I said, "Don't you want to improve the service? This is probably the worst service I've ever experienced in a sitdown restaurant." He said, "I comped your spring rolls. I don't know what you want from me. We're busy." So I said, "Fine, if you have no interest in getting better or listening to customer feedback, that's cool. I'll get out of your way then." He then feigned chasing me down the restaurant and I asked him to please leave me alone. He had no interest in doing better in the future, just wanted to get rid of me as quickly as possible and probably attempt to avoid the bad review he knew was coming. He didn't comp anything else (but seriously that was not what I was after, I just think that fact is relevant to the review) and we still tipped 20% because this isn't our servers fault -- it's the restaurant itself. 

Also, the food isn't even good. I didn't finish any of my dishes. They were bland! That's why I was asking essentially every staff member who walked by for hot sauce. Too bad no one ever gave it to me besides the table next to me.
author: Ellen C.

description:
I went there 4 times now. Never disappointed.
The location is great, the place looks great inside, the table are fairly big and confortable.
The noise level is not too high so it's easy to talk to people without having the yell and make them repeat.
The service is pretty good, and the food is really good and cheap!
author: Jonathan P.

description:
I got the catfish clay pot and it was extremely good. I'm always looking for good and interesting restaurants, and trying to give well-distributed reviews, but this one gets a 5 for a mix of great service, fun casual atmosphere, great prices, a wonderful menu that makes me want to come back as soon as possible to try more things (especially the noodles, which I hear are great), and really really tasty food. There aren't a ton of vietnamese restaurants in the city (relative to many other cuisines...), and I've had mixed experiences at some of the others. I'm not particularly knowledgeable about vietnamese cuisine, so I can't speak to its authenticity, but what's important to me is that Mau creates a broad-yet-cohesive menu of delicious, well spiced, well-balanced, well-portioned dishes and meals, and provides them efficiently and consistently (this claim I'm taking from my friend who has been here regularly and says they're always as good as they were on our date).

We walked in at 6:30 and there was no wait, but by the time we left it was crowded with a decent number of people waiting, so get there a bit early if you're hungry.
author: Chris M.

description: Absolutely loved this place! They have a great ambiance and friendly service. We ordered the vegetarian spring rolls - normally they are not flavored and taste quite raw. At Mau, they were really well made and bursting with flavor. I also had the vegetarian pho. It came in a giant bowl and was wonderful. I loved the vegetable broth and the combination of vegetables in it. It's so difficult to find vegetarian pho - this place totally hit the spot. Every time I'm in SF again, I'll be sure to make a trip here.
author: Maddy K.

description:
It was the day after the Super Bowl and I was whistling a tune of glee walking around a city full of despair and disbelief when I noticed the old Wings joint on Valencia had been converted into a trendy looking Vietnamese place.  I scanned the menu posted by the door and decided to give it a try.  I got the vibe that they were going for a more down to earth Slanted Door which was perfectly OK with me.  I knew I was getting the Shaken Beef within seconds of glancing over the menu, having had it at that other waterfront place a few times and always enjoying it.  I sipped a tasty Mircobrew (of which I have completely forgotten the name) while passing the time before the meal came. 

The dish arrived looking pretty simple.  A mountain of brown rice surrounded by cubes of tender beef with a cold salad of some sort.  I began nibbling away at the components separately and enjoying it.  I then decided to mix the whole dish together and eat it at once and it went from being a great dish to being an excellent dish.  The contrasts of the hot rice and cold salad worked great with the succulent beef.  I devoured that plate without even thinking about anything but the fabulous meal in front of me.  

So why only four stars?

After the plate was licked clean the wait began for the check to arrive.  The place had unexpectedly filled to capacity and both servers were severely overwhelmed by the influx of hungry guests.  After about ten minutes I placed my card at the edge of the table and expected the waiter to take the hint that I was ready to go.  But no.  It took at least another ten minutes after that for the check to arrive.  

This place easily would receive that fifth star had they not been so understaffed.  I understand it was quite unexpected on such a low key Monday and I intend on eating there regularly as long as I still dream of the amazing Shaken Beef.
author: Andy Z.

description:
We definitely enjoyed our experience at Mau's. The service was good. We arrived early, 7:15ish and were immediately seated. Over the course of our dinner it became crowded and we could see there was a wait. 

We ordered the deep fried quail which was super tasty. I had the beef pho noodles in broth and it was delicious. Very flavorful. My husband had the grilled Neiman Ranch vermicelli noodles. On the lighter side, more of a salad and very good. 

I would eat there again which says a lot because we're very picky. The portions were nice size. I took some of mine home for leftovers. 

If you like Vietnamese food, you'll definitely like Mau.
author: Laura R.

description: Visited on a Saturday around 8pm and our party of two was seated almost immediately. My friend's pho looked and smelled delicious and my lemongrass tofu plate was tasty. Great place for veg heads! Also reasonably priced! (we both ate for less than $25)
author: Maureen B.

description:
Good food, great quality meat, bold flavors, decent prices, great location. I like Mau a lot. 

Their pho is delicious though I prefer the one at Jasmine Garden (best broth I've had in a long time). 

Papaya and banana blossom salads are packed with flavor. Spring roll is good but pretty standard. Get the noodle fish with lemongrass chicken and add grilled shrimp. Bomb.
author: Elad C.

description:
I never bother to write a review on yelp.  But after having gone to Mau tonight, I just had to.  Mau is definitely going to be my new go-to Vietnamese place in the Mission.  I've had tons of pho, in the city, in Oakland, San Mateo, San Jose.  And plus, I've grown up with Vietnamese friends all my life.

This is definitely one of the best phos I've ever had.  Broth was superbly authentic, flavorful and not just a bowl of salt.  We had the Vietnamese Crepe too.  Perfectly crunchy and not soggy.  Super fresh vegetables.  It's a real gem.  Don't let the looks deceive you.  It's definitely not a lame fusion place.  Authentic.  Amazing.  Just the Vietnamese that the Mission needed!
author: Mike L.

description: I was looking on yelp for a good place to have lunch. Came across Mau and read a few reviews. All I can say is that the lemon grass chicken was amazing! Chicken was cooked very well. Had a nice jalapeño lemon cocktail to go with my meal. If you're walking through the Valencia area, you got to try this place
author: Jason J.

description:
Service: Excellent - waiter was very friendly, attentive, and helpful, and managed our large group quite well.

Atmosphere: Way too hot inside, and it wasn't totally packed, so they must've just had the temperature jacked up. Otherwise the atmosphere is nice - cool modern feel, casual, and didn't feel like sardines.

Food: I liked the Pho (had the veggie and tofu pho), but could've used more flavor and spice. 

Overall: I liked it, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go or run back anytime soon, it was just a-ok.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I really had a hankering for pho and we were walking towards Thanh Tam II when we happened upon Mau. It was my husband's birthday and of course given I am in my first trimester of pregnancy, I didn't plan a thing and was only thinking about my intense pho craving. I though Mau might be a nicer spot to eat vs. Thanh Tam II, ambiance wise. And I was right, the ambiance is niceR and the service was slightly more attentive. But the the food was really mediocre. Meh is a good description. 

Earlier in the day, I was at Costco and had a sampling of their pho soup, which got my craving starting. Have to say, Costco beats Mau hands down on their pho. Not to mention every single hole-in-the-wall-$4-a-bowl pho place around. I really didn't care for the pho at all. It lack that indescribable but very fundamental broth flavor that makes pho, pho.

My husband that the clay pot, which he poured hot sauce into. It lacked flavor as well, and left me feeling bad about taking him there on his birthday. We'll have to do a do-over.

Lastly, the service, in comparison to the food was so-so. The waiter didn't really check in on us and the food came out slowly. So did the check. And we didn't get the Young Coconut we ordered but I was ready to leave. I will say, the waiter was nice, but clearly overwhelmed. 

Probably will be skipping Mau moving forward. Curry In a Hurry (next door) however, is a great spot, cheap and tasty. Go there for your cheap eat!
author: Janet C.

description: This place really is great.  But the Pho is just average and the quality varies drastically from day to day.  I've had great pho and bad pho.  I keep coming back though because it's a great experience.
author: Charles L.

description:
First time I came and had the chicken pho which was bomb with the ginger broth.  Not typical traditional but definitely California inspired Vietnamese.  Also had their imperial rolls (cha gio) which were good although not enough lettuce to make wraps.  

Second time got their hue rolls which was good although the rice wrap could've been less rubbery or thinner.  Also had a variety of rice plates to share.  Including the $16(!) shaken beef which came in tiny cubes mixed with bell peppers and tomatoes and other veggies.  The portion of meat for the price was extremely disappointing and the meat was a bit salty and not extremely tender (especially for a 'tenderloin') as other shaken beef I've had.  The waiter also couldn't answer what the greens were and made us wait until the end of the meal to ask the kitchen what it was (even though it's written on any menu). In contrast, the lemongrass chicken ($9) was plentiful on meat.  The gulf prawn claypot was easily the worst dish I've had in a while, where the broth it was cooked in tasted like one of those slightly off clams that you always dread to get.  

It's a pity that my second visit was so disappointing.  I've seen the waiter behind the bar so maybe he was just filling in on the floor this time.  Really an ok restaurant I think if you stick to the Pho or vermicelli bowls only.  But I bump them to a 4 since they're still getting their feet wet as a new restaurant.
author: kiwi l.

description:
Great first taste.

I had the tofu & minced pork, spicy tomato broth soup, which was really tasty. The  tomato broth had excellent mouthfeel, good depth and the addition of kaffir lime leaves added a nice complexity. The egg noodles were nicely firm and plenty of gai lan leaves rounded out the bowl.

They make their own sriracha and another garlic chili paste, which were really nice and added even more of a kick.

I want to try the salted lemonade next time, as I hardly ever see this on a menu.

More asian food in the Mission is truly appreciated!
author: Derrick V.

description:
This place is phenomenal. Not since Vietnam have I tasted such delicious Pho.
My kids and I spent 3 weeks in Vietnam and they were hard to talk to during dinner since their heads were down as they couldn't not stop devouring this fresh and thoroughly delicious meal.
Finally! San Francisco has an authentic Vietnamese restaurant besides that impossible to get a reservation for, "Slanted Door".
author: Jake S.

description:
Oh. Mau. Goodness.

We attended the soft opening of Mau tonight... And it was DELIGHTFUL. Staff was attentive, and being in a group that ordered one of everything - we weren't in the slightest bit disappointed.

Grilled Beef Salad (with more beef than I can even request -obviously a plus - and perfectly seasoned)

Tofu Noodle Salad, TDF: to die for - the tofu is perfectly cooked - even for us meat lovers at the table. The perfect lunch entree or dinner for two starter.

Banana Leaf Wrapped Whole Fish - need I say more?

Duroc Pork Belly Rice Bowl - wanted to crawl up and make tiny sheets and live in this.

The decor is great - all of tables are refinished from old Nebraska High School Bleachers. 

Overall we had the best time - I can't wait to spend all of my lunches and Friday night dinners here.
author: Chelsea D.

description: Great food. Generous portions. Excellent service! My Pho Bo was huge! their Bun thit is also a must try.
author: Lyla U.

description:
Well we came the day after the soft opening, so Day 2 of operation, and the service was rusty, but all involved were quite nice.  Once they figure out how to greet customers and direct them to a table, how to work the register, how to set and clear the table swiftly and unobtrusively, this will be a 5-star joint.  BECAUSE...

THE FOOD!!!!  Omg.  

Pork and Soft Tofu Noodles = amazeballs.  ate every bite.  there were two teaspoons of broth left at the end.  my lunch compadre dragged my bowl a little closer to him to be able to get a taste and I almost smacked his hand b/c I thought he was trying to take it away from me.  wonderful flavor - bits of greens (lemongrass?), perfectly cooked pork and tofu, and noodles done to perfection.  yummy in my tummy.

Tofu Banh Mi = AMAZEBALLS.  lunch compadre finished it in like half the time it took me to eat the noodle soup.  then pondered getting a second one.  then decided he'd rather come back on saturday and get one to go, for lunch.  the tofu in this was marinated and grilled with magic.  MAGIC.  it was so so delicious.  because of the tofu magic.  perfect bite after perfect bite.

all for...$26 for both lunch entrees plus one ginger ale.
author: Allonsy A.

description:
I don't know why I never learn my lesson.  My aunt was convinced that this was the best Vietnamese food there is and the ingredients are far fresher than your typical Vietnamese pho shop.  well, maybe in San Francisco it might be considered good.  In fact, it wasn't that much fresher than my favorite Vietnamese places in the East or South bay.  And i would have pho at turtle tower over Mau any day.  But I guess the mission needs something new every few months.  It's not really fusion so much as poorly executed Vietnamese in a modern minimalist interior and English speaking waiters.  If you're vegan however you may be a little more excited I guess.

One thing that I do like are their appetizers.  I would just stick to that and call it a day. We tried hue rolls, excellent.  The imperial rolls, standard.  And the beef salad, which was weird.  I was expecting more of the Thai style salad where there are more fresh ingredients like carrot or papaya bit it was just romaine tomato and hard boiled egg with really sweet beef on top.

I had the fish clay pot.  It was just fish in a clay pot seasoned with a ton of soy sauce sugar pepper and garlic. With a side of rice.  It was like something id make for myself in college.

My aunt ordered the bun bo hue.  And it was NOT bun Bo hue.  It was a regular pho with more bird eye chili and rice noodle!  I dunno.  She ordered a coconut juice too and it tastes and looked like sugar cane juice.  Also weird.

Anyway I wouldn't come back.  It's one of those places your Asian gangster crew would hate on all evening.  Like I have done for you today.  Also, why is it called mau?
author: Biqi C.

description:
Lamenting the loss of Tu Lan... continuing the arduous search for a substitute for #17; bun thit nuong w/ imperial rolls

If I'm in the area again and fiending for my Vietnamese fix, this place'll satisfy... unfortunately, as the neighborhood goes... it's kinda pricey.  Imperial rolls have the great crunch and chewy caramelized texture, but not enough filling and light on the seasoning compared to funkier, more authentic versions.  Dipping sauce for the bun tasted watered down.  The little monkey dish given to me when I asked for sri-racha was disappointing; as was the surprised comment by the waiter when I quickly dumped all the contents on my noodle bowl and asked for some more... gringos.

The place is nice and clean.  The ingredients are good and fresh.  The price fits the 'hood.  Maybe best for recent transplants who still have the chain attached to their wallet in the back pocket of their faux-retro trousers.
author: Josh K.

description: The food is absolutely delicious with awesome flavor. Nicked one star because service was slow at the beginning. We sat down and it took 15 minutes for our server to get to us, and skipped the people who sat down next to us before us, I felt bad. But once we finally ordered the food came out fast and it was seriously amazing!
author: Gillian K.

description: Awesome and cheap! Just go. Sorry for the short review, I'm too busy enjoying my food.
author: Dave L.

description:
Tried Pho for the first time and I loved it! We ordered the Lemongrass Tofu and Veg Pho, they had a garlic veg broth and a veg sauce (normally they give a fish sauce) to put over the Tofu Dish - both were delish!  I am a huge fan of lemongrass so they definitely sold me with their homemade lemongrass chili paste and homemade sriracha sauce.  

Alex was the one who seated us, gave us suggestions on what to order and constantly checked up on us even thought we had another server attending to us.   The service was great!
author: Dipu P.

description: I was super hungry in the mission district and decided to check out Mau. The atmosphere inside was good, as was the customer service. The chicken in my pho and bahn mi was weird and chewy though. Might be worth trying some other items on the menu.
author: David T.

description:
Made it back on a non-Sunday night and so glad I did. Great meal, the vegetarian option spring rolls are wonderful and huge, and the Pho was on point. 

Also, can we get an extra star for a tasty place that both me (GF and meat eating) and my vegan friend can be happy with?!!! Yay!
author: Sarah X.

description: Great vietnamese restaurant in the middle of Mission.
author: Jonas H.

description: LOVED it! Visiting from out of town and always craving Vietnamese food so this place was definitely worth the visit. Super cute and trendy atmosphere, friendly and fast staff, and food was awesome!! Started with Hue rolls and banana blossom salad. Got Pho Bo and Bun Bo Hue. All of it was delicious! Meat was perfect in everything and broth was flavorful and not a speck of grease (which I hate). Loved the spicy sauces and toppings for soup as well. For drinks we had salted lemonade (very good), hot green tea, and Vietnamese coffee (yum!). Met up with some family and it was the perfect atmosphere to catch up over lunch without feelings rushed or anything. If we are ever in town we will for sure stop by again. Thanks!!
author: Devon S.

description: In each of the three times I've had food from Mau (twice at the food bar and once takeout), the food has been pretty tasty, clean and healthy. Unfortunately the service has been pretty shoddy and at times I felt like my server couldn't care less about me or my party.
author: Taylor N.

description: If you're looking for fresh cuisine that tastes great and is reasonably priced, you've found your match! Mau serves up simple flavorful Vietnamese fare with several great vegetarian dishes too. For vegetarians, I highly recommend the veg freshrolls and the tofu bun dry noodles dish. The cream puffs are the perfect end to your meal...sweetened to just the right level and light.
author: Komal P.

description: The ambiance is not exactly what I expected (used to pho places being more hole in the wall and less hip restaurant) but I have to say the food was excellent! I got the veggie pho and it was the best I have ever had anywhere (although I have not had THAT many veggie phos). The spring rolls were delicious and the service was excellent!
author: Leonard C.

description: On the pricier side of Vietnamese food but it has a clean and chic decor. The food is great and always fresh. Mau is the sister restaurant of Tin Vietnamese in the SoMa area (which is also worth a visit). I highly recommend the Bahn Xeoh crispy crepe over the crispy rolls, because the crepe is fresh and also has meat, seafood and fried crispy goodness.
author: Christina H.

description:
The newly-minted Mau Viet Kitchen is a great addition to the Mission. Overall I would return anytime and walked away thinking "fresh."
The Hue Rolls were vibrant not by color but by texture, and would make an amazing small lunch by themselves. 
The Bun Bowl with Chicken was nicely balanced: large portion of fried spicey chicken, noodles, veggies. Maybe a tad heavy on the sprouts.
Price point very reasonable, walked away for $26 for rolls, bun bowl, and Anchor Steam Brown.
I would recommend this for lunch, and not for romance.
author: Brian Z.

description:
Best Bahn Mi in town. 
The pork is incredible. 

Their home made shriracha and hot sauces are excellent! 

we LOVE this place. 
the staff is freindly.
author: Mellissa B.

description:
Mau is our new go-to Vietnamese spot. They have THE BEST vegetarian pho & tofu vermicelli dish I have EVER had. Everything tasted amazing and fresh. The presentation was gorgeous. The staff were sweet. The art was fun & funky. And it was really affordable.  

More people need to go here!  Seriously, so good!
author: Amber K.

description:
Expensive and unimaginative fusion food.

This was a 2.5 - 3 star experience.

I hate to rag on a new restaurant but I've been here twice since their recent opening - once for lunch and once for dinner and both visits were "meh" 

Their lunch prices are pretty steep.  I don't mind paying $8-9 for a banh mi but I expect it to rock my world and unfortunately Mau's version did not.  The sardine sandwich was nice worthy of 3 stars but the sausage banh mi was a snooze.  
Portions were small and for $4-6 bucks, I can get a great banh mi sandwich in tons of banh mi joints in San Francisco. 

Most disappointing was dinner.  We came on a rainy night and the place was pretty empty.   I was surprised considering that every restaurant in the Mission is packed.  We ordered:  

Pork Belly Rice Bowl $15- 2 Stars -  where's the pork?  Where's the crispiness?  Where's the decadence?  Where's the flavor?  I had 5 little pieces of pork with regular steamed rice, some lettuce, and a few pickles for $15 bucks!  Really?? 

Pork Shop to Share $25- 3 Stars - the pork chop was a nice meaty portion and cooked well but slightly on the undercooked side but I'm ok with that.  The pork chop was served with a scoop of white rice and some pickles.  The chop was juicy which was enjoyable but lacking flavor and at $25, I didn't think it was worth it.  C'mon guys $25 is a lot of money - put some effort into this dish.  Just grilling a good chop is not enough to justify asking for $25 buckaroos. 

Wok Fried Greens - no flavor, oily.  

Beef Salad - $10 - 2 stars.  Salty, missing acid.  Just not worth it. 

Sausage - $8 - 2 stars.  The sausage lacked flavor and the nuoc cham sauce does not taste very good and that is a huge problem considering that this is served like a wrap with lettuce and herbs.  Anyone that knows Vietnamese cuisine knows that the nuoc cham sauce is ultra important to the dish- it can make or break a Vietnamese dish and in this case, it failed.  

Ice Cream Sundae $8 - 1 star.  This is scoops of ice cream from Bi-Rite served with coconut toppings and peanuts.  This is disappointing because if you only have 1 dessert, make it great and special.   Just giving us scoops of ice cream with toppings, it just is sad.  ANd, for $8, it's near robbery.
author: Denise T.

description:
When I have "ethnic cuisine" I like the decor to be in sync with the cuisine's country/region of origin. I also prefer it when the staff is from said country/region. Is that so wrong? Well I don't want to be right.

This place is the polar opposite of these preferences. First off, the decor has a pretentious, sanitized feel to it. Second, our waiter looked and acted more like someone who should be handing me a beer at a dive bar than handing me a bowl of Pho.

As for the food, I just had a beef salad so I can't comment extensively on their menu but the salad was pretty forgettable.

Hipsters, please stick to coffee shops and leave Vietnamese cuisine to the Vietnamese.
author: Teiki K.

description:
Love, Love, Love.
Give me their tofu noodle bowl any day of the week and I'll be happy. 
Also love the fried green onions (would never have ordered it if the waiter hadn't recommended it) YUM!
Have been three times and it just keeps gettng better. 
Love it!
author: Shiny D.

description: This place is in my hood but we just happened upon it for the first time during Sunday's Valencia Streets.  Where have we been?  We dug into the Chicken Pho and Spring Rolls and had them bring a plate of other additions to add to the soup.  It was delicious.  So good we are heading there for lunch again today.  ENJOY!  Next time I will try to remember to take some photos before it all disappears!
author: Lisa M.

description:
Awfully LOOOONG wait.  Party of 6 on Monday for lunch.  We got a table fairly quick (15-20min).  But we waited for food for TWO (2) hours.  No Kidding!!  Patiently sitting around and drinking water.

As for the food.  Same menu as Tin in SOMA.  However the cooking not as good.  Something is missing.  Very mediocre taste.  We'd continue going to Tin on Howard instead.
author: Alex R.

description: Weeknight takeout go-to. I love the Pho. It can get nuts-busy.
author: Charles W.

description: Love this place, as do my coworkers. I could eat the cat fish clay pot every day for lunch. Highly recommend giving it a try.
author: Erica L.

description: When I got a table at this hipsterish place I waited 30 minutes to get our appetizer.  By the end of our meal the two of us had waited an hour for average food that was not stellar by any means.  The service was extremely slow and the table next to us got served before us.  I will never go here again, service was lousy.
author: Jerry H.

description:
Eaten here about 10 times now and love it. The freshness of the vegetables is outstanding, the sauces and flavors unique. They make a wonderful hot sauce of lemon grass, ginger and peppers and it has flavor that is in nice balance with the heat. The basic dishes are good but it's the specialty dishes you should try Hue Roll, Bun Bo Hue, Hu Tieu Kho (my favorite, the celery is so tasty). 

Yes the first few months was rocky where service was spotty but I say that the last 4 times we went in the last 8 weeks it has all been ironed out. And if they have the sardine bahn mi EAT IT.
author: Sarah S.

description: Good food and great ambiance at the bar if you're just in the market for a quick drink!
author: Matt J.

description:
Mau? More like Meh...

Overpriced and not that tasty...maybe they are still working out the kinks but service seemed really awkward as well...
author: Joe C.

description:
Fish Clay Pot - 10 bucks 
Very well seasoned and the fish perfectly cooked. The sauce just goes great with rice. It's a perfect meal for a cold night in the city. 

Shaken Beef - 16 bucks
Very tender beef but I feel could use a little more kick to it. I see the lime, salt, and pepper to the side but I'd rather have you make it right without me having to throw condiments on it. 

Bottle of Malbec -29 bucks
Bold and went very well with my beef. I wished we had wine glasses instead of the table wine cups though. 

Will definitely comeback to check out the noodle soups and maybe the sandwiches for lunch. I saw a glance of the bun bowls at the nearby tables and they didn't look all that great to me.

The price is pretty good considering the modern and minimalist decor they got going on and being on the hottest side of the block. The service was really warm, attentive, and almost personable.
author: Charlie L.

description: Amazing food and great for celiacs! I called ahead to make sure they had gluten free itemsI ordered the chicken pho and asked for garlic broth instead of ginger. It was so delicious! I also had the spring rolls and they were incredibly fresh and high quality. I asked for fish sauce to use for dipping and it was the best fish sauce I have ever had!
author: Jill M.

description: Totally long wait for table service.  I thought the food was very good, but would only eat here again if invited.
author: Paula P.

description: If you can't tell by my photo, I'm Vietnamese. And I think this is the best Vietnamese restaurant in the city. The ingredients are always fresh and high-quality. The food tastes amazing, which is why there's a long wait for a table 7 days a week. It's worth the wait though!
author: Julie N.

description: I have been here many times and each time I have a fantastic experience.  They have exceptionally nice and genuine people working here.  The food is amazing and their spicy lemongrass pho with beef and pork sausage is absolutely my favorite (I like to sub egg noodles instead of vermicelli)  I'd highly recommend trying the Hue Rolls appetizer!! It's perfectly seasoned bbq pork with mint and herbs rolled in a very wide noodle like container - delicious!!
author: Jessica L.

description: Just moved to the mission and I've been looking for good Pho in the city for a minute. This place is legit. Their cocktail menu is pretty good too. I had the uncle ho which was surprisingly well balanced and tasty. The guys there are really welcoming and cool to talk to. Gonna definitely be one of my go to spots from now on.
author: Michael J.

description: Pho is my favorite food and this place does it right! Love the pickled onions with the pho. Try the hue spring rolls too!
author: Lydia G.

description:
I really like getting lunch here, I'll keep going back. 

Food 5 - the food is great. I usually get the pho bo which is one of the best I've had. They have a good selection of food and drinks too. The price is great and I always feel satisfied when I'm done.

Service 5 - The service has been great 3/3 times. They guys there are really nice and attentive. Pretty much no wait to take my order, get my food, and get out and the place was pretty busy.

Atmosphere 3 - Atmosphere is kind of none existent which is fine with me but when I try to picture what the place looks like all I can remember is there are wood tables and chairs... Probably not where most people would take someone on a fancy date.
author: Raquel L.

description: Went a few months ago when they first opened up shop.  The food was good, but they didn't have pho available at the time.  I'd go back again if i was feeling like vietnamese food, but not the grittier stuff from the hole in the walls nearby.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Wow what an unexpected find!! Always passed by Mau never went in but we really wanted pho on a chilly night so decided to try it. 

All our food exceeded our expectations. Veggie spring rolls were delicious! They were fresh and full of flavor. Also got garlic sautéed Bok Choy that honestly was the best Bok Choy we ever had. Lastly, we had Pho bo good flavor not overly salty and full of meat and noodles. Great taste and generous portions!

Service was friendly, helpful, and attentive but don't go here if you are in a hurry. We enjoyed the decor, style, and atmosphere too.

Overall had a great date night! Would recommend this for a date or small group outing
author: Marie L.

description:
Great  tasting and fresh.  We ordered and I would recommend cha gio fried rolls
banh xeo crepe, papaya salad and their lemograss pork.  So tasty and soo delish.  Too bad we live so far away, otherwise, we'd be eating here at least once a week.
author: Cj P.

description: Food was great. Came reasonably quick and was reasonably priced. The service however was slow. We had maybe 2 water refills for a table of 6 (they have pitchers on the tables) and the pitcher barely filled a round of drinks. When it came time to pay, we took a few minutes to split our check, and then waited another 30 before one of us latched onto another waiter while they were putting an order in.
author: Sean C.

description:
I don't believe in fancy Vietnamese restaurants. I think they lack authenticity because they try to be too different. Usually they plate food nicely, charge you double, and the food doesn't justify the price.
I wouldn't find myself picking a trendy viet restaurant but was invited here for a birthday. To my surprise, the food was actually decent. My favorite was the banana blossom salad. I want more as I'm typing this review. The nuoc mam (fish sauce) in it was point on. Most trendy restaurants water down their fish sauce. I think it's to cater to everyone? Highly recommend their salads since their nuoc mam is really good.
We also tried pho ga, bun bo hue, shaking beef, banh mi, claypot catfish, garlic noodles, and cha gio.
Everything was decent. I would order the cha gio and claypot catfish again. 
Cha gio (viet eggrolls) is usually made with ground pork, mushrooms, glass noodles, and taro. The taro will give it a little mushier texture inside. They were light, crispy, and the portion was decent. Nuoc mam, again, to dip was on point. 
If you're looking for something jam packed with flavor, try the claypot catfish. It can be a little overwhelming for some but good with rice. 
Bbh was decent. Flavor was there. It lacked spice so I asked for more chili sate sauce to give it more of a kick.
It's worth a try, but I rather spend on the average viet restaurant in San Jose.
author: Linda P.

description:
I'd say 3.5

Generous portions. Spring rolls felt not so fresh, like they were made an hour ago. Chicken wings from the starters menu were pretty good. Vermicelli was decent but not the best I've had. 

Busy place we ran out of water a few times and the waiters were too busy to check in I guess, but they were very friendly.
author: Danielle A.

description:
A great choice if you like Vietnamese/SE Asian food, made with local organic ingredients.  Food was very tasty and at a good price point.  We had the beef salad, five spice chicken bowl and a side of greens....all delicious!  Its nice to have a great, healthy meal like this and without the oily, salty side effects of some other Asian restaurants.  

Highly recommended!
author: Wendy C.

description: Gave this place 1 star due to finding hair twice in the pho. The first time I found hair I didn't come back after 2-3 months and then today Saturday May 16th found hair again in my pho. I called in the issue and was apologized to, but the manager I spoke with I believe he said his name was Nevin said "it happens, and that if we were living in a perfect world it wouldn't have." I wouldn't eat at this place anymore, once an employee accepts that things will happen cause it's not a perfect world is when they start to let their guard down and who knows what else is in their food.
author: Arland B.

description: Always heard great things about this joint so I decided to finally check it out! Very unpretentious and comfy casual atmosphere. I'm glad that it's not one of those dimly lit trying to be hip places! Great food, fast service and very nice and courteous servers! I had the mango salad along with the shaken beef, deelish! Thanks to the lovely gentleman at the bar (NH) for being so gracious! I will definitely cone back to try the other yummy delights on the menu for sure!
author: Roland T.

description: My Fiancé and I live in the area and wanted to try a new place. We ended up at Mau and although both the Claypot Catfish and Claypot Chicken were both so delicious, our service was super slow. We waited about 15 minutes to take our order and another 40 minutes for our food to arrive. I am still waiting for our check right now and it's been 10 minutes already. This isn't okay SERVICE WISE. The taste and quality of food was amazing though! Great prices! Just don't go when it's busy. You'll regret it. I am.
author: Paige C.

description:
Really great food, reasonable prices and AMAZING drinks. Owners, managers, and staff are so friendly and give excellent recommendations. 

Whatever the special is, order it. So far it's always been amazing. Great Vietnamese iced coffee too.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I told my friend I wanted some delicious Vietnamese food, so she suggested we try this new place that just opened in the Mission. Now, I'm not generally a fan of modern decor, but I love how this place is laid out. The lighting fixtures are super unique, the room is very much perfectly symmetrical. I love the dark browns contrasted with the whites.

They also had Sapporo on their beer list. Japanese beer is my favorite type of beer so big props to Mau for stocking Japanese beer. I had the meat pho, and that was quite good. Broth was steaming, meat was tender, tons of veggies to add to the soup. I just wish I had been hungrier to order spring rolls! And our waiter was very attentive, always coming around to make sure we didn't need anything, or if we did, he would get it. Great experience.
author: Saroya W.

description: Love love love Mau! Hue rolls for sure. Awesome staff. Close to my work. Great spot!
author: Gina O.

description:
Not bad at all. I previously dismissed it and walked by it many times, but went last night. This is a good option in neighborhood given the fact that your other choices are MSG filled  or just plain bad Vietnamese.  I had the Grilled Beef Bun Bowl and my friend had the Fish Clay Pot. Good portions of food for the right price. The downsides: white wine  in a water glass means that it got warm by the before I finished it ( that's annoying) and the space it's a little too minimalist and stark-- I can see why people walk past it and not go in. 

What struck me too was how oddly tall (and white) the wait staff was.  Thought I was in Scandanavia!  Weird.
author: Uda W.

description: Mau is my favorite place in the mission. Consistent food and service.
author: D E.

description:
If you happen to be strolling down Valencia and craving Vietnamese, Mau will satisfy. 

We ordered the spring rolls, which tasted okay but were a tad bland. I expected more herbs other than just mint inside the roll, and the side of peanut dipping sauce didn't deliver any punch.   The Pho Bo ("traditional" pho) had great components (meat, broth, noodles) but somehow overall was nothing extraordinary. The highlight of the meal was the Hu Tieu Kho (warm noodles with pork, chicken and shrimp) which was served in a delicious soy-tomato sauce (very fishsauce-y, be warned!). But, the noodles were overcooked (completely stuck together) and I only found one shrimp in my bowl.

i can't comment on how Mau fares in comparison to other Vietnamese options in the heart of the Mission because I haven't been to any. I can however tell you, that in all the places I've been to in San Francisco, this is commendable but not necessarily the best or the most authentic.  

Props to the staff for not rushing us out after the restaurant had closed and we were the only patrons left.
author: Roxane W.

description: The bok choy was phenomenal!! Perfect bite sizes, the garlic sauce was delicious.  Just heavenly.  I also had the five-spiced chicken rice plate.  All very good, I would definitely go back.
author: Nicole H.

description:
OH MY FREAKIN' Goodness!
It was by far the best pork bun me I ever had in my life!!!
I am floored! I cant wait to try all the other yummy dishes!!!
author: Domina V.

description: Everything we ordered was yummy! We started out with two rolls. One was crispy and the other had a peanut dipping sauce that was divine. Another great thing is that everyone got Pho, even the vegetarian in my group! Yup, they have vegetarian/vegan options that are mighty tasty. I had the Bun Bo Pho and it was excellent. It was also really large and after having spring rolls, it was a bit too much to handle. I'd totally go again.
author: Theresa D.

description: If you want Vietnamese food, go elsewhere. The pho is almost as bad as the seating which is so close together to other parties. I recommend avoiding the gentrified Valencia street altogether. Unless, of course, you ride a Google bus and don't know you suck.
author: Clara A.

description: Nice spot for a casual meal, service is pretty quick too if you are in a hurry. We started with the spring rolls and mango salad which were both nice appetizers. The spring rolls were super fresh and probably a little better than the mango salad. The tofu bun was great and a large portion so we had plenty leftover. They also have a nice shot and a beer special ; (cold sake and a sapporo for 6 bucks). Definitely will be back...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Really tasty food, cool atmosphere, and friendly staff.  I had some kind of beef dish and loved it. Fun Sapporo and Sake shot deals as well. Prices were reasonable.
author: Kevin M.

description: This place is the best! Staff, food, ambiance. All of it! Thanks for being great!
author: giulietta o.

description: As the other reviews state this is an midscale/hipster Vietnamese restaurant. I've eaten here twice now and have been really happy with my Pho Bo and as result have gotten it both times, so I can't comment on much on the menu beyond that. My date was also happy with her Pho Ga and ended up getting it again :). Prices are reasonable (for what you're getting in terms of environment + food) and they have a decent beer selection. The only thing I will knock it on is that it can be a bit loud and service can be a bit on the slow side.
author: Ben R.

description:
Five stars for the food -- they've nailed the broth for pho. 

Negative four stars for the service and the ambiance. It's so loud, I get a headache, so to get my pho fix, we call ahead for pickup. 

The last two times I've come in for pickup, I've had to wait 15-20 minutes to get my food, that has been sitting on the counter, getting cold the entire time. 

I'd give Mau four stars if I didn't have to deal with the front of the house staff. Alas, I'd rather eat glass. Not going back there again, and I recommend going to Tin for future pho fixes.
author: An B.

description:
Service is awesome...food is amazing...soups are very tasty

Absolutely recommend this place
author: Muschi T.

description: What a great spot. Lovely blend of traditional and fusion Vietnamese. Great atmosphere, even better soup!
author: Lindsay L.

description: Great chicken pho, beef pho, and veggie spring rolls. I haven't tried anything else but it all looks good. Very affordable and a good ambiance. Highly recommend this place!
author: Jillian P.

description:
Well, this was a rough experience. We called in food for dinner (2 orders of chicken pho and veggie spring rolls) and were told it should only take 15min. 1 HOUR LATER we finally got our food. Multiple people came and went while my girlfriend kept waiting, and asking, and waiting, and yelling at me ( I was circling in my car), and waiting, well you get it. No one would give her a straight answer why it was taking so long. Turns out it the majority of meal was ready for 45 minutes and the 50 minute wait was for the noodles to boil for 2 cups of pho. She had to ask for water and no one seemed willing to help.
   Bottom line is, no one should wait that long and if they do, comp them something, get them a drink, offer them water, and be nice maybe? After work is a tough time, it's the dinner push, but it wasn't even hat crowded. 
  Ok, sorry, enough complaining. Food was good, service and experience was horrible... So bad that we aren't going to grace Mau with our business again. I really hope you get your act together, talk to someone, or realize we, as consumers who aren't buttholes, deserve a meal that doesn't drive us bonkers trying to obtain it.
author: zach B.

description: Great place to get your pho fix. They have some traditional dishes, but I really liked their pork belly with vermicelli dish that didn't seem too traditional. Servers were nice to us too and attentive. Went here with a couple of friends just to try out this place. It didn't disappoint. Plus it has a bar! Wait wasn't that long and the place got packed very quick too. Will definitely come back here!
author: Cindy S.

description: Good customer service, but not impressed with the food. A little too much onions and garlic to my taste. Also, flavors did not remind me at all the delicious vietnamese food i used to eat in Europe.
author: P. C.

description: This is an excellent, cute, casual Vietnamese place in the Mission.  I had the wonton noodles with shrimp and pork wontons, xa-xiu pork, egg noodles, and the chicken clay pot.  Both exceeded my expectations, they were both flavorful, with big portions, and the clay pot had extremely delicious, tender chicken.  The claypot looks very bare bones, it's really just chicken and the dish itself is small, but don't underestimate it.  If you go as a couple, definitely get the claypot, a pho of some type, and an appetizer (all to share) and you're good to go.
author: Terry K.

description: The service was horrible, the waitress never brought our drinks or came by the table to check on us or refill our waters and the food wasn't good enough to make up for it. I wouldn't recommend this place and the food didn't seem like authentic vietnamese, it was more over priced American/Vietnamese fusion.
author: K S.

description: Food was good. The wait was terrible. It took forever to get someone's attention to come take my order. It took a long time to get the food, and it took even longer to get the bill! My order was straight forward and not customized in any way.
author: An Minh P.

description: I love Mau. The Hue Rolls (pronounced WAY i think?) are a must every time. I can always go with the Pho Bo or the Wonton soups but the rest of the menu is great too. The only weird thing is that some of the waiters charge to split the soup in two bowls and some don't... but whatever, the food is bomb!
author: Lauren O.

description:
Yum!  Just had the pho bo and it was great.  I get pho (how ever you pronounce it) often and Mau's version is very flavorful.  
A bowl of pho bo and the spring rolls are enough for two for a light lunch.
author: Francis B.

description: This place was just ok. I had the Hu Thieu with broth. The meat was of good quality. The broth was too sweet for my taste. Also $14 for a bowl of noodles is expensive, but it is the the Mission in SF, so it is to be expected, sadly. Usually I'd only pay $8 max for a bowl of noodles like this. My favorite place for Hu Thieu is Thanh Ky, a hole in the wall in Oakland. Service at Mau left much to be desired. They need more servers. The place was packed and I only saw two servers on the floor and two behind the bar. It was hard to get the attention of any server. The server who took my order forgot to bring my the drink I ordered. I decided to let it go and told the server to just take it off my check. I would not call this a "Vietnamese restaurant"; it is a restaurant that serves Vietnamese-type foods. The servers will say the Vietnamse names of the dishes and if you're actually Vietnamese, you will cringe.
author: Mara C.

description:
Mau's kitchen knows how to cook. All of the menu is rather standard Vietnamese restaurant fare, but they execute each one with reliable skill. This spans the whole menu: pho, salads, grilled meats. You can't go wrong! The staff is great, the restaurant itself is attractive and clean. 

So why not 5 stars? Because of their poor lunch hours. They open very late, at noon. And they're popular, so there's a rush of people all waiting to get in immediately. Which slams their kitchen all in a rush. The restaurant should open at 11!! It'd be better for the customers as well as the restaurant itself. When the hours are fixed I'll excitedly revise my rating to a well deserved 5+ stars.
author: Ryan S.

description:
This is a solid choice for Fusion Vietnamese in the Mission.  Between a mellow ambiance and very reasonable menu and price you can't go wrong.  Do note that the menu was limited but of the items we ordered there was not one thing that I did not like.

The owners were very friendly and checked up on us throughout the meal.  Its nice to see folks who care so much about their place and their customers.

My only complaints were that the chairs were not overly comfortable and there was no place to hang our jackets when we were there.  Overall well worth the visit.
author: Andrew S.

description: Service was terribly slow but friendly enough. Pho was tasteless and disappointing. Wine was corked. Good apps but didn't solely enhance the overall experience. I was expecting more.
author: Livia M.

description:
I've dined here 3 times and each time, the food has been good. I usually get the Pho Bo (beef noodle soup) $9. Now you can get it with tendon or tripe or both for $1 extra for each. I like mine with everything so now I'm paying $11 for a bowl of pho that I can usually get for $8 somewhere else. 

They have a good menu, lots of variety. And a decent wine list. 

I have one issue that has prompted me to write this review. The drinks take kind of a long time to come out. Every time I've been here, I get my drinks at the same time as the appetizer or after.
