The first time it happened, it wasn't a big deal. But now it seems to be kind of a consistent thing. I could maybe overlook this if they didn't have someone behind the bar...
author: Cleo F.

description: Good food. Sort of dysfunctional and overwhelmed staff caused very poor service in every respect.
author: Ravi A.

description: Mau's sinkful of soggy noodles ($9-$12) and "C"-for-effort hot plates are nonetheless spicy, savory and satisfying. Certainly not "delicious", but, to quote my roommate, "it's okay. It's warm and salty."
author: Liz C.

description: Very good choice for Vietnamese food.  Service is good, just too slow.  Nice decor and solid food.  Prices are fair, not cheap but still reasonable.
author: Java Z.

description:
Noticed that this restaurant got high ratings so we wanted to give it a try.  When we first arrived we mentioned to the hostess that we had theater plans at the Marsh so someone came by immediately to bring us the menu. 

We had a chance to carefully look over the menu but we waited quite a bit  for a server  to take our order.   At that time, the restaurant was not full yet, we arrived before the full dinner crowd.  We politely reminded the hostess that we needed to catch a show, can she please send a server back to our table?  When our server arrived he came with a scowl on his face, angry that he had to take our orders.  It really took us aback - his attitude was really funky.  It's one thing if the service is slow but it's another when you feel like you're definitely not welcomed.  

When we asked for containers for the leftovers, they put the noodles from the pho in a cardbox box container, not a plastic tub for the soups and inevitably the container melted away in a soggy mess.

I enjoyed the food but the experience and service is what I'll remember. Typically, I never give negative feedback about places.  I'd rather share great services/businesses with others instead.  In this case, I thought the restaurant should be aware of what's happening with their diners.  Nicer, more experienced servers could make all the difference.
author: June O.

description:
Service was decent.
Chicken wings were good.
Five spice chicken was good.
The homemade sriracha sauce was good.
But don't get the Srirachalada, unless you like sriracha water. Supposedly it had beer in it, but I couldn't taste it.
author: Glendon M.

description: Typically do the Tenderloin noodle joints like Bodega Bistro and Tu Lan but have been giving Mau a spin lately. I love Vietnamese food having been to Central & Northern Vietnam I get me a hankering for the popping fresh flavors of that cuisine on a regular basis. I have to seriously ignore the hipster-douche contingency (get the F off your phone and move yer self righteous arse over at the bar!) and tuck in to delicious bowls of bun, pho and lately some kickin' FROG LEGS! I also really like the woman and her husband who seem to be the proprietors - been topped up on my beer, gratis, a couple of times... cam o'n ban!
author: Russell B.

description: I don't know if they have noticed it yet, but I literally go here once a week. I have brought many friends here, and all of them have loved it. I really appreciate that they use good quality meats and such fresh ingredients, it shows. While it's a bit pricier than hole in the wall Vietnamese restaurants, it's totally worth it for the quality. Their bun and spring rolls are good, but their beef pho is my go to. Secret that isn't on the menu, if you want some veggies with your noodles and beef, just ask to add extra veggies! It's about $2-3 more but worth it. It's been really popular lately, so be prepared for a little wait, especially if you go in a group.
author: Danielle B.

description: I like that they have a veg option for pho. I love that it tastes really good.
author: Menandro M.

description: Ordered their Bun Rieu (crab soup); theeee bomb. If you love tomatos and seafood taste type of soup that is. Lol. I loved it bc it didn't have too fishy of a taste to it. I came on a Friday after gym for a quick bite. I need to come back to try other entries. Customer service was excellent too especially on a busy Friday.
author: AJ J.

description: Vietnamese food with American twist. I had the 5 spice quail for the appetizer, which was yummy, but the bun thang was like a bad one night stand I want to forget. My friend had beef shaken rice plate which he thought was alright. Like seeing a cute girl for the very first time and you don't want to say anything bad about her. Having visited Valencia St. several time now, I must say that I would rather come here than the other Vietnamese joint down the street.
author: J C.

description: Great Vietnamese! Spring Rolls are fresh, wonton soup tasty, service was good, good craft beer range.
author: Selina B.

description: Came with a group who wanted to do family style, and since noodle soups are not really shareable, we did not order anything from that section. Had the crepe appetizer, the hue rolls, lotus root salad, catfish noodle, and lemongrass chicken rice. IMO, only the catfish noodle and hue rolls was worth it. Could have done without the others. Not super pricey, but not cheap either. Can get better Vietnamese food elsewhere
author: Ava C.

description: There's a dish I crave probably once a week. I don't know if I'm being picky but maybe growing up near the town with the largest Vietnamese population outside of Vietnam justifies it. Bun cha gio is the perfect combination of textures--soft vermicelli noodles, crisp bean sprouts, refreshing cucumber and mint, lightly sautéed green onions, crushed roasted peanuts and lastly, fried egg rolls. This dish had all that (plus an extra plate of herbs requested) but something was off. Maybe it was the fact that the server couldn't pronounce the dish correctly--but neither can I. I'm used to a larger portion for that price but it is San Francisco and the decor looked nice but I sat outside anyways. I'll definitely try it again if I'm not closer to Little Vietnam Cafe.
author: Justine L.

description: A solid Vietnamese choice. Portions are large, food tasted very fresh, and service was good. I like the spicy sauces they had on the side...very unique tasting and flavorful. Another great thing about this place is that unlike most Vietnamese places, they actually have a good beer selection. Prices are very reasonable too. Will come back and would recommend.
author: Zak S.

description: The Pho Bo was the best pho I've ever had. It was so good I forgot to add the usual condiments!
author: Jing J.

description: Mau has a great combination of good food, great vibes, clean decor, and friendly service. I am not a huge fan of Vietnamese food but Mau hits it on the head. I love their Claypot Fish, Pho Ga, and Bun Thit Nuong! I highly recommend checking out this yummy spot in the mission.
author: Justin C.

description: I'm a big fan of Vietnamese. But a little skeptical about Vietnamese on Valencia. Just because I am not drawn to the hipster environment. Overpriced and don't really care for the people. I was wrong! The food was not bad and it was quite tasty. However, we got our appetizer when our meal came. That sucked a little cause we were hungry. But, I would come back here.
author: SF S.

description:
I ate in this place once and it was good, really good. 
I came back to order I go and I took garlic noodles and ask them to add shrimp.
They charged me correctly for the shrimp but I only had 2 with the noodles.
So yes it was really good but come one, if you charge to add food, add food.
author: Willy C.

description: Very disappointing.  The spring rolls were very good but the entrees were bland and the service was slow.
author: Sondra P.

description: I may be guilty of perusing the menu and making a bad decision. Although this restaurant should add more vegetables to complement their very simple 'chicken claypot'. My cousin and his girlfriend made wiser decisions with ordering the 'vegetarian claypot' and the pho.
author: Alex R.

description:
When they first opened, their Pho was pretty good... the ambiance is really nice.. very spacious, tall ceiling, hardwood tables & chairs... draft beer... but since then something has gone very wrong with their kitchen...

The Pho is now completely flavorless... it's like boiled water... horrid... for everyone giving it high marks, what are you comparing it to? Is this the only Pho you've ever had?

My wife is Vietnamese and I've tried Pho up and down the entire West Coast, in NY, PA, and FL- their current flavorless swill is one of the worst I've had...
author: Gene G.

description: Nice wooden atmosphere, mellowly lunch, great services, pho Bo soup simmered down my wife's cold and bun bowl of rice noodle and meat does wonder to my tongue and tummy.
author: Pepe W.

description: If you're in for mediocre service, a bleh ambiance, and inauthentic Vietnamese food, go here!!!
author: Vicky A.

description:
Mmmm... the pho... sooooo good.

I wish they'd be open on Sundays.
author: Rowland J.

description: I went down the Valence, scored a parking spot (amaze-balls!) and had to walk around for half an hour till they opened at noon. Let's just say I was miffed. I wasn't planning on going back but due to my current obsession with Vietnamese cabbage chicken salad I had to get a fix. Luckily I knew Duc Loy would be open so I grabbed a beef bun mi, which was super delish but I didn't eat it till later. The Mau version of my favorite salad was drenched in vinegar dressing. Not terrible but not very good.
author: Maria G.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but from the moment we stepped in the packed restaurant, I was already dissatisfied. The host ignored me and my family for several minutes (which is quite a feat with a toddler and 5-year old) while we waited patiently next to the "Please wait to be seated" sign. We were finally acknowledged, then sat down at our table, where we waited about 15 minutes for our order to be taken, despite my numerous attempt to catch the eye of our server. We at last ordered, and received our spring roll appetizer. It tasted fine, about what you would expect from any hole-in-the-wall place, and when we got 2/3 done, I noticed a hair. I tried to brush it off, thinking it might have been one of my eyelashes, but no, it was very long and completely woven into the noodles of the roll. I sent back the remains after telling them what had happened, and they didn't seem too concerned about it. Then, my husband and girls received their lunches, and mine was nowhere in sight. I waited for 10 minutes, nothing. I finally flagged down the server to ask about it, and he seemed confused, and says he'd inquire in the kitchen. Five minutes later, still nothing. Finally, I gave up, and asked for the check. My meal wasn't on the receipt, so I just decided to cut my losses and leave without my meal. 

To say the least, the whole experience was infuriating. And a shame, too, since the food that did come was tasty.
author: Audrey L.

description: Mau is my new favorite Vietnamese restaurant in SF.  Flavorful food, a great selection of drinks and really fun vibe and good service.  Their papaya salad was so fresh and flavorful that it rivaled the same dish made at home by my Vietnamese friends.  Now that's pretty hard to do!  My dining companion had the five-spice chicken, which he raved about, and my lemongrass tofu bun was spot on.  In short, a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: hk k.

description: I usually don't trust hip looking Asian restaurants but Mau was a welcomed change since there aren't too many good Asian spots around the area. It's a very different vibe than our regular Viet spot, Sunflower. I've tried the pho, spring rolls and lotus root salad which is featured on the  2014 7x7 big eat list.
author: Julia T.

description: I wouldn't recommend this place. I ordered online. I found hair in the soup and it was supposed to come with seafood it had one shrimp!
author: Mariam B.

description:
They're trying. And, I'm nice. 

Here's the story. We didn't have tons of time but we had an hour to have lunch before Ian needed to head out for SFO. Plenty of time, right? Especially for lunch at 1:45, when any sort of lunch crowd would have passed, yes? But, not quite. 

It all started okay. We were seated quickly, and given menus and water promptly. But, then it took ten minutes for our waitress to come, even after the bus boy said he'd send her over. We considered walking out. She was friendly, thanked us for waiting, took our order (bun rieu for me, tofu bun and Vietnamese-style limeade for him, and veggie hue rolls for us), brought out the limeade (which was too sweet, with undissolved sugar crystals hanging out at the bottom of the glass and lacking all tartness), then we waited. And waited. 

I looked at my watch: 2:15. Nothing. We thought about leaving again. Other people who were seated after us had their food brought out to them. I must have made a face because our waitress then came over to apologize that our appetizers (the hue rolls) were brought to another table. She'd bring over a new plate immediately and take it off our bill. No problem but we're in a rush, we told her. We had a flight to catch. Okay, she'd bring our bill. 

The hue rolls came out instantaneously, and they were good. The steamed rice wrapper was chewy in a good way. The lettuce added a light crunch. The sauce that came with it was not overwhelming like some fish sauces can be. And, that chile sauce with the chile flakes in it (which we had to ask for) is spicy, numbs your lips spicy, even for me, the girl who grew up with the Sriracha founders as her neighbors -- so, watch out, you just need a little. But, I think it what really made the dish was the shiso. Love shiso. 

And, the waitress brought our bill, with the hue rolls removed from the tab. Great. 

Then we waited some more. Our plates were taken away. Our waters will filled. We waited. We considered leaving again, but we needed to eat and, really, how much longer could it be? I was getting antsy. The busboy's movements (his clanging of the dishes), the dance club bass beats of the background (rather, foreground) music, watching all our dining neighbors eating their bowls of noodles (possibly our noodles), the fact that it was approaching 2:30 and our meals were still not in front of us, all of it made me anxious. 

A man (not sure who he was, as he wasn't a waiter nor the busboy, perhaps the owner?) took our credit card. "Excuse us, our food hasn't come yet. We're in a rush -- we have a flight to get on -- so we wanted our check early. But, we've been waiting for nearly forty minutes." "Forty minutes?" He seemed embarrassed and was really apologetic. He said he'd see what was going on. He came back a minute later and apologized: they have a new busboy, who was trying to help out but brought our dishes to other people instead. "But, he brought our hue rolls to someone else too." "Oh, you were that table. I'm so sorry. This is the fifth time he's done that this week. I'll get your food out right now and take it off your bill. And, I'll check in with you guys to make sure everything's okay." 

And, all that happened. Our noodles came out two minutes later. The man gave us a bill for $0. Our waitress came over, apologized, and offered us another limeade, which we declined. The man asked if we needed anything, more limes maybe? The man gave us napkins, which we didn't ask for or need but I do like having extra napkins. The man offered us more limeade -- on the house -- which we still said no to. He was trying. 

As for our noodles, they were pretty delicious. Sure, Ian's bun bowl with tofu and shitakes isn't like anything you'll find on Larkin Street but it was flavorful and filling, with plenty of tofu and veggies (though he did say that my lemongrass tofu is better). And, yeah, I'd choose to eat my mom's bun rieu over Mau's any day. But, if I'm feeling a craving for home, I'd totally eat that bowl of bun rieu again. 

So, in summary, the food (at least what we ordered) is good. As the daughter of Chinese/Vietnamese immigrant parents, I'd eat here again. I wouldn't take my parents here of course, as they would say it's too expensive (maybe a few dollars more than what you'd find at a hole-the-wall, green-chopsticks-on-the-table sorta Vietnamese joint, but not expensive either) and my mom can make all this food herself and do it well, but I'd eat here with friends. 

As for the service, they're trying. If the staff wasn't so genuinely apologetic to us and if we hadn't had our meal comped, I would be irate; I'd never go there again. But, they realized their mistakes, they apologized, and they tried to make up for it -- I can respect that. 

So, three stars for food quality. And, an initial one star for having delivered all our food to other people and being slow plus the five stars of trying to make up for it, averages out to 3 stars for service.
author: Susan T.

description: Mau really delivered on its pho!  I ordered the Pho Ga and was very happy with the dish..chicken+ginger broth and lots of yummy chilly sauce to go around.  The restaurant itself is up scale and modern, unlike many good hole-in-the-wall pho places that you might expect.  Even the prices/service were totally on par, try this place next time you're in Mission!
author: Ubz D.

description: My boyfriend had the Mi Xia Don (without the pork) and I had the Tofu Bun.  We also shared the garlic sauteed bok choy and had the spring rolls (again, no pork).  The spring rolls were fine, nothing special and neither of us cared for the peanut sauce.  We were completely in love with the bok choy, really excellent.  Both of our main dishes were quite good as well.  I liked mine better, the tofu was prepared perfectly and paired wonderfully with the noodles, beansprouts, mushrooms, etc.  My boyfriends dish was also very good, much stronger flavors though.  Our waiter was attentive and offered good suggestions.  Overall we were very pleased, the service, food, and atmosphere were all quite good and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Sorely disappointed.  Those are the two words that sum up our experience at eating at Mau.  

We really wanted to love it.  We arrived open minded, eager to spend a rare evening out (without our offspring) at a restaurant I expected so much to enjoy.  

Here's a summary of our experience:  
- BEYOND salty fish clay pot that we had to regrettfully return to the kitchen.  And I'm a person who loves salt-laden food but this was truely unedible.  They graciously replaced the dish with the shrimp claypot, but that was also MSG-infused heart attack inducing salty.

- overcooked mushy garlic noodles that stuck to oneanther like gnocchi.  

There were however two decent entrees.  The deep fried eggrolls (CHA GIO*) were decent, but weren't served with enough condiments to wrap up (lettuce, carrots, vermacelli) and dip into the savory sauce.  And the Shaken beef (which was cooked perfectly) but the meat itself was tough, had to chew it to a whilte to masticate it enough to swallow.  

The restaurant was packed.  So much so that I felt included on all the conversations of tables surrounding us -- definitely not a place to have intimate discussions.  I left knowing a bit more about java-script thanks to our neighboring eaters on the right and experienced a first date due to our neighbors on the left.  

We didn't eat any of the soups, but after this original experience, I wouldn't give them the doubt and go back.
author: dave g.

description: We really enjoyed the food n the atmosphere. I had the prawns n it came w a big side of white rice..it was ok but the pho n noodles looked very good n the rice cake appetizer was very good. I want to go back to try more items on their menu.
author: C A.

description: Worst Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco I've ever been to. Not even close to authentic. Service is OK but I've never waited that long for noodles. My crab noodle soup tasted like Campbell's tomato soup straight out of the can.... so bad I had to sign up and write my first review.
author: Tee V.

description: Decent Vietnamese-style food. Their appetizers (we had the garlic greens and the Hue Rolls) were wonderfully flavored. I had the noodle broth (pork and chicken), and it was loaded with meat, which was great, but I think the broth could have had more umami. Great for smallish groups, the ambiance and furnishings are modern and tasteful. Service was friendly, and relatively on-time even though they were packed with people waiting throughout the restaurant.
author: Keito U.

description: Absolutely delicious pho and the staff are so nice too.  I came here many times during my time in SF and would definitely recommend it.  The staff are really nice too.   Great buzzy place!
author: Emma H.

description: Quick service, good and flavorful food. Nice and attentive waiter. Interesting people watching. Fair price. In short: good stuff!
author: I R.

description: There are a bunch of things about this place I love. The hue rolls are absolutely fantastic here. They are topped with a sort of roasted onion which gives the dish a nice crunchiness. Frankly, all the dishes are great and it's fairly traditional, so it's really perfect food wise. But one reason I like it is because most traditional Vietnamese places usually has a tv in the corner with the owners kids studying next to it. This place, however, has more ambiance. It's casual, bright, nicely lit and more hopping than any other Vietnamese restaurant I've been to.
author: Brandon B.

description: Wonton soup is incredible. Service can be hit or miss especially when busy.
author: P L.

description: Love it.   The pho selection is modern and delish, and the chicken wings are excellent!
author: Best M.

description: Love Mau - they do a very good job westernizing vietnamese food just a tiny bit. The result is something that tastes authentic and yet is slightly more sophisticated than what you'd get in a real Vietnamese joint.
author: Fred A.

description:
pretty good food PAPAYA SALAD slowish service could be better

yums
author: Sabrina W.

description:
meh.  it's ok.

my first thought is that the food isn't good enough to compete with some of the better vietnamese fare on valencia st but then i think of how the service is at both thanh tam and sunflower and well...

maybe mau has a fighting chance. 

while i find the food at the other 2 places better the waiter at Mau did not yell at me or ignore me so maybe they are winning.  i came here for lunch on a random Tuesday I had taken off to spend with a fellow vegetarian friend from out of town wanting some noodle action.  she had the veggie pho which was flavorful but not especially outstanding.  i had the lemongrass tofu plate and we split the daily greens (which were bok choy) and i could not stop eating the greens.  they were garlicky and delicious.  

the restaurant was fairly busy but our server was attentive enough and i never felt rushed.

and mad points for him not having anger management issues (sunflower) or completely ignore me (yes i'm looking at you thanh tam).   

i'll be back to try their bahn mi's when i'm no longer doing this stupid low carb nonsense that is slowly killing me inside.
author: Jen I.

description: Had an awesome evening in here. The food was really, really good. I'm also going to mention something -- salted lemonade. Or something like that. It was so damn good. Looking forward to going back just to try it!
author: James A.

description: I am unconcerned with what authentic Pho is supposed to taste like. Fact is that simple Chicken Pho in ginger broth is heavenly, and now my new local go-to food for hangovers and colds.
author: Janett R.

description: Food took way too long to arrive. Got the Bo Kho and it was filling, but not enough noodles in my opinion. Wait staff was friendly, but said he "had other stuff to do," when we asked to split the check. Who does that?
author: Vigor L.

description: This place is 6 blocks from my office and house. I've gone about 10 times (3 or 4 for lunch and the rest for dinner).  On a Friday night at 6pm we have rarely had trouble getting a table. Ordering over the phone is quick, usually 15 - 20 minutes for the food to be ready. I'm a pescetarian, and there are several great options for me. I love the claypot fish and tofu, as well as the tofu bun.
author: Alex S.

description: This is the best Vietnamese place in SF! Everytime we've been there its been great! Its always very packed though, so be prepared to wait! But its worth it! The Pho is sooo tasty!
author: Jo L.

description: Street parking is limited but was available. It's pretty loud inside but I could make out the salsa music which added nicely to the environment. The Pho was pho-nominal. There were two coed restrooms for men and women one with no paper towels but they fixed that quick. The server was a little slow to get to us but overall great experience and two meals cost under $20.
author: Robert anthony D.

description: Hands down best Pho in SF! Order the amazing chicken wings they will not disappoint.
author: William M.

description: The food and ambiance were both fantastic.  Came in on a weekend night and were shown one of the few remaining tables.  I have been eating pretty authentic Vietnamese food in Philadephia so I had high expectations.  Upon our server's recommendation, I had the Hue rolls to start and the flavors of the ingredients paired so well together along with the dipping sauce.  I ordered the Bun Bo Hue (pork tenderloin, beef shank, spicy lemongrass chicken broth) pho, which was amazing and so much food for the price.  The meat was good quality and cooked to perfection.  I proceeded to eat almost the whole bowl because it was so delicious.  Can't wait to come back again!
author: Ellie K.

description: Consistently good Pho.   Best option in this part of the city.  Atmosphere is good for groups and dates. And a solid bar to boot.
author: Bill S.

description: The service here is very good and very friendly, and the food is terrific. I had the banana blossom salad and it was terrific. Summer rolls stuffed with mushrooms and served with peanut sauce were among the best I've tasted. Chicken wings were perfectly cooked and abundant, and the catfish clay pot was tender, moist, delicious, and very well seasoned. I'll be back to try to pho. The portions are huge and the prices are modest.
author: Scot N.

description:
Food was good, but not excellent.    ++ for vegan broth pho

Staff wasn't great.  Felt impersonal and uncaring.  When I asked what kind of tofu they use the response was "no idea" not "let me find out for you"
author: B B.

description: Classy spot for pho. Servers very professional, space clean and modern. The pho ga was very good however they do not offer the five spices chicken which I prefer. Nice fresh basil and other accoutrements were solid. Tea is extra as opposed to divier places but excellent. Imperial rolls were the typical quality/style but well presented. A solid choice to satisfy your pho cravings.
author: Michael L.

description: Being that I am Vietnamese, it's hard to find a genuinely good place because I can tell the difference between good and bad. Mau was delicious and fresh! Not only that but the environment, customer service, affordability, and authenticity made the experience so much better. Must stop by if you're in the area!
author: Thuan N.

description: New fav restaurant in the mission. Awesome pho, vermicelli, and pork chop. Nice decor, reasonable prices, and the wait isn't too bad for the area.
author: SFA M.

description: Let me start off by saying that my usual pho spots in the east bay are hole in the walls, so when I walked in to this very nice looking restaurant I was taken aback. The restaurant was beautiful, but the service was lacking. I came in at noon on my lunch break solo. It took them probably 3 to 4 minutes to seat me in a mostly empty restaurant. The prices were higher than I'm used to, but being in SF that's to be expected. I ordered the Pho Bo. It took 25 minutes before I got my bowl of pho. So between waiting to be seated and and getting my food took half my lunch break, which if they were busy I could understand, but let me reiterate that the restaurant was mostly empty with staff out numbering customers. Finally my pho arrives and I have high hopes. But upon the first bite I was disappointed. The broth was bland, the amount of noodles and meat were very underwhelming. I will not be returning here and will be on the look out for a better pho spot in the area.
author: Emad D.

description: Definitely try the Hue Rolls! They are delicious. We had Hue Rolls, Veggie Noodles, and Papaya Salad. Have to admit, like mexican food, the dishes were all very similar, but all very tasty. Great service, a little crowded, but that is obviously because it is so good. Next time I would like to try the Pho.
author: Robin L.

description:
I can't fault the restaurant for how horrible the patrons at the table next to us were (obnoxious artsy hipsters, talking loudly about their drug-taking exploits and drama with ex-boyfriends and all sorts of personal information the rest of the restaurant doesn't give a f--- about, really, have some social decorum and shut up - also, get the hint when we move and loudly announce why, and people at another table chime in that you've been doing that for as long as they've been there too - ugh) 

Anyway - the low rating is not because of the food (we thought it was pretty good, maybe a little pricey but not horrible) but how atrocious the service was. One of the staff apparently told our neighboring table they were short today because someone had called out sick, but after reading other reviews here from the last couple of months, it sounds like this is not an unusual problem for them. It took 10 minutes for someone to come take our order, us hassling the busboy to get our appetizer another 15 minutes later (turns out he'd brought it out earlier and couldn't figure out who to bring it to; I think that was after he tried to bring us someone else's food). He eventually brought us our food too but we had to remind him we'd ordered drinks; turns out they'd been sitting at the bar for who knows how long. My husband just went straight to the counter to ask for the check since "we'll be here half an hour waiting for that."

Overall, we were satisfied with the meal, but not at all pleased with the experience. Not worth coming back.
author: Clementine K.

description: The vermicelli noodles here are delicious although I recommend opting for the grilled lemongrass pork. I had the beef last time and it really didn't do it for me. They serve the beef tightly wrapped around onions and another vegetable I couldn't identify which was disconcerting. We also ordered the green papaya salad which is delicious. Looking forward to trying the pho next time around. Service has been attentive and friendly. Solid spot.
author: Ellen S.

description: I love Vietnamese food and Mao is one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in the city. The Hue rolls, in particular, are spectacular. HOWEVER -- I'm only giving it 3 stars. I'd be adding two stars and eating there twice as often if they would cook the food with half as much salt, or even less. It's *so* not necessary. My Vietnamese sister-in-law makes delicious, authentic Vietnamese food and it's never too salty. So -- Please guys?
author: John M.

description:
I'm so happy this place opened up in the Mission. Sure, there are two other perfectly good Vietnamese places just down the street, but Mau is different -- they use great quality ingredients in their food, and it shows.* I love the Pho Ga (I could drink the ginger broth till I die and be happy!) and the pork banh mi (lunch only) is perfect, but everything I've had so far has been delicious. The service is great and friendly, and the decor is tastefully modern without being overly kitschy or mission-y or anything else. 


* A suggestion to Mau for the menu:
"We seek out produce & meat from farms & ranches that practice ecologically sound agriculture whenever possible" is SO vague, and if you're going to go there, why not be more clear? Are the vegetables pesticide free or not? Is the beef organic or not? Were the chickens' beaks clipped or not? When is it *not* possible to find organic/pesticide-free/etc in the bay area?
author: June D.

description: cool atmosphere, good food, but nothing to rave about. I wanted more intense flavors in my noodle bowl.  Very nice servers.  GOod beer selection
author: Belinda B.

description:
We wandered in about 8pm on Saturday, on our way to a show. We arrived just as a table opened, so had no wait although the restaurant was otherwise full. The decor was spare but comfortable and place seems like it's new. It was a somewhat noisy but like I said the place was full and it was Saturday night so that was to be expected.
We started with spring rolls, which were good- as was the peanut sauce that came with them. There was a good beer selection- both domestic micro brews and Asian standards. We both had bun- one of us had grilled pork and the other had grilled beef and  added grilled shrimp to the order. The ingredients were fresh and well prepared. The check was pretty reasonable for a place with cloth napkins.
We had a good overall experience and would totally go here again when we're in the neighborhood.
author: Lisa L.

description: Such good service!  They are nice when you are there for food, of course, but they are even nice if you just need something you're not paying for like a bag or utensils.  Fabulous.
author: Rachel M.

description: Best fresh spring rolls I have ever had. I had the lemongrass Chile chicken thigh noodles and my daughter had the tofu noodles and both were absolutely delicious. Her iced coffee was also delicious. The water could have been refilled faster but all in all a great place. Had lots of interesting sake drinks on the menu but I did not try them this time around.
author: Cassie A.

description: Amazing beef pho. Really really good. I could eat it every night.
author: Wendy J.

description: Food and service was great. Pho was solid in comparison to others. Also, the Gulf Prawn pot was phenomenal. Came here when I first moved to SF and is certainly a hip spot to take visiting friends.
author: Josh S.

description: This place just keeps getting better. The service has improved and the food is as good as ever.
author: Scott H.

description: I think you can get the pho anywhere so it might be better to stick with the pork _fill in the blank_.
author: Dora C.

description:
I should be compensated for how much business I bring to this restaurant. I'm literally here twice a week!

One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Casual dining, great prices, great food. Love their wonton noodle soup, their pho, and believe me when I say this: their fish claypot. They something on the menu as an appetizer, described as a stuffed crepe- I highly recommend it. Their baby coconut is the best I've found recently too! Light selection of beers great win selection (New Zealand Sauvignion Blanc is very good). 

Two complaint is: 
1. their price of wine doesn't seem proportiante to their price of food. $7-$9 for a very small glass. . . meh.
2. THEY ARE CLOSED ON SUNDAY
author: Ava A.

description: This place is too overpriced for the quality of food. I shared the beef salad, curry mussels and the pork plate.  The salad and mussels were delicious, the pork chop was bland. That was a good amount of food for 2 people and probably cost around $60.
author: Skye W.

description: Not a fan. Pho came not very hot and broth was pretty bland - none of the tables had sauces. Overpriced for what you get - I shouldn't pay $30 out the door for a meal for one at a pho place.
author: Sung P.

description: My husband and I have come here a few times over the last four months. We enjoyed the food and the service was usually prompt and friendly. Which is good because we only have a short time to eat before having to make it to a class around the corner at 7pm. Well last night I showed up at 610 and asked for a table and I was informed that she would not seat me until my husband arrived. This is the first time anyone has said this and in the past I will often get a table and order for both of us, so that we aren't late and have time to eat. So I questioned this employee who I'd never seen before about this policy and she gave me a bunch of attitude about how this was always their policy. I left, and will not be going back. If this is indeed their policy then I hope they think about the money they will loose by turning away paying customers who are in a hurry to eat and leave their table. Also the place was not close to full. Too bad, I'd always been treated nicely in the past.
author: Jessie C.

description: It was empty when we arrived, which made us think that we may have trouble ahead.  What a great experience though - The food was delicious (we loved the clay pot dishes in particular) and we enjoyed a great bottle of Adelsheim rose.  Juan, our server, was the kind of server we should all have - gracious, polite, and very helpful with suggestions.  We all left thinking, wow, we have stumbled upon something special.
author: Sarah P.

description: Went for lunch. As prior reviews mention, overall service is lacking (took several minutes to be seated, get glasses of water, place orders, get the bill) but the food was great. We started with the fried egg rolls---to die for! The claypot chicken and shaken beef were solid but not quite to Slanted Door quality (but who is?). The salted lemonade was interesting and I liked it. We'll be back to try more on the menu.
author: K J.

description: I've been here twice for lunch. The food ranges from mediocre (the beef pho was the weakest dish) to decent. The prices are much higher than Thanh Tam II or Sunflower down the street -- can't really be justified. The ambiance is nicer, but the food and service (which can be forgetful and slow) is not. The first time I went here I ordered the Banh Mi, which is 40% more expensive than the one at Thanh Tam and not as flavorful.  The second time I ordered the Hu Tieu Kho, and I'm pretty sure they messed up the order because it didn't have some of the ingredients listed. The waitress couldn't identify all the dishes, and nor did she know who ordered what, so we were kind of at a loss. Anyways, what I got was small and bland -- really just a small bowl of barely garnished rice noodles.
author: David C.

description: Had the chicken pho. The serving was generous and fresh tasting, but I especially loved the broth. The cha gio was okay (was strangely advised that it did not go with the pho--fine, but I just wanted one as an appetizer without having to order the full portion; they kindly obliged). Nice interior, great service, but just a bit expensive for what it is.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
So this should be 2.5 stars but half stars aren't possible here.

This restaurant  needs help.  We ordered the quail appetizer based on our waiter's recommendation that it was an awesome dish. We ordered 2 for $12 as there were 2 of us and quails are notoriously tiny a delicate and tender meat.  What came out was 4 half pieces of quail  on top of a bed of watercress (or some similar green).  The quail was chopped in 2 and fried... and it was crispy, a bit charred (not burnt but seriously well done) and chewy similar to beef jerky in spots.  I was amazed when it came to the table that it was even served to us, it was obvious when it arrived that it was overdone.   I did give it  a chance and ate the first half. I couldn't taste any of the five spice that it was supposed to be flavored with bits of the charred skin flaked off and got all over the table.   At the second half (which was more meaty)  I decided to try and hunt for the succulent juicy meat that  I associate with quail.. The uncrispy meat literally could be fanned out ... dry and pointy.  In short .. if I served chicken wings to my guest that were this overdone I would be ashamed, it was probably the worst cooked quail I have ever had... and I do enjoy quail when it is done right.  If this were my first introduction to quail I would never order it again.

To make matters worse when our waiter (or busboy) came by to collect our appetizer dishes.. and my uneaten quail remained on the dish I mentioned that it was really overdone and I got a "thank you" in reply.    

I did have a lovely light colored beer SpeakEasy The Witness (on tap) to wash down the appetizer.  The watercress was decent although one of those difficult items to serve and eat with chopsticks due to the long stems and small leaves.   

For dinner we each ordered the clay pot.  My friend got the fish $10 and I got the gulf prawns $14.   I'm not quite sure what I was expecting after hearing the waiter tell another table that the prawns were much more flavorful than the fish and he would recommend that dish over the fish by far.   

What I received was 5 prawns iin the bottom of a clay pot with some sauce and spices.  I really think it was 5 shrimp (not prawns) .. they were about 2.5 inches (including the tail) and if they had  been straightened out might have been 3 inches from end to end. They weren't even particularly large for shrimp.  After the quail fiasco, I was really hoping they weren't overcooked.   The prawns were "edible"  not quite completely rubbery  but slightly overdone and a bit more chewy than you expect them to be served at your restaurant table.   It was kind of like the way prawns feel after you take them home and reheat them in the microwave the second night.

Along with my 5 prawns (that would easily fit in the palm of my hand)  came a bowl of rice on the side and a small dish with some bean sproutsetc.    Our chopsticks had been removed from the table with the appetizers and we each received a Chinese style ceramic soup ladle spoon for mixing and eating our dishes.   My friend's fish dish was pretty similar although her fish actually covered the bottom of her clay pot (the clay bowl was about 5 or 6 inches in diameter).  When she added her rice and her sprouts the bowl  had rice about an inch over the rim and she still had rice in the bowl.  When I added  my rice my rice sat about a half inch or more below the rim of my clay bowl.  My dish was actually pretty tasty, but I really don't think 5 average sized slightly overcooked shrimp and rice are worth the $14 price tag when the fish dish provides so much more food.  

They did bring out the house made siricha when we requested it and some lemongrass pickled hot spice.  Both of the house made condiments were quite tasty. We did have to request a spoon to go with the condiments.  Except for the shrimp portion of my dish I would give it a decent rating and even with the over cooked shrimp it was probably worth of a 3 out of 5 ... although not good enough for me to want to go back and try another dish. 

The meal came to $50 total for 2 .. (a beer, a tea, an appetizer, and 2 clay pots) which I think was rather pricey for what we got although not a price to complain about. 

As for the service it was interesting.   I was sitting against the wall and observing the other diners.  Dishes often came out and the servers weren't quite sure where to serve them .. we were nearly served the entrees for the table of 3 - 2 table down from us.  A table of gentleman on the other side of us were served an entree that they did not order - a bowl of pho rather than a plate of meat. By the time his correct plate arrived his companions were nearly finished with their meals.   Our meals were served correctly.   Although I found myself lacking in water at points in the meal,  I always had some liquid available to drink.  

Hopefully the service and cooking improve. This place has potential.
author: Cat C.

description: Decent Pho with good ingredients, but nothing special. I've received my pho warm, not hot, more than once here. The noodles have also been clumped once or twice.
author: Ben G.

description:
This become one of my favorite restaurant.  I been here few times now and the food was really good and consistent.  
Service was pretty decent, good place to eat
author: js w.

description:
I'm Vietnamese. Took my mom here (who's pretty picky about her Viet food). She enjoyed it, and I was relieved.

I love the authentic cuisine mixed with polite, communicative, professional waiting staff. Would go here again and again.

So many good dishes - I'd recommend trying anything with lemongrass.
author: T N.

description: If the service would have been better I would have given this place four stars. The pho was delicious (I had the tofu) and my wife enjoyed her dry noodle bowl. The baby bokchoy sautéed with garlic was fresh and tasty and the spring rolls were solid. The service was a miss, though. We weren't brought the pho bowl accompaniments and had to ask twice for them, it took over five minutes to get chili sauce, and the one drink we ordered came after the food was served. I'll be back to eat, but I hope the service can improve.
author: Brian J.

description: I had high hopes for this place going in as it opened during Tu Lan's renovation and I was in need of a go-to spot.  This place just didn't deliver.  Imperials rolls and Thit Nuong are pretty much the yardstick of vietnamese cuisine and they weren't as good as most other places I've tried in the area.  And it's a bit pricier than your average VM spot.
author: D D.

description: I can not get over how delicious the food is! I know I'm going to get hate mail over this, but it's even better than Sunflower! Of course having hot wait staff doesn't hurt either.
author: Pandora B.

description: Thoughtful and well executed. Our table devoured the amazing Cha Gio rolls. The Shaken Beef was cooked perfectly it just needed some red chili love. The Malbec was a great match. The Ginger Chicken was hyper ginger and tumeric. I could not eat a ton. The Shrimp Hot Pot was the hands-down winner of the table. Very afffordable eats for SF. Go here now.
author: Staci W.

description:
Weird pseudo-Mexican decor inside (plus Mexican beers on the menu), but this place has the best Vietnamese food I've ever had. Pork belly anything is delicious. The pho is the freshest I've ever tasted and the flavors incredibly complex.

Service was simple and efficient, waiter was chill and not overbearing at all. Prices are really cheap for the cool, thoughtful ambience. Blends the line between a place for a somewhat quick lunch and a nice place for a longer dinner.
author: Nicholas R.

description: Obsessed with MAU! What else can I say...Their claypots are amazing, pho is absolutely amazing, and bok choi is out of this world! I come to Mau at least twice a week- the menu is very reasonably priced and the food is exceptional! Definitely one of my favorite spots in SF!
author: Sheryl P.

description: Ate here with a couple of friends today. Services wasn't great but the food was really yummy. I had their pho ga which I believe was made with free range chicken. I don't care if it is or not, but thought the food was very good. Garnishments was very much on the weak side but love the chilly that comes on the side. I tried one of my friend's grill pork, and will say, it was very good. Probably better than any place I've had in a while.
author: Alexander N.

description: I tipped 15% for the lousy service I got, but they increased the amount to 20%. Good thing I check my credit card statements. Not going back.
author: Gigi S.

description:
Mau has become a staple for weekly dinners! It has stood out amongst the influx of new restaurants opening and closing everyday in our hood. The ambience is lively, yet roomy, so we always manage to get seated quickly even with a large group. 

The food is tasty, fresh and reasonably priced (which is rare in our hip neighborhood these days)! My favorites are the Hue Rolls and any of the clay pots.  I tend to drink the Limeade too fast because its so delicious! 

My only gripe is they're closed on Sundays, because just talking about it makes me want to go tonight!
author: kris p.

description: Solid experience - started, as I do always, with the baseline: Chicken Wings & Mixed Beef Pho (Sliced beef, brisket, tendon, tripe, and anything else we can toss in) - chicken wings were good (not great) - lightly fried with nothing as per coating or batter (mixed feelings on this approach) - the quality of the wings were great, and taste was good, just like to see a little more put into it (light panko crust for example).  Moved on to the Pho and that was also very good (not quite Turtle Tower quality - that is still the one to beat for me) - menu overall was good and had lots to choose from, will be back.
author: Richard D.

description: Ordered Pho Ga and Cha Gio. Good food, OK service, but chicken in the Pho was essentially remains of meat after making soup stock. It was tough and dry than what I'm used to. Broth was good, not too much cilantro. I would go back to try it again or something else.
author: T A.

description: The food was fine but nothing to go out of your way for. We had the Mango Salad with tofu, garlic noodles, and the tofu noodle dish. The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't good, it was just ok. Dessert, the banana cake, was pretty bad. It was actually burnt and obviously microwaved.
author: Mini A.

description: Great food! Better than slanted door for sure! The pho has a nice flavor and not overpowering. The broth is clear not grimy like the TL places. Next time I gotta try the clay pot items they smell so good!
author: H M.

description:
First off, I want to say that I was going to write a positive review for Mau after a dinner there just one week earlier.  I was disappointed that Mau had reviews skewing not great and I thought after my first two meals there that it was just misunderstood.  I live in the neighborhood and it's very frustrating that there are so many new restaurants in the 'hood and that so many of them are not "accessible" to the people who actually live in the mission (from a $, reservation and crowds perspective).

Thought this place was misunderstood, but not after tonight's dinner.  

1. Epically bad service.  We were told three times that we would be seated right away, just to be seated right away and then no one came to take our order for over ten minutes.

2. The waiter (red shirt, black suspenders, heavy accent) was short and borderline rude.  Hint: the first time that you speak in a full, polite sentences in your interaction with the customers should not be once you are returning the credit card receipts for signing.

3. The best part is the food.  I really liked the vermicelli bowl and the five spice chicken rice plate.  The soup was underwhelming.

4.  Clearly understaffed so the waiters are running around like crazy people and forgetting about customers.  Service was slow and while we were waiting to put in our order after being forgotten about post-seating, I witnessed one of the two waiters disavow us as "his table" when the hostess/manager pointed out that we had been abandoned.
author: S S.

description: Pho is crazy good. Veggie spring rolls are warm!! Excellent!
author: pouria m.

description: sibling of Tin restaurant. Same great food and prices, even better neighborhood. Try the hue rolls!
author: Daniel V.

description: Simple and delicious. The hua rolls were a good surprise. The bun was bun. The meats were moist, flavorful and lean. If you forced me to rank them I'd say, lemongrass pork, chili chicken, grilled beef - photo finish. We were seated right away, but did wait a looonger than average time to order, to get the food, to get the bill. Lighting no bueno.
author: J. R.

description: Nice, just nothing special.  It was good to have a pho and KNOW that it was vegetarian appropriate, which is a bonus to me, but otherwise I don't think i would need to come back here.
author: Phil J.

description: Phenomenal service at the bar. Great descriptions and recommendations of the dishes which was wonderful for newbies like us. The chef was very interested to see our reactions to each dish which was fun. Very good experience. We'll be back!
author: Nicole O.

description: The food is great! I love the fish claypot.
author: J M.

description: Excellent tasting Vietnamese.  My group of four shared the lemongrass beef with vermicelli, lemongrass chicken with vermicelli, the five spice chicken with rice and the fish clay pot.  Every dish was delish! Service was all-hands-on-deck style, one main waiter with others to help bring out food.  Never felt neglected at this busy place.  Decor was simple but interesting, with a fresh wall mural and basket weave lighting.   Again, busy and buzzing but I never felt forgotten.  My group (including 2 chefs) all felt full, satisfied and that everything tasted yummy.
author: Kristin C.

description: So glad there's a good Vietnamese restaurant in the Mission finally!!!  This place is awesome...the dishes are delicious and affordable, and the staff quite friendly.  I am Vietnamese and I give this place a big thumbs up (unlike Sunflowers restaurant a block away where I tried a few times but always walked away feeling meh...).  The Pho bo here is the best...no MSG, generous portion of meat, and tasty soup.  I haven't tried the rice and vermicelli dishes...but am sure they are worth every penny as well.
author: nicole l.

description: Came here with an old friend. Some good Vietnamese food and some Chinese food options. First place I've seen with my favorite breakfast meal from Vietnam - Bun Rhieu, was really excited. It's good with solid portions. I wasn't amazed by the flavones of the tomato soup base though.
author: Deanna L.

description: Best Asian food in the mission! It may not look like it when you first walk in but this really is amazing food!
author: Curry F.

description: I didn't actually eat here. I was ignored by the "host", who I found out is actually the manager who also works waiting tables (I assume to make more money). When he finally came over he greeted the couple behind me and offered them a table. When I spoke up and said I had been waiting, he ignored me. I just left. I don't care how good the food is / supposed to be. I can't support businesses that behave like this.
author: Lake Y.

description: Mau is amazing! We have been there many times and never had to wait, the food is always delicious, and the service is fantastic. Hooray for Mau!
author: Laura P.

description: Im a fan of Mau, I ate several times in this Vietnamese restaurant and I think that  the food is amazing, the price is great and the service is good.
author: Jillian H.

description: This place is amazing. I usually do not like to pay for overpriced vietnamese food, but this place is well worth it. Their crepe, banh mi, spicy noodle soup and pork sausage are soooo delicious. I've been there 3 times within a month and can't wait to go back again to try at least everything on the menu.
author: Pei P.

description: The service tonight was great and our waiter was attentive and kept apologizing for the delay with our food.  The restaurant was only 2/3 full but many phone orders kept ringing in.  I watched as the food came out of the kitchen and into bags to fill the to-go orders.  My table finally got their food after an hour wait.  Ridiculous!  The night manager should be fired and the owners should get their priorities straight or change your business to take-out so people don't waste their evening sitting inside the restaurant.
author: Kim L.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this place.  First time I had Bun Bo Hue and crepe and it was delicious.  But I prefer my noodles more 'al dente.'  Much more interesting than the usual bowl of pho.  Crepes were also tasty.  Nice decor.
author: Eric C.

description:
Pricier than many of the pho places I frequent in, say, Chinatown or Little Saigon, Mau is definitely still pleasing. The fantastic aroma of lemongrass is what got me to notice this restaurant, while walking by. Later the same week brought my girlfriend for dinner. We were seated immediately about half way back in their large-ish dining room. One notices immediately how many staff persons there are, and that there are a good number of tables. I'd describe the dining room as casually chic. 
I ordered the Bo Kho, or braised shank pho, with brisket, carrot and basil. The broth was meaty and rich, spiced but not spicy, and opted for the egg noodles though a baguette is also an option on the menu and likely goes well for soaking up. I was pleased to see that two varieties of saison are listed, and chose the honey saison. Also ordered the sauteed vegetable of the day, which happened to be bok choy, scissored into bite-sized bits and drizzled with sesame oil. My girlfriend ordered the Pho Bo, which seemed a more traditional type of pho, with thinly-sliced brisket. Her only complaint was that her broth wasn't scalding hot, the way she appreciates. 
We managed to get out of there having spent about fifty bucks, which is pleasing by comparison to most other places currently situated on the Valencia corridor. 
Will absolutely return for another go.
author: Brian G.

description: Food was very good.  We had the vegetarian spring rolls (Vietnamese style with mint and lettuce leaves) and the traditional beef pho and the vegetarian pho.  All was great and brought back fond memories of Vietnam.  Service was also very good - fast, attentive and very friendly.  Will definitely be back.
author: Eliette K.

description: This is a review of their Pho bo. It's fabulous and hits the spot on a cold chilly day. The ingredients are fresh and clean. The beef tender and medium rare. Homemade sriracha is great. The service was attentive. To put this review in perspective, I have gone twice and it was during lunch and the work week, therefore the restaurant was not crowded. I also had the green papaya salad and it was very good, could have been a little more spicy, but I like my food hot, hot, hot. I am fairly confident that had I requested that the salad be spicy, they would have done that.
author: Pamela W.

description: I found Mau's last fall and I have been many 20 times since. Valencia street is a happening area, the ambiance is great and the food is delicious. They make all their own broths and sauces. Try the lemongrass chili condiment on anything, to die for. Not only are they affordable but delicious. A must if you enjoy vietnamese.
author: Lana B.

description: Great spring rolls and soups. Sweet, attentive servers and good people watching by the front window.
author: Lauren C.

description: Very good, if over-priced, Vietnamese food. But hey, you get to also try things like ginger and tea infused beer! Large space, so fairly easy to get a table. Definitely a reliable spot for dinner in you're in the area. If you're craving noodles and have time to wait, try Ken Ken Ramen around the corner.
author: Charlotte C.

description: I absolutely love their vegetarian pho. It is the best I have ever had. The vegetables are incredibly fresh and the flavor is wonderful. I see they have great reviews for their vegetarian spring rolls, so I am excited to try that next time.
author: Hayley T.

description: Love the bun with lemongrass pork.  I go for lunch fairly often and I really enjoy it.  I will give a slight ding because occasionally the pork seems to have been cooked too long before serving it, and it comes out a little cold and dry.  I know this is a cold, salad-type dish, but when the pork comes hot off the grill it's awesome.
author: Terry C.

description: Reasonably-priced Vietnamese food with a trimmed down modern decor. They have a fairly simple menu too, but really good.
author: Heather D.

description: Came here on a Friday night, the wait was only about 10 minutes. To date I have not visited a good Vietnamese spot, but man I think I finally found it because this place was GOOD! We ordered the steamed rice wrap spring rolls with shiitake mushrooms for an appetizer, which were outstanding. I ordered the tofu clay pot which had shiitake mushrooms, carrots, broccoli and my boyfriend ordered the PHO which was also very delicious. I also HIGHLY recommend getting the young coconut, it was so refreshing and tasty. Finally, the service was outstanding our server took time to actually get to know us, tell us to come back and gave us an awesome run down of the menu. We will be back again soon!
author: Marina S.

description: The wait staff was pleasant and the food okay, but the wait time for dishes to be served was just awful.  We won't be coming back.
author: Thomas C.

description: service is good. food is ok...claypot comes without any vegetable thats a point minus..
author: Shuting Z.

description: I gave this a poor review 2 years ago because of a service problem. I want to remove my earlier review, but Yelp will not allow that, only an edit.
author: Blake G.

description: Food was good and tasty. I'm not Vietnamese but I think this is more Americanized. The portions are also really small. I'm 5'2 and 120 pounds and wasn't full. So average sized people, beware lol.
author: L M.

description: The food is good and i have been going there for a few years now.  However, I finally saw the owner and witnessed how badly he treated the staff.  I tried to intercede but he turned out to be a complete asshole.  I would never help this person make a profit this way!  Stay away!
author: Bennie F.

description: I got a pho ga. The broth was not flavorful enough. And with pho flavor is everything. So no I am not impressed. The ambiance is hipsterish. Play crap music in the background that has nothing to do with vietnam or its food. I can't say much for the other food cause I did not try it. But you gotta get the pho right man.
author: Neeraj K.

description: I had dinner here last night with my boyfriend, and was pleasantly surprised that the food was so good. We shared the Cha Gio as an appetizer, which was very good, and I had the fish claypot while he had the pho. I loved the fish - it was spicy and delicious. My boyfriend reported that the pho was okay, but not amazing. The service was slow, but friendly.
author: Shoshana L.

description: Vietnamese food for White people.  If you enjoy authentic Vietnamese food, you're much better off going to the Sunset or even one of the places on Mission.  MNot worth the money at all.  Bland food, crowded, no parking and overall too pretentious for ethnic cuisine.
author: Sheila S.

description: This Vietnamese restaurant is great! The best thing about it in my opinion are the number of delicious, satisfying vegetarian options on the menu.  The tofu pho is by far and away the most richly flavorful broth I have found.  The bowl is loaded full of bright vegetables, the noodles are done perfectly and it is a really balanced and delicious meal. The vegetarian hue rolls are also not to be missed.  Anytime I am out of town for a while, as soon as I come back to town I need my Mau fix!!  They also have delicious cocktails that pair really well with the food.  Its got a great, casual ambiance.  The only reason I don't give this place all 5 stars is because the service can be very slow.  It would be great if they were open on Sundays! Great restaurant!!!!
author: L S.

description: I've given this place a few more tries since my initial review. Only for lunch though. Bun with grilled pork and imperial rolls were good and a reasonable lunch special deal, so I tried the pho again. It was better. In fact, it might even be the best pho on the block now.
author: Will R.

description: the veg spring rolls were packed with delicious tofu and mushrooms and the veg noodle bowl was sweet and creamy (we added extra veggies, ie. broccoli). yummmm. my lady friend and i split everything and the bill was quite reasonable. we were real full and then the server surprised us with a coconut bread pudding treat! total win. AND the window spot was killer for making eyes at passing babes.
author: Amber S.

description: I ate here in November 2012, so I hope Mau has gotten better since my experience. First, when we sat down we let the waiter know we were in a bit of a rush. He doesn't return to take our order for 15 to 20 minutes. Second, I ask for no onions in my food. My food comes covered in onions. I bring this to his attention, and he half-heartedly apologizes and takes it back to the kitchen. Again I mention we are in a hurry. So, I share my boyfriend's meal waiting for my food. His noodle dish was bland and unexciting. By the time my food comes out, I ask for it to be packed immediately and for the check. The guy that brought my food out took forever to bring me a container and the check doesn't arrive with the container. Our server is nowhere to be seen and I finally flag another server down and explain our situation. He gets our server who brings the check. The only thing our server did right was to comp my meal. Not impressed with my meal by the time I eat it. Not impressed at all.
author: K H.

description: A refreshing addition to the Valencia corridor in the mission. Not at all pretentious and yumm yumm food :)
author: Rashmi V.

description: Pho is consistently good. Be prepared for running nose; the soup is awesome! Nice low key ambiance. Service is good as well.
author: teatzar s.

description: I had a horrific experience at this place yesterday for lunch.  The service is just plain bizarre and inept.  My table, along with the table next to us, waited over 30 minutes to have our orders taken, despite repeated requests for someone to serve us.  Several workers acknowledged our situation, apologized, and then left doing nothing to fix the problem!  While we were ignored, I watched our "server" take orders from newly seated guests, run food, pour water, and stand blankly staring at the computer.  Both of our tables placed orders only after I insisted that someone take our orders.  It gets worse.  While waiting for our food, a cockroach is crawling next to me on the bench I was seated at.  We got up and left, while the hysterical person next to us jumps up on the bench and starts screaming.  That actually almost made it all worth it!  It seems  this business is taking its success for granted and not putting good systems in place.
author: Joan J.

description: Two stars only because the pho was all right. The beef salad is horrendous. Do yourself a favor and stay the hell away from it. Fish in clay pot tastes good, but it's expensive and the portion is very small. The service was the worst I've experienced in years! The manager said they were under-staffed, but did he jump in to help? Nah. Definitely not going back.
author: Kathy R.

description: For all the parents out there, Mau is an amazing place for lunch. The staff is welcoming to the toddler set and offers every accommodation to make the meal easy. After getting the stink-eye in other hip places in the mission, it was a breath of fresh air to be welcomed with open arms here and offered drinks in child appropriate cups with  straws immediately as well as delivery of food asap for the more demanding clientele. Everything else was prompt and delicious to the adult palette too. Really more than that. The food is divine. We loved everything we tried Soup, Bun etc. I was just so blown away by the accommodating service which s such a refreshing surprise! I will return again and again.
author: Betsy R.

description:
My meal at Mau last night was amazing. I want to go back and try more of the offerings on the menu -- I'd go back just for the Hue Rolls as a starter. It was grilled pork with mint wrapped in a rice noodle roll with a yummy dlpping sauce, and all the flavors together were fresh, tart and savory all at once. We also had the shrimp clay pot.The flavors were chili and sweet. The rice was served on the side so I mixed everything up in the clay pot.  It was different than what I'm used to at the Vietnamese restaurants in Oakland where everything is baked together in the clay pot and the rice gets crunchy. But delicious still. We also ordered the sauteed greens, which was bok choi last night. I have never had bok choi made so tender and seasoned perfectly with salt and pepper. It was easy and delightful to eat and I would go back for that also. My friend had lemongrass chicken and she loved it too. We loved the housemade Sriracha which had a certain brightness to it.

The service was fast and friendly. The atmosphere and furnishings were comfortable and I was told they were all hand-made out of repurposed wood.

This is definitely the trendy Mission's version of Vietnamese. But Chef Kai, who is herself Vietnamese, has put together some typical dishes and all the flavors merge well together and have flare and freshness. Also I thought the pricing was really good compared to the new Mission restaurant scene. Can't wait to go back and try the Bun!
author: Nadia K.

description: I'm of Vietnamese descent so can be a bit picky about food from the homeland.  Mau is pretty solid and surprisingly affordable for such a hip decor on Valencia St.The menu is full of very traditional Vietnamese dishes. We started with the cha gio which were a bit greasy but we really enjoyed our Pho Ga and Bun Thit Nuong.  The broth for the Pho - a true litmus for Vietnamese food - was delicious.  The service was good - super nice waiter who apologized for not being able to pronounce everything on the menu authentically and they didn't blink an eye when our 20 month old made a huge mess and made himself very at home here.  I know people are commenting on how overpriced they felt it was - we found it reasonable ... $30 for two (and a half of us) and we had full tummies.  Our other Vietnamese go-to in the neighborhood (Thanh Tam II) is slightly cheaper but the people in there often seem grumpy and the tv is always on.  We'll definitely be back - I want to try the banh mi!  I hope folks will give it a chance... we can't all be overpriced Italian pizzerias!
author: A H.

description: The shaken beef rocks and so do the spring rolls. I'm a fan. Consistent good food with strong (and sometimes too salty) flavors.
author: nana b.

description:
the best vegetarian pho in San Francisco! just one think!... I'm always need more houstin sauce! 
service... really good! 
food... excelent! my boyfriend ate the pho Bo  and he said ... just what I need!
author: ZOnia G.

description: First of all let me start by saying this restaurant was highly recommended, what a disappointment.  I ordered the fish clay pot, Horrible is an understatement, unless you enjoy farmed raised fish soaked in soy sauce.  It was extremely salty.  Our waiter gave us the wrong order, yes he did make up for it by taking care of two of our beers.  The beef shank dish was awesome, but for less of a hassle I would try Ben Tre restaurant in SSF.
author: Saira C.

description: Good vegetarian options, nice ambiance, good service, but food is ok. I ordered the tofu pho with extra garlic and veggies; didn't like the extra 2.50 charge for the veggies, which the waiter did not mention to me earlier, but did like that the noodles were flavored with lemongrass (nice change from bland vegetarian pho). One of the better Vietnamese restaurants I have been to but by no means the best.
author: Sofia T.

description: It's really 3.5 stars.  I have tried almost everything on the menu and for the price, the quality, it's damn good full of the fresh flavors I love about Vietnamese food.  Let go of your pre-conceived notions about what Pho should be and how much it should cost.  Making this soup is labor, labor, labor.  These guys pull it off well.  When it gets really crowded the service gets spotty and that's why it didn't get the big 4 stars.   But other than that, it's a staple.
author: FairReviews A.

description: This place has changed my opinion of pho for life. We walked in at 7:45 on a Saturday night and got seated straight away. The place was busy, but not pretentiously overpacked with hipsters. The hostess, Alex, was super sweet and helpful. The tofu pho and lemongrass tofu dishes were amazing. I loved the depth that was added to the dishes with the various sauces, thai basil, garlic, house made hot sauces, jalapenos, etc. I actually dislike soup and pho, but this has officially converted me. I absolutely will go back. Thank you Alex for helping us with our selections and being so hospitable.
author: Divya P.

description: This is my new go-to restaurant in the Mission. Nice big space, friendly accommodating waitstaff, and day-amn good food. I'm not a vietnamese food eater by nature (apparently, I can't even spell that), but Mau's take on it features super fresh vegetables, well-balanced flavors, and an inspired mixture of ingredients. I highly recommend it.
author: Todd A.

description: Very nice and hip environment. Their grilled dishes are great - the Ha No Cha for example. Great Vietnamese drinks are good. My one complaint is that their soups are not as good as their dry dishes - probably not their specialty.
author: Quynh T.

description: It's taken me over a year to find good Pho! Mau is great, well priced, nice service, yummy food. I don't really understand why it's not busier, I've never had to book in advance and have always been seated straight away. Great to see that they have tofu pho on the menu too, that can be hard to find!
author: Claire R.

description: The food is good enough for take out which is all I've ever gotten here.  It's fast, not crazy expensive, and tasty enough.  Not spectacular but no real complaints.
author: Stacy M.

description: So far they have had consistent food, good service ( carry out with in 5-7 mins) and great atmosphere.  I have had several of the bun bowls which are always fresh, and on the money. I have not tried the pho or hot pot but planning on it in the future.
author: Chloe W.

description: Delicious, healthier version of Vietnamese food in the Mission...all made with local organic ingredients.  Portions and prices are good, too.
author: Fogdog M.

description: Excellent.  Most yelp reviews herein are accurate.  It does not look like an 'authentic' Vietnamese restaurent; however, the decor is bright and attractive and the food could not be better.  As our world diversifies, White peeps can serve and cook oriental, Cajun or African food as authentically as anyone else.   It is a matter of attention to details and common sense, so lacking is some many things today.  Eat there, you will enjoy it.  The rice noodle appetizer is sooo good.  The 5 spice chicken is superb; and the 'White guy' waiter is just lots of fun.
author: Dannette P.

description: I live in the neighborhood and I've liked every dish I've had here! I usually do takeout, but have eaten in the restaurant once and found the service to be good, if not a little TOO attentive. I usually get the pho ga, but the waiter suggested we start with the hue rolls (pork spring rolls) and they were excellent! Really tasty. I hope this restaurant does well and stays in the neighborhood.
author: Margaret G.

description:
totally unexpected. the food was delicious and the service was memorable (in a very good way). the menu was tough for someone who eats healthy, but i got the clay pot chicken and a papaya salad. both were excellent... and the papaya salad tasted quite different than any i have had before.

great food, excellent service, and no wait. :)
author: Matt C.

description: Excellent pho at a good price. Sure, it's not a hole in the wall price; but your stomach will thank you for choosing a cleaner kitchen. Plus, the ambiance is rather nice! I've only eaten here a handful of times, but I've never been disappointed.
author: Severin C.

description: Took 15 minutes to get noticed at our table, AFTER we sat down on our own because none of the staff came to greet & seat us. We ordered two rice bowls, which took 45 minutes when the restaurant was half empty. The server hardly checked in with us, and they were out of several items by 8pm. The competition is too high on Valencia, also read the latest wine article by Bauer. Later Mau.
author: J A.

description: Normally I would say does Valencia really need another asian restaurant? in the case of Mau I say yes! Not only do they make everything from scratch including the delicious brined pork belly that they use for their rice bowel and a scorching habanero sriracha but the prices are reasonable. We also got the beef salad which had tender flavorful beef cooked to a perfect medium as well as a side of flavorful fresh greens and the whole fish for two which is stuffed with fresh herbs and chilies yum! What also sets them apart is that they have a dessert menu that's not an after-thought my boyfriend is a sweet fiend so we got both the plum bread pudding with lemon grass custard glaze and the coconut tapioca with mango and toasted coconut. The bread pudding was fluffy yet creamy with delicious roasted plums on top. The tapioca was pure comfort food but the mango added a great tart component. Definitely going back soon!
author: Rebecca O.
